I think teachers should be more strict on attendance so more students will show up to class.
There seems to be a sense of superiority from the Greek side vs. the non-greeks, but not enough to where it's a problem.
There is a ton of school spirit, especially during basketball season.
Campus crime has been increasing lately and it seems to not be as big of a deal as it should be because of the lack of notice/ lateness of notice being given to the students.
I wish I had more scholarships for my awesome grades.
I've heard it's pretty great, don't have experience myself though.
We have the best choice of restaurants, I promise. You have to try Fuzzy's Taco Shop and Pizza Shuttle!
Don't have a whole lot of experience with it, but it's trying it's hardest.
A lot of bad reputations.
dont know much about it, new student
Best basketball team around the area. Basketball games in the student section are unforgettable and give you chills.
I like it here at Park 25 a lot. You can find an apartment that fits your needs and wants easily, there are tons of choices. I love this college town, it's amazing.
It's great if you are into basketball, but the football program is a total embarrassment.
It's Kansas, need I say more?
Amazing selection for the middle of no-where. There are some great options.
They are just punching the time clock, they don't really want you to report crimes because they may have to actually investigate. They have a handshake agreement with the local police.
They are building some new ones, that should help. What is there now is dated and run down.

KU is surrounded by a college ghetto of old homes that have been converted into multi-unit habi-trails of bad smells and mold. Apartment complexes are located a little further out and are your typical thin-walled cheap affairs designed for minimum building cost and maximum profit. Only a handful of individuals control the lion's share of properties so you are going pay premium money for a marginal place.

It's awesome if you are into just hanging out and pounding beers, that kind of action can be found almost every night through out the college ghetto. They have pretty good bands in the joints on Mass, but they are expensive and most definitely mid-western hobunky. If you are into something more sophisticated and worldly, Lawrence just doesn't cut it but if you like pick up trucks, hipster beers and plaid shirts, this is the town for you.
The basketball games have a great atmosphere and basketball especially gets a lot of public attention and is the center of almost everything!
I feel safe but not too safe, I know that there are cameras almost everywhere but it doesn't mean it still can't and won't happen without with being seen.

Off campus housing is convenient when you live close to campus but if you not there are buses that will take to you class but they aren't always reliable. I think its a lot harder to make friends with people if you live off campus but there are other ways around that.

Off campus there are a variety of different options to choose from but not all of the dining options are convenient driving wise. The best place right now to try out would have to be Burgerfi which just open in Lawrence on Massachusetts Street a few weeks ago!
The University of Kansas is not very strict, since its a very liberal school but it does have standards and rules students must abide by.
Fun and supportive college town.
Lots of variety. Nice facility
I feel safe. There are people I can call if I need to walk at night on campus.
Not too bad at all!
Love the multidisciplinary research building for NMR analysis.
Great atmosphere and the friendliness of the city is next to none!
sports are huge here! even football which we do not excel at everyone still comes out in support. We have the best fan base!
Getting Scholarships here seems impossible and for those people like me who really need them makes attending an expensive school very stressful.
Tonic is the best club around Lawrence. There is always a great mix of great people ready to just let loose. No fights and little to no danger.
There are always shows and places to go on the weekend to distract you from studying. Atmosphere aside from school is great!
Depending on where you live and who your landlord is there can be huge variations in cleanliness and work that needs to be done. Best options would be the refurnished apartments off campus.
There are tons of places to choose from! Great food and a variety of cuisines.

There are loads of opportunities for off campus living. Some may be farther away than others but there is a great bus system that runs throughout Lawrence that allows students to get from class and back home in a timely fashion.

I love my major and the classes surrounding it that I have taken I greatly enjoy. However there are many mandatory classes that have nothing to do with the career path I hope to pursue and those classes are very challenging for me. My GPA has suffered because I cannot achieve good grades in those classes but they are mandatory for me to take in order to graduate.

I have a lot of friends in the greek life here on campus and they always have nothing but great things to say about the greek system. It just was not for me. I still get invited to events in the greek atmosphere and I don't feel treated much different because I am not in a greek house.

Our university views safety and school policies as a top priority. From cheating in classes to sexual assaults in our guide lines there are clear identifications that these actions will not be tolerated from neither a school nor legal standard. Our university seeks to keep this atmosphere as safe and secure as possible for all its faculty and students in attendance.
I personally feel like living off campus is a bad idea. It's harder to make friends, and be in activities. It may be cheaper if enough research is done, but the cons outweigh the pros in my opinion.
I have never had the opportunity to experience an internship, but I have shadowed a chiropractor and a physical therapist. The experience helped greatly in my career planning and livelihood decision.

There are may attractions and fun things to do off campus, but the safety issue needs to be addressed, especially where the campus policy on rape is concerned. A rapist was let off with some community service and an essay here, and the victim was harassed and blamed. This doesn't inspire confidence in my own safety here.

We at KU host the worlds best Quidditch team. We are Ferocious!

Additionally the rec center is excellent, and always clean. The cycling team is not well followed but very good. I don't think I could neglect to mention basketball. The basketball team is very popular.

As a vegetarian, I was very pleased to see all of the options given in this community. Even in the residence halls there were vegetarian and even vegan options for almost every meat option. There are coffee shops that are open all night on campus that also sell food, and off campus dining is generally affordable and close.

The campus is strict about substance abuse and alcohol consumption, but they realize that things like underage drinking and partying will happen, so students are given resources to protect themselves as well.

Though I am not a member of a Greek community I find that the volunteer work and projects undertaken in the Greek fraternities and sororities to be both inclusive and helpful to other volunteer organizations and the community.
Most of the time, I can find something that I could have but there are not many options since I am vegetarian. Thankfully the rates are affordable so eating out once in while is not bad.
There is a health clinic that is accessible for all students that is located next to the rec center.
LFK. Lawrence F****** Kansas. One of the best college towns ever. A prime example of a great college town.

Most dorms are nice such as Lewis, Hashinger, GSP, and Naismith. However dorms like McCollum and Oliver are old and run down. Luckily, McCollum is being razed next year and future freshmen won't have to experience it.
Administration is always there to help make your lives easier.

There is always something to do in LFK. The Hawk and Cave are VERY lenient with fake ID's and there are always decent parties happening on the weekends. The only tough part is walking to these parties.

KU Basketball isn't a sport here. It's a religion. Our football team is going through some tough times right now and that is a big reason for the low fan turnout, but come basketball season, everyone is at Allen Fieldhouse.
So many different food options in Lawrence
There's ALWAYS something going on
Dorms are not only big but kept very clean and safe
There is no better place to watch basketball than Allen Fieldhouse.
Going greek was the best decision I have ever made. My sisters are absolutely amazing and have helped me transition to a big school in a different state

The university truly treats its students like adults and gives us full responsibility for our actions. Services, such as SafeBus and SafeRide, are there if we need them, but for the most part campus strictness is very lenient and fair.
There are some nice dorms but some are pretty old.
It was very difficult for me to pick a major and they don't really explain them to you.
The political science department offers lots of opportunities to help you find a job and get experience.
They are very strict when it comes to plagiarism and research
Campus is usually a very safe place and there are rarely any problems
parties on weekends are the best especially house parties
it helps you gain experience and skills for future work
campus safety cops are always on the look out for any suspicious activities
I dont know much about greek life
Great living off campus, apartments prices are reasonable to afford
Possession of fire arms is strongly prohibited
Great athletic program and fans are the best in the world
very exciting and students like to party a lot
Seems great for those that do that.
Like any scholarship opportunities there are requirements to meet and hoops to jump through.
I don't take part, but I know there are a lot of options for partying.
There's a lot of diversity. It's great.

At the University of Kansas getting my financial aid was easy. It was all link online and it told me what forms I needed to fill out. It have me an estimate of how much I needed and where to go if I needed more.

At the University of Kansas they send you an email with a housing guide if you do not choose to live on campus. This guide tells you the do's and dont's of choosing a place. It also gives links to apartments and other off campus living places.
Administration is very strict on some issues, like parking and plagiarism, but not so strict on others, like alcohol.
Most of the buildings are pretty old and the dorms are far from classes, but the overall quality of buildings and dorms isn't bad.
The best parties are house parties
Instead of telling my to come back in a couple months, give me types of scholarships I could earn.

The university does nothing to prevent sexual assaults. The university tries to hide sexual assaults and degrades women by giving out statements such as "Women who take birth control give consent to all sexual behaviors." As a young woman myself I feel unsafe on campus and not proud to be apart of this university.

Have you ever heard of Kansas men's basketball? It is the biggest sport on campus, but other sporting events are also attended and supported by students. Some of the less popular sports give out free things and sports other than football and men's basketball are free for students.
Greek life as a whole is viewed as cliquey but most students will get to know someone and not base their judgement of a person on their involvement in Greek life.
There are a variety of both local and chain restaurants in Lawrence.

This school is very old and isn't quite appealing to the eye. I haven't noticed a lot of places for students to sit outside and study on nice days. Also, the campus is on a hill, and it is A LOT of walking.
In my program, the class sizes are smaller than for a typical class on campus. The professors are alright. Some are better than others.
There are many job opportunities with the degree that I will be getting from this school. KU is a well-known institution.
I really haven't paid attention to the strictness on campus. I would guess it's alright.
It was a lot of hard work to get into my program. I feel though that even if I didn't have perfect grades/volunteer work, etc, I still could have gotten in.
I do enjoy my program, I've met most of my best friends there.
there are a lot of parties to go to. they dont get out of control as much and its nice to meet and see new people
There is variety but for me i love mexican food and there are not a lot of places.
i struggled with receiving my financial aid and for it to go cover my expenses
There are tons of things to do on campus as well as off campus and its not very far to get to them
Living on campus is great. there are a lot of nice people to socialize with.
the campus is not as close to get to your classes
i have not had an internship but i would like to have one for the experience.
its great because you are surrounded by people who have similar goals as you.
you have to check in at 11pm with your card if not you are not allowed to go your dorm
Not easy to find but near KC so it's convenient.
No problem at all, very helpful advisors.
I was a volleyball player last year, and even as a female team we were recognized and treated just like men's basketball... which is huge.
I really like my dorm (Oliver) but girls party too hard
I wish they would do more about the weed in the dorms, but nothing invasive or annoying by the cops. They make rounds every weekend at least.
Well, obviously our B-Ball team is one of the best, but I don't do sports.

I don't know much about it, but it's really easy to get it at KU. Not at all like the movies where the bitches only want other hot bitches, but it's a lot of money and you have to dedicate a certain number of hours to Greek events.
I love taking a walk down to Mass St where all the foods and cool shops are. Lawrence holds concerts and 5k runs often and the KU Rec center is pretty nice.
I was given 4 scholarships my freshman year, but each year the office seems to lose half of our FAFSA and verification paperwork which is confusing considering it's all sent electronically.
Pizza shuttle is open all night and taco bell is
There are tons of apartments and neighborhoods with rentable houses around here. It's nothing fancy, of course, but it can be great for a couple of friends getting together and splitting the cost.
Don't worry, don't stress. There's just endless amount of booze; you probably won't get caught.
My favorite classes were not my major classes. Art History and English classes were by far the most interesting/compelling courses for me. Great professors, great options.
The reason I go to school here is because of the alumni. As for job/internship prospects, that clearly depends on an individual's major and personal drive to succeed.
From what my friends have told me, start the process immediately.

Some departments are superb, others are just average. However, it has great resources for those interested in studying abroad, studying languages, and interested in hard sciences. However, their art and design program are not competitive programs in the long run. I'd say take classes there, but take advantage of going abroad to very good art schools at the price of KU enrollment.

I'm an illustration major. For one, the freshman courses were a joke. A lot of projects that have little to nothing to help improve our illustration skills. I did improve my graphic design skills, and now I can use a xacto knife to a piece of foamcore in a way that puts any novice to shame. However, I wanted to learn to draw, paint, etc., but my course load, even at 18 hours each semester, did not let me do that. The facilities for the design and art program students are great, but the faculty is currently limited to only thee professors, and they only have two professors that work full time. They put much more allure to the program based on the potential of what the program "could be" and not what it currently is. I was disappointed, which made me either consider switching to the graphics program or transferring to better school with a less bullshit program. I wasn't challenged in the way that I wished to be challenged, nor do I feel I gain skills in drawing or painting.

It's a really lovely college town. There are great places to eat, the living is good, but it can be a bit small. There comes a point when you become a local to the various places; not much to really experience newly.
I've been able to receive some scholarships, but as for financial aid in the form of loans, they weren't worth it to me to accept. :(

The campus is overall a very nice campus. The buildings all aesthetically match while still being different enough that one can easily tell them apart. There are two main places to eat on the main campus and both have a plethora of choices. There are also small food/drink stops all over campus; every library and building has one so you can always find something to eat. The libraries have great study areas and there are lots of computers to use. Printing is easy and each student gets some print money from there tuition each semester and you can always add more. Everyone on campus is friendly and will try to help out if you need it.

I think the diversity on campus is pretty great. There are many different types of students that you could interact with. And really, everyone is pretty accepting. You don't really hear or see any problems people have with fitting in or finding any friends. Even if someone is different, more than likely there's going to be someone who's just as different as them, and they would then connect and become friends.

Our school has one of the top men's basketball programs in the nation. So of course basketball is really big. Almost every game is sold out and students even have to camp out just to get into the games. At other sport events, the fan support is definitely still there. I would say my school has great school spirit. You always see lots of students getting involved.

When it comes to campus, I feel pretty safe at most times. There usually isn't a lot of violence that goes on during the school year on campus. I always make sure to not walk alone at night and to pay attention to my surroundings. There are security cameras on campus and there are also telephones that notify the police when the button is pressed all along the campus. I believe those are pretty helpful for students.
I absolutely love where I go to school. It's a great place for students and residents as well. The people are friendly and there are a lot of events to attend.
Campus dining is great. There are a lot of options.
I honestly don't pay much attention to those who aren't friends.
I think KU has a great reputation because of the knowledge that is imparted with every student when they leave here.
We have a lot of GTA's who are often a few years older than us. The math program at KU however is structured very poorly.
Campus strictness is average overall.
Lawrence has a great transportation system.
As with any school, KU's financial aid department often poses its own hurdles in receiving funding in an easy manner.
There is currently no greek housing for any of the Divine Nine chapters. I've never been involved in Greek life and don't know too much more about it on campus
I no longer party but when I did it was often hit and miss. Most of the clubs are the same and they could use a lot of improvement.
There is a lot of variety off campus. However, the pricing is usually a bit steep.
KU is known to have the some of the best fans/prideful students around and it shows in campus life. There's almost always something going on on campus.
I love the Rec center! They have everything: fitness equipment, tracks, numerous courts, racquetball, rock climbing, everything! There's so much to do and the equipment is modern and easy to use.
Although is a predominantly white campus, there is so much diversity. I just love it!

They provide a lot of options. I've seen a lot of different places like Asian cuisine, Indian, Vegan, Chinese, etc. There's definitely a lot of great pizza places with convenient prices; my favorites are Pyramid Pizza and Pizza Shuttle. There's also great places for treats like ice cream, coffee shops, Billy Vanilly cupcakes, and Hot Box cookies! (Must haves)

KU is a dry campus, so all dorm and scholarship halls are very strict when it comes to alcohol and drugs. Other than that, strictness on other matters depend on which halls you stay in. Most of them aren't strict on other matters besides, noise violations and controlled guest policies.

There's plenty of places to eat at KU. The main dining hall is Mrs. E's, located on Daisy Hill. I personally stayed in a scholarship hall with a unique meal plan so people within the hall cooked. Popular dining options are: Mr.s E's (Daisy Hill), the Underground (Wescoe Beach), and the Market (Kansas Union). There's a variety of options including Pizza Hut, Panda Express and Chic Fil A. There's also plenty of places outside of the campus that accepts Beak Em Bucks.

There's practically something to do every night. The most popular places to go to are: The Hawk, the Jackpot, the Grenada, Ice House, and Wilde's Chateau. KU is a party campus. There's always clubs, bars, or fraternity parties to go to. The'yr all pretty much a convenient distance from the campus. If you don't have a car then there's the SafeBus or NightLine.

A lot of the professors on campus are fairly relaxed. Registration was a breeze to get through! Class sizes are pretty small, meaning there are lectures but majority of the classes aren't set up this way. The workload depends on which professor you have; it typically ranges from reading a chapter a week to reading 1-2 chapters a day. However, there's plenty of help for any class; whether it's office hours, TAs, study groups, or tutoring. There will always be someone available to help you, don't be afraid to ask for help!

My major was Business (Accounting) and Cultural studies, with an emphasis on East Asian religion. The workload was pretty easy. My advice is to NEVER take chemistry and calculus within the same semester. With a business major, there is a building on campus, Summerfield Hall, that's specifically for business students; two words: GO THERE! They have a help room (absolutely free) that has saved lives/grades several times. It's literally a building filled with people who has been through the same courses that you are/will be taking & want to help. Also in that hall, they post facts, job employment opportunities, and anything else that is business related.

Generally, KU is a predominantly white campus but there are representatives of every culture all around. Guys tend to be more relaxed than you would typically imagine on a college campus. The students are pretty friendly and willing to talk/help when approached. I've even ran into some of the basketball guys and they are extremely friendly as well. There isn't a secret dress code that everyone seems to be following, just dress how you want; whether that's pants in the summer or shorts during the winter (yes, I have seen this several times throughout the year). There are multiple interests so it's easy finding people who are more like you.

I love the local atmosphere! Lawrence in general is a college town. There's downtown, "Mass St." with so many dining, shopping, and entertainment options. The cost of living is fairly average. The Granada is one of the main event attractions; we've had artists ranging from Christina Perri to Chance the Rapper and YG.Besides KU events, there aren't very many sporting events that happen. Overall, the scenery is beautiful and the people are generally very warm.

Student life is great! The staff are warm, welcoming and really friendly throughout the whole campus.The libraries have unlimited resources and amenities available, the librarians are very helpful and willing to aid in any way they possibly can. The campus is pretty live, meaning there's always something going on around the campus to get involved in. At the very beginning of the school year, there's HawkWeek, specifically for freshman to get acquainted and mingle. The campus is filled with a lot of traditions.
My program is fine, you get to meet a lot of people with the same major as you and that's always helpful.
Since I'm pre nursing its really just taking all the pre requisites for my major but its been fairly easy to get in to all the classes that I need for it.
I love being here now as a student but am not entirely sure I would want to stay on much past that. Not that Lawrence isn't fun, I just think would want a new chapter in my life.

The only time I can recall ever having sexual assault being brought up, every single person was notified through our school emails and so on so we all knew exactly what to be on the lookout for. Very helpful.
Again, if you can't find it, you aren't looking. When in Lawrence I can almost always find not only what I want to eat, but find it available when I want to eat it as well.

While I was annoyed with the blatant lack of aid that I received, I made an appointment with an advisor and after her helping me am now working on filling out the paper work I need to to be able to hopefully get the aid I'm looking for.
I would say again that there is such a variety that if you don't find somewhere that you enjoy living, you really probably just didn't look.

There really is always something going on in Lawrence, and we really do have such a wide variety of bars and things that there really is no reason to not be able to find some place you enjoy, unless you just seriously aren't looking.
I would say that the level of strictness they enforce the rules with is right on, it sounds like it is comparable to the other schools around but isn't super ridiculously strict.
I don't know any other school, at least not locally, that has the kind of pride for their basketball team that KU does. It's incredible and honestly moving to be in Allen field house during a game.
We have such a wide variety of food options I would be genuinely surprised if someone couldn't find a single thing that they wanted.

I needing help figuring out what to do after the nursing school I applied to said my ACT score of 28 was expired and id have to retake it, and my KU advisor helped me find a major that overlapped with what I've been taking for pre nursing but also is its own major so I have something to show for all the school I've finished and maybe then with a major, I'll go pre med instead.
I had a couple fairly close minded professors but that's how people are in any place, a couple will be. Overall, I love it here.
I am just getting more into my major this year. I am enrolled in more classes specifically for my major and am very excited about it.
I feel that the school is just trying to keep everyone safe, even though some people may feel that they are ruining the fun.
Everyone has their own style and personality.
Honestly, my parents helped a lot to take care of the process.

There is always something going on in Lawrence, Kansas! Whether it's a party or a bar, students always come out to have a great time. The Hawk is especially popular on Wednesdays, also known as dollar night.
I wouldn't want to be anywhere else. I love my school and campus. I feel that there is always a lot to do and everything is very safe. I have made a great amount of friends and memories.
The University of Kansas has a great amount of school spirit. Going to sporting events are a great experience. I am definitely proud to be a Jayhawk!
I feel very safe on campus. I have never had any threatening incidents and neither have any of the close circle of friends.
I really enjoyed all of my classes and most of my professors. Overall, I have had a great experience at the University of Kansas.
Personally, I haven't looked much into this topic. I do believe there is a great affiliation though.
There is a great diversity on campus. I feel that everyone can connect.

Oliver dining hall, which is the hall I lived in and ate at, was just okay. It was hard to find health options and the food didn't satisfy majority of the time. There were other dining halls on campus, like Mrs. E's that had a much larger variety of meals to choose from. It wasn't very convenient for me to get there often but I would occasionally find my way there.
Most people on campus are pretty down to earth and easy to get along with.
A great deal of international students come into KU ever semester. I have to admit that most people who go to KU are from some part of Kansas otherwise.

I immediately got a bit of financial aid from the school when I qualified for it through GPA and ACT exam scores. I managed to maintain my aid by managing to keep my GPA in the school over a certain level.

I think the English and History program at the University of Kansas are both pretty good but I have to admit that I prefer one over the other. The English Department has many great classes that have all topics one could wish for in American, African- American, British, Irish, and Latin American literature. I have not taken one class which I've regretted taking later. The teachers are also very approachable. The History Program is about the same in most respects. The professors are really nice and they do offer a wide range of classes that deal with many places throughout the world but it is also quite limiting in a way. This is especially true for the capstone classes. There are only a few classes on very specific subjects that you can take each semester.
I've never eaten in the dining halls but I hear they are terrible. Luckily there are a ton of options all over the city to eat, and many deliver.
Night life here is pretty great. Thursday nights are the best because there are so many drink specials and that's when everyone tends to go out. Mass is the place to be on Thursday nights.
Girls in this area are a little stuck up and can be huge partiers. But of course there are girls who aren't. Guys around here are pretty laid back.
I'm not a greek, it is just not for me. Many of the people who are tend to be a little snobbish. Some of the houses are nice while others are pretty run down. Pledging is definitely not for everyone.

Getting around the town can be a total nightmare, especially on game days. Many of the streets are small 2 lane roads that get jam packed with people and it can be impssible to turn into stores off the main streets.

As a psychology major there are a lot of options to expand my education. There are a lot of research opportunities and many hospitals and other facilities in the area work with doctors and professors at KU, so it all coincides, which is really nice.
There is always something to do in an around the city. Lots of places to shop off Mass street and people are all pretty friendly to eachother.
There are multiple options and varieties off campus and there are a ton of places that deliver.
There are more stuck-up guys than not, although there are some guys who are very friendly. Many smart guys here.
Great place to live, but I am looking to experience other parts of the country as well.
No matter how many times I try, I am unable to receive any financial aid, even though I need it.

As as student with multiple dietary restrictions, it is nearly impossible to find a decent variety of food that I can eat. When there are meals for students with dietary needs, it's usually about three different meals total for the whole year. It is very hard to find things that I can eat.
Lots of different options for people who need special dietary needs or are looking for something different. Many late night options and many places have discounts for students.
The department of student housing is not well run, there is a never-ending process to get everything correct and those in charge abuse their power more often than not.
House parties and bars, like any college. I'm not a big part of that kind of life.
Lots of different people from many different backgrounds.
Basketball brings the entire campus together.
It depends on the internship you are awarded.
Super easy to get in, and not hard to stay in.
Could be a lot better about lawn work.
Lots of variety. Easy and flexible scheduling
Everything is customized for you. You feel like you have your own learning plan
No warning when new ones are posted
Ku does very well maintaining their facilities
I've never lived off campus but my friends have
You get away with a lot
You fit in where you fit in
I think awareness would make the sexual assault decline
Everything you need is on mass street
I love ku classes. I have a bond with my teachers and ask them questions and go see them in their office for further questions
I just eat at home most of the time
Campus strictness is the perfect middle, where it's not super strict where you don't wanna be there but you also know & feel that everyone cares for you! KU has an AMAZING atmosphere
KU is definitely more of a bar scene then house parties! On the weekend & even on Wednesday's most students are either at the bars or the frats!
The local restaurants in downtown Lawrence are awesome!!!

I am all for Greek life, especially at my school!! I didn't go greek my freshman year & I still very much enjoyed their parties & went to a few events! Going into my sophomore year I am definitely going to join! Although greek life is kind of big at my school, if you're not apart of it, you won't feel left out! Half of my friend group is greek & the other half is non greek! I recommend trying it out & if it's not for you, it's biggie!
Although I haven't been in every building on campus as I was only a freshman this past school year, the quality of our school is very top notch & up to date, at least in my eyes!
Like every town, there will be some sort of sexual assault but I honestly feel very safe on my campus!
We again, literally have everything from singles, doubles, 2 & 4 person suits, to on-campus apartments! Everyone is sure to find their perfect fit!
There are many different races & ethnicities on campus but they are obviously still he minority, but being apart of the minority I don't feel as though I am treated any different!

I personally only got $600 my freshman year so not much but if you have good grades & act/say you will get some sort of scholarship! KU is a pretty pricey school for out of state students but it's well worth it!

There is literally something for everyone, there are the cheap, not so nice apparments that students usually opt for that are in close proximity to the football stadium and then there are the average priced nicer appartments that are a good 5-10 minute walk from campus & most of the bars and then there are the more pricey fully furnished apartments that are alittle farther (walking wise) to campus, so there is honestly something for everyone!
I honestly love the town of Lawrence, so much so that I want to retire there later in the future!!!

KU basketball - what else can I say? The football team hasn't been doing great lately but games are still fun to go to. Sporting events bring the student body together and are the only time you are surrounded by a hundred other students with such enthusiasm. I don't care about sports but at KU it's hard to ignore how fun the games are as a social event.

It's pretty average. Nothing really stands out. The rec is good, but I don't go there because it's always so packed. The machines are always taken. The libraries are a hugely popular study spot, but I prefer the computer labs because they're less populated and free. Engineering students have free unlimited printing, which is amazing.

Watkins is great. It's SO much better than LMH (Lawrence Memorial Hospital) and is open almost every day. The staff is so friendly. Sometimes appointments are hard to get, it just depends on the time of year and the day of the week. The walk-in clinic also varies with waiting time. The pharmacy is very convenient and the staff is very helpful.

There's so much to choose from. Lots of places deliver and most places are open late. You can use your KU card to pay for most food in town. There are lots of local places that are often overlooked but just as good as the chain restaurants. Lawrence is very vegetarian-friendly!

I love KU. I probably wouldn't change my decision to come here if I could go back in time. However, I do sometimes wish I had gone to a 2-year school first and transferred here. The intro-level courses are definitely weed-out classes here. Once you get past the weed-outs it's not too bad, but it's very easy for your GPA to suffer if you're not careful.

Guys are either really fratty, really nerdy, or totally hipster. There's not much else. Most people are in greek life and act stuck-up and spoiled rich. The people who aren't in greek life are great. Most people are shy but friendly if you approach them first.
KU is very diverse, but everyone pretty much sticks to what they know. There aren't really diverse friendships between students on campus. People don't seem to intermix here.

The dorms are pretty run-down and old. Elevators are constantly broken and lobbies are constantly vandalized and trashed. But I don't really know what else you would expect from a bunch of college freshmen. It's easy to find a place to live. The buses are always going between the dorms and classes, so it's very easy to get around. Everything is also within walking distance, but there are lots of hills.
No matter what day of the week it is, there's always a party in Lawrence. There are many places close to campus, and other places that aren't too close or too far.

In the evenings and nights it's hard to find stuff to eat on campus. The dining halls have okay food, but the Underground or the Union are better, when they're open. Everything is pretty expensive because it's convenient. Lawrence is very vegetarian-friendly.

Greek life is so huge at KU. If you're not involved, it's hard to make friends or find decent parties to go to. Greeks are snobby and think they're better than you. I took an economics class and I was one of 2 non-Greeks in the entire class. Everyone in the class already knew each other and nobody was willing to talk to me, even for our required group projects in the class. They don't even tell you how to join until after it's too late.

There are so many places to choose from, in so many different neighborhoods. Between apartments, townhomes, houses, and other options, there is something for everyone. It's not hard at all to find an affordable place to live with the amenities you want, and a location that works for you!
The dorms are prices way to high for the quality and space of the dorms.

They guys at my school are majority attractive and interesting. The dress like another American male would. The social life usually include partying. They typical girls wear leggings, Sharks t-shirt, and Sperry's shoes.They are usually interested in either guys, drama, or partying. There seems to be good and bad sides to each relationship.

The campus life at KU is awesome. Everyone has an equal opportunity to experience, share, and get involved in it. The social scene is always steadily expanding. There is a place for everyone to engage in deep discussions or light chit chat.
Life on on campus is always lively. You can tell that students and staff want to be there more than anywhere else. They come and stay which means that they are enjoying life at KU.

The campus is well suited for an excellent college lifestyle experience. There is plenty of help to guide you and well light seating areas. What makes KU unique is its warm social atmosphere. Anyone can find a healthy outlet to express themselves whether its a club, a sport, a church, or spending time talking with friends.
The off-campus housing selection is varied, and the school is accommodating with regards to helping others find off-campus housing.
There is a significant emphasis on taking sexual assaults seriously, and taking preventive measures against sexual assault.
"Diversity" a vague term, encompassing any number of possible attributes among a population. Nevertheless, it would be fair to say that the school has at least a moderate level of "diversity."

Biased in my evaluation, but I would say almost everyone here is obsessed with "Greek life". Everyone is gathered in cliques centralized around Greek life, and if you didn't come to college with previous social acquaintances, especially those involved with Greek life, you might as well be a social pariah for all these snobs care.
Granted, I'm biased in my evaluation, but I'm a first-generation student coming from a low socioeconomic background, and the school has yet to provide adequate aid so that I can continue to attend.
Overall, the department and program has a positive reputation. I have yet to really get involved in the program, so I cannot really speak to what it's like at this point in time.

Liberal arts courses are supposed to have a reputation for highly respected professors. This is primarily because many philosophers within these departments emphasize critical thinking, logical argument, and thorough evaluation and/or revision of written text. I cannot speak for the science or math professors, as I have taken very few science and math courses at this point in time.

My counselor guides me through the process of getting my major requirements in tack, but still its a little confusing on what classes to take and what counts, what doesn't. I can't do it on my own i have to have help from a counselor.
Everyone is accepted at this college. Everyone helped everyone out if their lost. The people in the helps rooms are very helpful to anyone.
When I go on campus I rarely see friends getting together. Everyone just goes to class and then goes home or goes to the library to study. No one has time to see friends during the school week.

It was a hassle but I got my financial aid. It's through the computer and I don't like that because you have to check your email a lot to see if you got the financial aid email and you have to accept it and then go on the university website to read and make sure I actually got it. It's very confusing, but I got what I needed.
The local atmosphere is alright. I'm not crazy about the area, and the town to me is run-down and shabby.
Safety on campus is fairly average, I don't feel particularly unsafe, mainly only at night.

The guys that seem to be around campus are pretty nice. Many of the students are finding themselves and trying to figure out where they are going in their careers and lives. I prefer when a guy has an idea of where he is headed.
My major is unique. I am in the PharmD program and the workload is tough, but there are many internship and job opportunities.
The academics are fine, probably comparable to other colleges. The registration process, or any administrative task in general is a nightmare.
An advantage to off-campus housing is that there is a bus that students can take to get to and from campus for free.
KU has a very diverse campus with many organizations and clubs that encourage diversity.
tons of new places to eat !
i feel safe on campus
its college student living, its average
I love the professors who teach art history courses and the different classes given are extremely interesting
I love the professors who teach art history courses and the different classes given are extremely interesting
the clubs to join at Ku are overwhelming there are so many, it's great !
acceptance among many different groups of people is a big part of life at KU. lawrence is a very accepting, loving city
It's not eaasy getting money from people, but If you put in the effort, many times you'll get rewarded

I personally would never join a greek, and i've witnessed first hand how cruel and ignorant frat boys and sorority girls can be. on the other hand i have a lot of friends in greek life, and they're some of the best friends ive ever had

I feel that KU is in a city of itself, people who do not attend KU said that when the breaks come around, that the city is quite and nothing is happening. In Lawrence it is amazing when there are a lot of people roaming throughout the city. Shopping is alright a person has a better chance of going to the Oak Park Mall and finding something good then shopping in lawrence. Other then the shopping Lawrence, KS you can always find something to do.

Living on campus is definitely great, for me all I had to do was catch a bus to class or even walk depending on the weather. I lived close to campus which was great but it wasnt close to society. I mean I lived in a all girls dorm and yes it was difficult but it wasn't as bad as it could've been, I met a lot of girls from everywhere. I made friends quite easily. I also... would put out there that even though my residence hall wasnt bad I would never recommend to live, it was alright and it was cheap but it wouldn't have been my first choice

I genuinely thought at first that I would be scared and not able to handle going away from home and being a big kid. After I got comfortable the University was one of the best decisions that I could've made. I loved meeting all these new people that I would've never met otherwise. It was definitely an experience, but I am glad that even though i had some bad experiences my good experiences outweighed them. I cannot wait until August to continue my experiences

I feel that the dining hall was great on certain days, because it was some days that the food was not good and I would just not eat. On other days it would be great. The good thing about your KU card was you could use it as a credit card, for example Dominos would take your Cuisine Cash as actual money, which is great for us broke college students. Buffalo Wild Wings used your Beak'em Bucks if you didnt want to carry cash around. I'm just waiting on chipotle to get on that card usage

The reason I believe that off-campus dining was okay, is because it was the same thing over and over. Even though they had a GREAT discounts for KU students, I just feel like it took a lot of money to eat when we could've just have eaten in the room and saved money.

The guys and girls.... Well it is a lot of people from every where, some of them are well off and dress better with nicer cars interested in rush week or getting phenomenal grades. Looking like models on campus while on the other hand there are the people like me, who are not the wealthiest yet not the poorest. I feel like we were the ones who were relaxed yet trying to make good grades because we know this isn't the cheapest things for our parents, we may not have looked phenomenal everyday but atleast we were in class.

The diversity is... Something I was definitely not used to. I went to a predominately black high school and to be the one of the only African American person in a class was weird. It was also a fun time, I gained lots of other friends from this. I learned a lot about cultures. As stated before it is what you make it.

I felt that the University of Kansas was a great social scene as well as academic.

They definitely know how to have a good time but when it comes down to academic they make sure you have all the help you needed, I wish I would've used them more

I had so much fun this first year. The library, I can't believe I am saying this was one of the most interesting places. I think that it actually helped me stay focused. I feel that the weekends are always the best because it is always something to do. Traditions night made me really feel like a Jayhawk, I learned a lot as well as had fun. I definitely think that student life depends on the person, you have to emerge yourself into it or it wont be fun at all.

There are many options around campus should you choose to live there. It's great to have your own place plus, more than half the time it would be cheaper than living on campus. The only real con would be having to accommodate time for getting to class.

There are many things to do on campus. SUA hosts many events to help give out information about clubs, sports, frats and sororities. Even if you are not a big social person there are plenty of spots around campus to just hang out with a friend and enjoy the day with. There should not be a reason to not find something to do other than you do not want to do anything.
Basketball is really big here, even though you might not be a big sports fan, just tuning into the game with a couple of buddies can really give you a sense of what is like to be a jay-hawk.
Living on campus is a great way to transition into the college life as you have plenty of people on the same boat as you as well as RA's that know how to help you should you need it.
A lot of people date in college. Every where I go, I see a couple holding hands.
This last semester was pretty rough, academically speaking. College life is pretty fun because you meet a lot of new people and it's awesome.
I mostly stay on campus but I probably cant answer these question well. But I know that you get a discount if you are a KU student at Dominos and Glory Days.
I don't mean to stereotype but there are a lot of people from South America and China that go to KU. But that's great. It's awesome to see and meet new people.
Of course, they are strict on the obvious stuff, such as underage drinking and quiet hours. Other than that, they are pretty chill.

The food is actually pretty good. For the scholarship hall, they cook their own food but for the dorms, they have a dine-in cafe. , which has a variety of food, form Mexican to Chinese to salads. It's pretty good too.
Everybody knows that KU has one of the best basketball programs. So the empasis on basketball is very much important.

Actually, it all depends where you stay. From what I heard, I know some of the dorms are in pretty bad shape. But if you stay in the scholarship halls, like Krebhiel, they are not that bad. Even though they are called scholarship halls, they are still high. I normally take the buses to classes because it would be a really long walk.

Every once in a while, you hear about the "stranger-danger" on campus or a shooting at a bar. But those are expected to happen because there are some nuts in this world. But about 80% of the time, KU is a very nice place to lived.
I wish more places delivered!!!! FOR STUDYING TIME
I like everything! Popular study areas are the libraries!
There is a lot of opportunity in the psychology department to excel.
Some thing were okay in my dining hall but mainly I did not enjoy it
Things happen that we all wish wouldn't but overall I felt safe but they may also be because nothing has happened to me to believe otherwise.
I had a good experience in my dorm.
They are helpful but it can be difficult at times. I wish there was more money available to students at times because the cost of schooling is outrageous.
Some things are strict but I would not consider it a strict place to be. You are in control of yourself.
I love lawrence on mass street

I rushed my freshmen year and did not join a house. If you are at a bar everyone will ask you what house you are in and when you say you are not in one they give you a look like, oh well ok.... wish that would change a little.
Looks are good, interests are very diverse, dressing styles are casual but nice as well, and social life is always hopping. There are people in relationships and some not just depends on the person.
It bisically has to do with having a good GPA of at least 3.0 and doing good in the courses that are related to your major
It involves a lot of discipline and hard work to succeed since the courses are very challenging and hectic
It pretty much does not take the average KU student into consideration like the on campus dining halls do
The availability of modern technology in the classroom helps to make learning easier and more fun. Lecturers are able to impact knowledge easily because of the level of technology at the school

Involves a lot of calculations and there is no room for error which makes it ally tough on students. Workload is always a lot because there re always assignments given and research work to be done. Internships and job opportunities are available for students and it is an easy way to gain experience and knowledge in one's field of study

living on campus is always a great experience because students get a variety of dorms to live in with different prices and amenities. Also students get the chance to interact with people from all walks of live and make friends that last a life time. Social atmosphere is always fun .There are always parties or events going on on campus and it is easy for students to attend these events because of the availability of transportation on campus.
A variety of meals are always available to students throughout the week in different dining halls which makes it easy for students to get access to food.
For international students,Scholarship opportunities are limited which makes it difficult for most international students to get enough aid financially
At the University of Kansas , people accept you for who you are and respect one's views and ideas irrespective of who one is and where the person comes from.
If you are not white you experience is limited
We do get some discounts but not many.
Everyone is pretty much on the same page about religion.
Everyone kind of dresses the same but it looks good.
Drugs are not abundant but available if u seek it.
If you like the full effect of each season, you're in good hands.
Good people, just don't be stupid and you're fine.
Lawrence is known to have great food and there are so many places that everyone can find somewhere they like.
You shouldn't go anywhere alone at night obviously but if you do, it is no big deal because you should be okay.
KU parking is not good at all, there is always so much construction.
We do a lot of community service and things for the campus but also know how to have fun.
One of the best decisions I have ever made, I went Greek and I think everyone should.
The campus is beautiful but there aren't many green spaces to hang out.
Definitely KU basketball, there's nothing like it.
I love it so much, and it will be really rewarding.
Getting into the nursing program is hard - KU has one of the best in the country.
School with one of the highest drop out rates because it is pretty difficult, freshman year is definitely full of weed out classes.
It stinks that the nursing school is not in Lawrence so being a pre-nursing major means not doing anything nursing related at all.
A very social school with a prominent Greek life, go Greek.
Not diverse at all. All white people.
A bus is a bus
Sports are huge here. Too bad I don't care about them.
My major is pre med. It exist and doesn't exist at the same time.
There a good teachers and terrible teachers. Teach yourself everything and teach others.
Mass street is awesome and huge.
A computer is absolutely necessary. Almost everything is online.
I have been to an off campus apt or house
It's awesome. I did not want to leave for the summer.
People do drugs and alcohol. I don't feel any peer pressure to do anything. I could care less. I'm not sure of what policy the school has with drugs.
I'm still a little new to campus, but everyone is very inviting and supportive.
Downtown is the best place to go for eating out. Since it's right next to campus, it's convenient, but sometimes things can get pricey.
There are lots of different people on campus. People vary by age, race, orientation--it's great to see a well-balanced community instead of everyone conforming to each other.
I don't like partying late at night because it can get a little too loud for me. It's fun watching people have a good time downtown, though.

Snow happens a lot during the winters here. Campus is hardly closed unless the weather is extreme, which is rare. I don't like driving or being in the snow, so I wish they would consider closing more.
Lots of choices to eat--so many that it's hard to choose some days. A little pricey here and there but it's worth it.
Wi-fi is pretty reliable on campus. Paying for printing is a pain, since not all of us have to print out loads of paper. I wish it were free.
I'm a born and raised Lawrencian and I don't think anything could change my mind about living here. KU's campus makes it even better--it's so pretty.
Sexual orientations are widely accepted on campus. There are many resources and social events to participate in.
The free bus rides to campus are great. It saves money and helps the environment.
There is a lot of school spirit on campus. We have a lot of reasons to be proud of our campus, and we show it.
At my sister's graduation, there was a lot of wine, beer, and champagne drinking. Bottles and corks were everywhere.
I don't hear much about violence, although it does happen at parties.
It is a great program, they are opening the new business school in like 2 or 3 more years.
If you're looking for an A, the workload can get pretty heavy, but if you like to settle for C's then you'll get by with minimal effort.
Speed is great everywhere in computer labs except in dorms, it can get pretty slow.
Campus life is alright, just make sure to make friends in your lobby, that will lead to even more friends!
Rec center is pretty cool, better than all the gyms around and libraries are pretty relaxing.
If you live in the dorms, the bus will literally take you to classes, and have access to other buses that will take you other places such as walmart.
It would be much better if the Greek Fraternities would actually allow non-greek guys to attend their parties.
You can find most of places on mass street, and there is often coupons for some places. After 10pm, you'll probably have to settle for a chain restaurant.
McCollum is an okay place, there is the most people and I feel like you can get away with a lot as long as you don't create too much attention to yourself.
All you need is a fake id, to have the most fun here, if not just wait for random house parties.
It is not too strict, anyone can visit you as long as they provide their state id
Great during summer and fall, but during spring and winter it can get pretty cold.
It's a great school, however as an Hispanic student sometimes I feel left out as majority of students are Caucasian.
I wouldn't have chosen any other school.
Our school revolves around athletics. The players are like celebrities. They facilities are great even if you aren't an athlete.
There are so many things to do. Shopping on Mass, or going to a baseball game, or out to eat. You could never be bored.
I think the tradition at KU sets us apart. It's so rich and no other school is like it.
Part of the reason I chose KU was because of the setup of the school, and how beautiful every part of it is.
There are a lot of computer labs. The internet is slow when a lot of people are working.
The nightlife is awesome. It just gets old after a while.
There is so much variety that has reasonable pricing for college students.
There is a lot of variety which offers a lot to fulfill a living situation.
The busses come every so often, and because it isn't a huge town they can go all over.
It's a great place to meet new people. The janitors did a very good job of keeping it clean.
The diversity is great! Everywhere I look it's diverse.
I didn't have to deal with very much, but I know they care about our safety.
I want to be a nurse and wish I could stay at the main university all four years. I have to have great grades to get into the nursing school and it is very competitive.
They have a variety of classes to take.
There were hardly ever spots, and ticketing was a little to expensive for a broke college student.
There is lots of variety, it just gets old fast.
It also is the students' responsibility to leave with a friend so things don't happen to them because if the police can't be there then a least a friend can try and help.

Lots of computers aroud. Mainly in the library, but you can get to a computer if you really need one for hard work within 10 minutes if you're on campus. The first two weeks back from summer or a major break, can stress the network, because everyone is trying to log on at the same time.
This is a large public school, you can study almost anything you want.
As an engineer, a lot is expected. The engineering career center seems great, I haven't used them to their full potential.
Lawrence has a lot of public transit, and if you're too lazy to walk to class, wake up a bit earlier and catch the bus. There are plenty of stops, and they make a round about every 15 min.
Very college town. Has it's own character. Hard to not like.
NE Kansas is known for crazy weather. One day it'll be 19 degrees and snowing, next day 60 and sunny. Gets annoying often, but better than constant snow and cold, or rain, or blistering heat and sun.
It's college, cute girls, handsome males, and anything in between. Look hard enough play your cards right you'll get lucky.

Lawrence is full of good food. Especially if you're vegan/vegeterian/pescetarian. I joke that I have to search for the "meat menu" sometimes because it seems catered to vegeterians. (Careful, on campus is hit and miss on this category) Price ranges are all over the place, to satisfy what your wallet needs. Lots of places have delivery, and if you're feeling extremely lazy/rich, there is a "food taxi" you can pay for.

Night life is what you make of it. If you're a male who's not in greek life, there goes a huge party source, you're not going to get in really unless you know guys from there. Females basically have free reign, they get into bars easier. Honestly, the harder you try to party the more you'll be rewarded, don't let your grades slack. Sometimes I get sick of it.

The cost is just about right, selecting your housing is extremely easy once you get the portal to work (KU seems to love Firefox - if you're having trouble, cycle through browsers, starting with Firefox).
Mass Street has the most diverse offerings for dining. Cost is always good, and the food is to die for! I always recommend The Burger Stand or Zen Zero for food options.

I come from a barely middle class family with two siblings and two working parents and only received one scholarship (which I lost) for $5,000 a year based on my ACT score of 32. However, the GPA requirement is 3.4, and I earned a 3.16, and I feel that I was punished for taking mostly honors classes and receiving slightly lower grades than I would have with regular classes.

Knew a few kids who got kicked out for drug possession. I don't do drugs but it isn't glamorous by any means, and is pretty much consistent with the drug usage and visibility there was at my high school.
Always windy on the hill.

Since it's in Kansas, there's still less diversity than the coasts. However, KU is great about making international students blend in and feel at home, and everyone is generally accepting of everyone else's religious and political backgrounds, as well as financial means.
Daisy Hill is the main location for dorms, and the social life is great up there. There's always someone to go to when you're bored or need someone to talk to, so it's really a close knit atmosphere.
Always something to do/a bar to go to during the year. And the university provides SafeBus/SafeRide to get students around safely.
Their job counseling is great and the advisors rock.
It's dorm food, so it's not spectacular and sometimes it seems repetitive but for the first semester and a half it's great.

It's KU basketball season year-round. From recruitment to pre-season Late Night In the Phog to game days and March Madness, KU has such a rich history with the program that it's hard not to get sucked into it.
Depends how far you are from campus and the tenants that came before you.

The Honors Program is one of the most selective and oldest programs for honors in the nation, and they are constantly willing to help their students. I am confident in my professors' abilities to assist me or direct me where I can receive assistance, and classes are no joke but are incredibly rewarding when hard work is put in.
Not entirely sure on the response for this, but a few campus alerts have been sent out regarding sexual assault which is a little unsettling.

Buses do a fantastic job of getting around campus, and Lawrence transit buses are free to students with proof of enrollment (i.e. student ID card). The drivers are usually personable and keep the buses clean, and restrict open containers to maintain this clean environment. Bus routes are clearly displayed and usually run on time, barring severe weather.

Greek life is pretty big but almost anyone can be accepted into any house. Essentially Greek girls wear really bummy clothes and Greek guys always wear khakis and some kind of button-down. I personally have never held an interest in Greek life, and KU didn't do a convincing job of making it look glamorous. But apparently the parties are good.
The athletics at the school is pretty great and the quality is top notch. I've heard great things about the rec center and the intramural teams. The school spirit is high and very proud.

There have been a lot of sexual assaults and the like on campus and yes they have emailed and sent out information on it but as far as catching them not so much as least to my knowledge. Not only that I don't really feel comfortable walking by myself later in the evening because a lot of these occurences happen later in the night and I've been called incredibly derogatory slurs while walking alone and am sometimes afraid of people acting out of that because no-one is around. Other than that I do see police often patrolling during the day and the number of emergency boxes around campus is a good amount.

The number of off-campus dining places is pretty decent and accessible. There's usually enough offers floating around that getting a nice size meal for lunch or dinner so it isn't hard to find something that's nice to eat. I haven't been to many places off campus but the two that I have been to were excellent. Ramen Bowls is by far the best place I've been to that serves ramen and the staff is great not to mention they are fast with the to-go orders. Don Don is another place I've been to and it's a great price for such a big bowl. Also if Asian isn't your thing they have tons of other places to order from take out or not.

The labs/computer spaces available are limited depending on the time of day and the time in the semester. Not only that when I've been in the library when my computer is down it's the computers are usually filled up or a good chunk won't turn on and it leaves few spots. As far as wifi goes, when you are on campus the wifi is pretty decent but in the dorms it's horrible a times. The speed is absolutely horrible especially for the price I'm paying to live in the dorms it's ridiculous.

There's generally a bus for every part of Lawrence whether your going downtown or needing to head to Walmart but outside of Lawrence there isn't a whole of transportation options. Not only that the schedule is slightly hard to read for someone that has never had to take the public bus before.
Sometimes you have to park far away because everyone else is already there even if you are an hour early for your class.
The campus police is mostly older men so sometimes I don't feel as safe as I could feel.
Mostly everyone at the school is very friendly and most will just come up and introduce themselves.
My campus strictness is mostly lenient about most things but if it is bothering or harming others it will be stopped by campus police.
Drugs can be found everywhere so there is no need to talk about it.
i never see campus security at night
They ignore the underage drinking and crack down on stupid stuff like parking
not many cute guys and way more guys then girls in greek life
not very helpful with giving scholarships or any aid
a lot of professors are foreign making it hard to understand material
there is nothing like allen field house
i dont live on campus
very helpful and on time
Some of the teachers are foreign and very hard to understand.
I live in apartments that are not affiliated with the school.
its very cold and windy in the winter
Competitive admission makes you work hard and not slack off
I like school a lot
I live in an awful, unsafe apartment complex and it is outrageously priced
Lots of things to try if you are willing to go out on a limb
Lots of things to do
I don't use the labs a lot but the wifi is everywhere, just occasionally slow
The buses are free and usually on time if they are the on-campus routes. If it is off campus, prepare to be early and wait awhile and never know which one
Walking around outside is what we do, if you aren't prepared, you are going to be exposed to the weather. If you just check the forecast, there is no issues, other than when it is blistering cold
I have to show up early just to make sure I find a spot and get to class on time
They are pretty stand-offish and unfriendly.
There are a lot of wonderful options near campus!
Greek life is very active, but doesn't dominate the social scene. The Greek houses are big and gorgeous! It was not the right fit for me, however I have friends who loved their experience.
I'm from Dallas, TX, so the winter season feel especially harsh. The Spring and Autumn season are gorgeous on campus! Summers are hot.

Shuttle buses come around frequently. I have a car when needed, but it's not necessary for getting around campus. I usually walk to all my classes. The only time when it becomes difficult is when it's freezing outside!
I am in Greek Life so I am biased but I am extremely please with it here at KU.
Buses are very convenient and run through campus stopping at various locations. SafeBus is also very nice.
Lawrence is the most liberal town in Kansas and the majority of students are moderate or liberal I think.
Lawrence has fantastic restaurants on Mass street, something for everyone.
Athletics are huge at KU, the rec center is great but it gets pretty crowded, could be bigger.
Kansas City less than an hour away makes for great shopping and professional sports teams, not to mention nightlife. Most townies that live in Lawrence love the school.
Lots of options for whoever wants to live off campus. Some houses look pretty shabby, but most students don't care about that.
I don't have any concerns finding an internship in accounting.
I am very happy with the business school so far in my experience.
Drinking is apparent during the weekends but nobody cares if you don't partake.
Lots of diversity on campus.
The busses cannot get up the hill if the streets are iced.
Most living areas on campus are great to live in.
Don't smoke in the dorms.
If you're not at the hawk you're missing out.
Currently undecided but my advisors great!
Live in an apartment if you can.
Night busses and other options available so students can avoid driving under the influence.
Strict about parking - get a pass ASAP!
Tons of choices! Just ask around but pretty much anywhere is good.
If you go to KU, expect to cheer for KU
Wifi is terrible in the dorms.
Don't live off campus but they seem reasonably priced and they promote a lot on campus
Parking is bad I've heard. But I walk to campus and avoid the issue completely.
I live within walking distance of campus and don't do much driving.
Top law school. Top professors with real world work experience. Innocence Project. Rigorous academics.
Helpful, kind, open-minded, supportive, friendly, open
I found very cheap housing within a 1/2 mile of campus. Application process is easy with all apartments I've applied to. Very affordable with flexible options.

KU has a laid back feel to it. The atmosphere is academically rigorous but laid back enough that you feel comfortable approaching all professors and staff with any issue at all. Staff is extremely supportive with any issue brought to their attention, academic or otherwise.
Lawrence, KS is a small town with a big city feel. Food isn't the most diverse I've ever seen, but it isn't lacking by any means either. Barbecue food here is the best.
The staff at University of Kansas are kind, helpful and go above and beyond to assist students in securing funding/scholarships to cover the cost of tuition. Go Jayhawks!
Even though my soon to be off- campus housing is farther away than wanted to all the ammenities are amazing and the housing is perfect and well kept.
I'm always known with where a bus stop is and know that most of the buses i can ride are always accessible to me.
My housing is one of the best dorms you can stay in and is always well kept.
I think it's safe around here since i see campus police everywhere, and Watkins health center is right on campus.
The bus system not only goes from campus, but it also moves around town so it's easy to commute around Lawrence.
Some of the buildings here are old, but they try to fix some of the problems.
There are a lot of different types of people here on campus
Ku basketball is pretty much the main thing to talk about on campus.
I would say the the strictness on campus would be average.
There's a lot of local shops here in Lawrence on Mass street that are much different than what you would expect
Its a struggle with the competition to maintain a scholarship.
This is hands on training, and you get a good education.
The only difficult part of getting into computer engineering is math.
Academics are great and there are so many options of classes to take.
I don't think campus is super strict. there are probably some things they could be more strict on like alcohol and noise, but other than that I think the campus is good as is.

The safety is great.

I am so not impressed with the health center. I took my roommate to get tested for strep and the lady took the throat culture with out gloves after having hacked into her hands not even 5 minutes before. I only saw an RN when I got a shot. The worst thing is that they say they work with all insurances but that's a total lie. One of my worst experiences has been at the health center.
Lawrence is awesome and has so much more to offer than just the university. It's nice to be able to get out and explore town to take a break from studying.
I am super happy with my biology program. The only thing I would change is to have a set advisor for me specifically.
There are so many majors to choose from, it is crazy. I'm not really planning on taking an internship, but i'm liable to shadow at the local medical center.
Lawrence has so many options for food and Mass Street is barely a mile away from campus so it's a fairly nice walk... if you like hills.

We take a "course" online at the beginning of Freshman year or every year if you're Greek. Lots of people smoke on campus and there were some drug users in the dorms. The boys' side of the dorm smelled horribly of weed, but the girls' side of my floor didn't really do drugs to my knowledge.
It's campus housing. It was what I expected it to be. It might have been different in a different dorm, but I don't really know.
I'm not Greek, so I don't really know anything about Greek life.
The bus system at KU is pretty awesome. Sometimes the buses can be really crowded, but as long as you don't mind being squished for a few minutes they work great.

Okay parking sucks. On campus parking is outrageously expensive and there is only 1 lot for the lowest paying option. (which is the only one students can purchase). otherwise you're looking at parking in someone's driveway or pretty far away from campus. Supposedly they are going to be fixing the parking when they begin the master plan, but in the meantime i think parking is going to become even harder to find.

There are several computer labs on campus, but they can get fairly crowded, especially during lunch. The wireless on campus is great and every building on campus is covered by the Jayhawk network. My only real complaint would be the price of printing. I think it's $0.40 per page, which isn't terrible, but when you need to print a 10 page paper on campus you're spending 4 bucks.
It could be 70 degrees one day, and then there would be snow on the ground the next day. The weather is insane.
Don't expect a lot apart from loans through your parents.
There are people of all types here. You can find just about one of everyone.
There are plenty of majors to choose from; a great amount of those in engineering.
From what I've seen, everyone here really wants to help you out and see to it that you get a good education and career.
You can't go to this school without being a fan. You will hear everything about everything that has to do with the sports.
I've never had any real issues or concerns over this topic. I don't live on campus, therefore I'm not highly familiar with the system.
The bus routes are great and go by every lecture building on campus. You do, however have to buy a permit to park in the spot where the buses pick up mass groups.
They pick me up at my dorm and take me to all of my classes.
Technology is wonderful. I have my own computer, but I print it to the main printer in the dorm.
I want to become a doctor and do research to help solve the massive problem of diabetes in the United States.
I have a lot of work, but I feel that I can achieve the goals that I have set for myself.
I spend most of my time studying, so I don't get that much time to enjoy the nightlife.
My father lost his job a few years ago, so it is really hard for my parents to help me pay for any of my college. I just wish that the university would look at the whole picture.
I find my way around campus no matter what the weather is on a particular day.
I don't know about drugs specifically, but alcohol is a major problem. Everywhere I look, students are drinking and partying.

I guess the academic experience has been alright so far. My grades have been good, and we are finally getting to the more interesting classes in my major. Dealing with the school itself, filling out forms, making phone calls, etc. has been terrible and it makes the school very unappealing.

When we had a bunch of snow this year, the lack of plowing was comical around campus. My group of friends and I would make a footprint trail on West Campus and stay in the same path each day. If the area was taken care of, it was still a sheet of ice.
I have yet to be to an athletic event. Most students take part in some sort of involvement with athletics. Either participating or simply going to the games.

I use public transportation and it has been a wonderful experience. The campus buses are great as well. Finding a bus stop that the particular buses stop at is a little confusing, but overall it is okay.
Printing is a disaster at this school, and there is little hope of finding an open computer.
I do not live on campus, but what I've seen of the amenities, I believe the dorms are just typical dorms. All the buildings on campus should really be updated though.

It was an awful process dealing with the financial aid office. I feel like a one-phone-call issue ends up being about twelve phone calls. If as a student, you are American, your parents have jobs, or you have a job... you won't receive many scholarships. And no one in the financial aid office could tell me deadlines, or even get scholarship checks processed in a timely manner.
