The management at many of the apartment complexes around aren't very helpful, so it is important to fond which ones those are, and make decisions based on that. I always tell people to ask around before signing a lease.

Public transportation is great around the University of Kansas. There are about 18 bus routes that run all day to and from campus, as well as around Lawrence. At night, when the buses are not running, there is SafeRide, a taxi-like service that doesn't charge, and is available to all KU students with a valid ID.

KU is accepting and comprises of all kinds of diversity. Most ethnic/racial diversity does come from international students. Sexual orientation is expressed through various clubs. Political beliefs usually are expressed around the year of voting but students have strong political beliefs for student senate.
I'm not in greek life but it doesn't dominate at KU.

The satisfaction of on campus housing will depend where you choose to live because costs will vary for each housing option. One of our oldest dorms will be knocked down with a parking garage for students to put in its place and 2 new dorms will be added on campus. I chose a more pricey option for my dorm and I was satisfied. All my needs were met. On site laundry, study room, computer lab, common room, suite with bathroom, small living room area etc.

I received grants and 2 loans enough to cover my tuition with leftover money each semester which I would use for rent and utilities for that semester. The amount of money that you get reimbursed will depend on the cost of tuition which will depend on what field you are studying and how much it costs per credit hour for that major. I handled all my financial aid on my own. You will need to obtain forms for loans or specific grants that aren't disbursed automatically through your FAFSA. Always apply for your FAFSA early each year as soon as you receive your tax information. First come, first serve.
You'll find people from all over the country (Texas, California, Illinois, Minnesota etc.) Stereotypes (besides Greek life) is rarely noticeable (usually within individual clubs)
It is kansas really haha.
Its a little far away from the main part of campus but its a great community over all.
Prestigious programs, undergrad research from day one, and actual professors teaching the classes.
Prestigious programs, undergrad research, and actual professors teaching the classes.
Tons of activity every night, Lawrence is always a good time.
Very easy to fill out the forms, and our office is always available to help.
Campus is only a few blocks away from downtown Lawrence, and there are many different types of restaurants on Mass St to choose from.

I have very little experience with public transportation in other areas, but I have found the bus system at the University of Kansas to be very useful. The busses are free with a student ID and they will take you close to almost anywhere you want to go. The only real issues I have with the system is the fact that there are three different busses that serve different parts of the campus. The routes are a bit awkward to coordinate and get to where you want to go on campus efficiently.

The people at the University of Kansas are incredibly diverse. There are many different foreign students from many different places. The dominant number of students are from eastern Kansas, but there is a fair amount of students from other places. There is a good population from California and Chicago as well. The general culture is strongly based in metropolitan attitudes and dress, but it is not terribly hard to find someone from any background, including 'rednecks'. The number of girls vs. boys is fairly evenly split.

Naismith Hall just did an amazing renovation to the lobby. Cool new fireplace lounge, large fitness room looking out at pool, ping pong/pools tables and new study rooms. Great location. And the best part, I practically have a private bathroom! Best dorm on campus by far. Love it here.

It's Kansas; you never know what kind of weather you're going to get. One day it could be hot and humid and 95 degrees, while later in the week it could be 70 degrees and rainy. The summers are hot and humid, the winters are freezing, but the spring and fall make it worth it.
There are plenty of off-campus housing options. You can live as close or as far away from campus as you want because the school has a fantastic public transportation system

For the middle of Kansas, Lawrence has a pretty decent restaurant scene. Most of the places students want to go are on Massachusetts St (Mass), which is only a few blocks from campus. Of course, the town also has its fair share of fast food, too.
If you're into that scene, you're not going to run into any problems as long as you're in the privacy of your own home/apartment and you're not driving. Most people drink, though.

Nightlife here is great, if you're into shopping and cool places to eat dinner. However, if you are under 21 and all of your friends aren't, there isn't a single place that will let you in on the average night!
The computer labs are further off of the main path of campus, but not usually crowded because of this. Internet speed is average.
Rental houses are plentiful around KU, but quality is lower than low in some. Parking passes are expensive for off campus students, so houses in walking distance are key.
Campus is hard to navigate but other than that its fine.
This is a 'white bread' state and the university reflects that. There is some diversity, but not like at some larger universities.

They have a good science program here. At orientation, they did not however have someone from my department there for me as I was a transfer student and taking upper level courses. Still need a chem advisor.

The dorms in McCullom hall are relatively nice, but the bathrooms are disgusting. They need to be completely remodeled. The good things in McCullom are the floor lounges. They are a great socialization place.
Most of the dorms at KU are fantastic. McCollum is the oldest one, but it's being torn down in a few years and two new ones are being built.
We're pretty much awesome. Basketball rules KU, but we are still spirited about all varsity sports. Even in Football where we're not at all good, the games are still sold out almost everytime.
Drinking is very, very, very popular. Aside form that, everything else is hardly found. Marijuana is pretty popular and prescription drugs are seen around midterms and finals.

Local atmosphere is wonderful! Lawrence is really a special town that you can't find just anywhere. Everyone loves KU and has a spirit that you can feel. On campus there is plenty of KU love, and it's impossible to not see a Jayhawk or KU shirt everywhere you go

Off-campus dining is awesome! Mass St. is all you will hear about at KU, and for good reason. It's funky, fun, and has the perfect mix of quirky and familiar eateries and shops. From Chipotle to the Mad Greek, there is a place for everyone. You will never get bored exploring Lawrence!
The KU bus system is awesome and definitely comes in handy. There could certainly be more buses going to the dorms when classes get out, but overall the experience is a good and easy one.

Since I'm just starting my sophomore year I don't feel like I've encountered any specific or unique aspects of the major I've declared. My high school curriculum was very similar to the courses I'm currently taking (heavy on math and sciences).

Lots of food, some local spots that cater to the college crowd plus abundant availability of chain restaurants and cheap fast food. There is some ethnic and vegetarian variety, but I have mostly stuck to campus (Greek) dining halls and buying groceries.

Starting my sophomore year, I'm now looking at continuing to pursue my Biology major with the intention of going into internal medicine. I feel like an internship at a doctor's office would be very beneficial however at this point, I have little knowledge of how to go about finding an internship or who I would speak with. Hopefully once this year gets underway I will have more of an idea on how to approach an internship.

The dorms are pretty awful. There are I think two or three that have been renovated within the last 10 years. Basically, stay away from McCollum Hall. However, that does have the most people and the most lenient drinking and drugs policy. My whole floor smelled like weed. YAY....
A lot of people don't care about academics here. I'd say probably 20% of the student body has declared a major by their Junior year and actually cares about said major.
There's a fairly wide variety of majors to choose from. The biggest departments are Engineering and Pre-Med.

There is a lot of diversity here. Among the varying cultures, there are the average hairstyles and then there are brightly colored and shaved heads, there are attires that include pants and a t-shirt, pjs, suits, or some combination that someone created themself.

I have not had run-ins with police officers nor have I had problems with professors, and in fact, I have brought two of my children with me to campus for weeks at a time as I had my children during the semesters I was enrolled.

Not really a lot of places for under 21 crowd, but there are bars within walking distance, many downtown and you can use public transit to get to those, and there are parties fairly often if you are into partying.
The campus is within walking distance to almost any restaurant and types of food you would like.
KU is a great university for anyone. It is at the center of the city of Lawrence and has a great atmosphere.

After graduation, I plan to become a licensed architect. Currently, I am content with my five year master's architecture program. Although the work is very time consuming, I thoroughly enjoy the challenges presented to me by my professors in my assignments. So far I have learned how to think more abstractly, how to prioritize my work, as well as use my resources efficiently to maximize the quality of my work and the reasoning behind my work. However, I keep on hearing that employment for architects is currently low and I continue to pray that I am able to find a job that can help me fulfill my dreams of building homes in developing countries.

At the University of Kansas, I have found it hard to find scholarships. There are either very few scholarships given out by departments, or there are very few scholarships given out in general. I have found it tough to find scholarships through my university. However, Kansas offers a fair amount of grants to its students. It is more advantageous to apply for outside scholarships to fulfill my financial package.

The three most exciting things I am aware of at Kansas are our basketball team, the architecture program, which I am enrolled in, and the school's major student organization. First, during the winter season, us Jayhawks are especially excited about basketball because this sport was originally created at University of Kansas, as well as the Allen Fieldhouse is known to be one of the country's greatest home courts. The Kansas basketball team is known for their hard working players, defensive plays, and talent. Secondly, The five-year master's architecture program provides a unique and interesting opportunity to students in their final year of the study. Students may join Studio 804 where they work in a group to design and build an actual building. Finally, members of Student Union Activities hold events everyday whether they be social or informative. These events keep the student body involved and often allow students gain new learning experiences.

On weekends students can be spotted two miles east of campus. After a nice and leisurely walk down to Massachusetts Street, variety of cafes, restaurants, and bakeries hold the attention of all age groups. Not only are these shops convenient to get to, but they are affordable as well. Students can attain discounts through a shop's daily special or use the coupon booklet distributed on campus at the beginning of each semester. My favorite restaurant is Encore, a vietnamese and chinese cuisine that offers the best sweet and savory pad thai noodles on all of Mass. Street.

University of Kansas' campus is very active. During the day time on Jayhawk Boulevard, people will be seen walking around with friends, standing in front of booths sharing information, or be seen sitting on the Wescoe Hall steps relaxing and/or studying. The university's organizations play a very important role in students' social and academic lives. The organizations help create a better community for their members as well as the rest of the Kansas community through volunteering, community service, and hosting events. At times when students are wanting to take a break from daily stresses of life, potter lake serves a perfect spot for reflection. Students are often seen sunbathing, or playing with frisbees, on the hill beside Wescoe stairs. Jayhawkers enjoy and make use of the amenities provided by the university to the fullest extent to make the academic year memorable through student organizations and campus use.

Far Above Average – Almost EVERYONE attends games. The school always hands out awesome swag at each game and even offers discount tickets to the students for easy access. It also helps that the teams will occasionally win championships and helps school spirit.
There is always a party, even on Thursday nights. of course finals week is always full.
Busses run all the time day and night. They run through campus and through town.

You will find all sorts of people at KU from athletes to nerds. We have those who live and breathe sports or greek life, but also those who are more comfortable at a local coffee shop or library. It makes it much easier to find your crowd of people.

Ku's history is rich and colorful, and the students really feel a sense of belonging and purpose based on its atmosphere. The libraries are extremely convenient, offering resources and search engines, and are open nearly all hours of the night. Faculty, especially in the financial aid/ Bursar departments are very helpful and professional. Having a natural history museum, art museum, bowling alley, and many hang-outs on-campus is beneficial to the students, and add a sense of inclusion, as well as a fun way to kill time between classes.

Kansas is a relatively safe state, and, in fact, Lawrence recently had it's first homicide in 10 years (no homicide is good, but that's an amazing track record). Personally, I'm more concerned with petty theft and public drunkenness; even though neither are extremely apparent, they're the only crimes I've witnessed. Overall, I feel very safe on-campus.

Public transportation (supplied by the KU campus) was always readily avaliable, especially for those attending parties or enjoying the night life around town. Underrage drinking was apparent, but public drunkenness wasn't too big of an issue; although, I knew many people who would use fake IDs to get into clubs that serve alchohol. Being a "college town". there were many safe alternatives to partying at night, especially on Massachusets St.

I was never big in the drug scene, but alchohol was a very prominant force on and off campus. The RAs usually kept a good eye on the floors, and tried their best to do so, but alchohol and marijuana undoubtedly made it's way in. However, public drunkenness and drug use was always treated with professionalism, and information was readily made avaliable on how to responsibly enjoy alchohol.
I am in the pharmD program and have an internship. It is a great job to have while in school to learn about the field and practice and apply what I have learned in the classroom.
I am in the pharmD program, and I am looking forward to starting it. The technology that is utilized should be an asset.
They have a little over 200 majors to pick from and most have national recognition.
I feel safe on campus. Police are always driving threw and making rounds. If there are any crimes committed on or around campus alerts go out immediately and there are postings about it.
Its Kansas wait 10 minutes and the weather will change, but for the most part the weather isn't all bad.
It's a very laid back campus and the people are friendly.

I love the transportation system at the University of Kansas. There is a bus system that is put into the cost of going to the University so all you need to do is show your ID to the bus driver. Cars are not too necessary if you just plan to stay around the Lawrence area.
I recieve a full academic to school of engineering.
Gets a bit chilly during winter, but on the positive side, only lasting approximately 3 months.

The main Campus Dining site for Daisy Hill residents is Mrs. E's which I would describe as better than most give it credit for. Sure, some of the food can be tasteless and bland but it's all in what you pick. Once you find out what's good, it's a very pleasant eatery.

To be quite honest, I never really notice such thing at the University. I'm not really part of that crowd but every now and then I do see evidence of certain drug use. People in my dorm rooms were usually loud because of the alcohol they drink during the night. A party was held in my dorm in which there were obvious signs of alcohol use. The University forces you to take a course on alcohol safety which, in the end, pretty much speaks for itself.
My classes are usually big classes because they are major science classes. There seems to be a good amount of jobs doing lab research.
I think that my program is ok. My school doesnt offer the specific major I need so I am just sticking with what they have.
Everyone seems to be accepting of each other. Our campus has a lot of foreign exchange students though I do feel like the African American population is at a minority.
For two years I lived in the worst Dorms though it is nice that we have on campus apartments which is convenient. You cannot control the heat though and prices are getting to be expensive
Beautiful Midwestern ladies. Visited plenty of other colleges and would stack KU gals amongst the best any day.
Lawrence, Kansas is great. Your quintessential college town. It's hard to imagine a place I would rather be.
They're getting annoying when it comes to Greek life but pretty chill for the most part
Literally great. They have set me up to be very successful and given me all the tools I need.
Love the professors. Great facilities. Helpful counselors. Plenty of opportunities for study abroad.
It is Kansas so weather can change in five minutes
I haven't started quite yet, but I'm looking forward to it. I'll be beginning the PharmD program this fall.

I love the restaurants in Lawrence! There are many options. Some are fast food and some are high end places. Downtown is where many of the students go. Its probably one of the best things about living in Lawrence!

The diversity on campus is massive. You get to meet many different people from all over the world. Most of the time they are eager to meet new people, but sometimes you have to go out of your way to talk to them. They will often group with others from similar origin.
Lawrence is probably the most liberal area in Kansas.

There is a lot of social involvement and activities that go on. The only downside is that some of the newer dorms are expensive and small. The dining hall is close and the buses take students to campus.

Parking is pretty easy if you live in a dorm. Unfortunately, the parking on campus is limited. Especially if you're trying to study at the library at night. The parking permit prices are very expensive and just increased this year.

There is a large variety of student apartments close to campus. Some even have buses that will take students to campus from the apartment. The only issue is that some will be loud or very cheaply made (not sound proof)

The computer labs are all over campus and easy to access. Some are more full than others. Printing is very easy, all you have to do is swipe your ID and print. You also get $8 for printing at the beginning of every semester. Sometimes the computers are slow or won't work.
I was immediately qualified for acceptance into the buisness school based on my ACT and GPA.
Love the buisness program at KU. There are so many options available to those who want to go international.

The labs on campus are excellent and there are lots of them. Some schools, such as the Journalism school, even have their own labs. Printing is easy - send it to any building, then go to any printer in that building, swipe your ID, and print. Network is passable - it's too slow to be reliable for streaming. Wireless access on main campus is great.
Best to use a bike. Parking is terrible, and the main road through campus is shut down in the day
There are plenty of opportunities for internships at KU
By far the best international buisness program I have encountered

There are tons of off campus dining options. For starters, the University is five minutes from downtown, which has chain restaurants (like Buffalo Wild Wings) and lots of local restaurants (Mad Greek, Ingredient, Genovese, etc). There's a wide variety of food - from Greek to Indian to Mexican to healthy, and at lots of different price points. Many restaurants (especially local pizza shops) offer great student discounts/specials, and they accept Beak 'Em Bucks too. The University also provides a coupon book every semester with lots of coupons for local restaurants.

Typical Midwest weather. It's humid, which makes the summers hotter and the winters colder. Typically in the 90s and 100s in the summer, 70s and 80s in the fall/spring, and 30s-40s in the winter. But it's Kansas - the weather is really unpredictable.
Classes are hardly affected by weather. Unless it snows over a foot overnight, there will be class.

I'd say they're pretty nice. Very nice and large rec center which you can go to as a student for free, the unions are nice with (slightly expensive but) good food available. The libraries are very large and offer plenty of help as a student looking for a book or writing a paper or if you just need a place to study they're open all the time. I'm always seeing people jog around and chill on campus. We have the concrete beach of Wescoe and a really nice valley where you can lay out if you'd like.

As a transfer student, you might get a scholarship your first year in to KU. Other than that I found them to be lacking. You might receive one, but even then most people don't seem to think it covered very much of the tuition. I think most students rely on their parents to fund them out of potential debt.

Basketball is HUGE at KU. Allen Fieldhouse is one of the most amazing experiences I think you'll have as a KU student. The entire place simply hums with energy when you're in there. We have a team and coach the entire town loves and supports. Football is a bit lackluster, people still go, I'd say mostly to tailgate but we have hopes that someday it will become a viable spectator opportunity soon.
As a social work major I worked very hard and liked the program.
I don't really know much, but security is okay. Incidents have decreased, otherwise, I don't know much about the Health & Safety.
Parking sucks, you have to be careful where you park or you'll get a ticket!
I did not find much, so I relied on FAFSA more or less.
Very subjective, but everyone is different. There are pretty people and ugly people, but a very subjective question.
Some buildings aren't great, some are better than others.

The parking is so complicated and frustrating. There are different times that you can park in a lot, sometimes if there is an event you can't even park in the lot. On top of all that, you have to walk a long distance before you reach you destination on campus.
KU has a campus wide drug free rule in affect. That being said, smoking on campus is permitted as long as your a certain distance away from the academic buildings and sports facilities.

At KU, there is always a way to get around campus. Whether it be on the University buses, riding a bike/moped, or even just walking, I have had little trouble getting around campus. After 4pm, all parking on campus is open and students can park there for free. There are also multiple options for students who wish to purchase various parking permits through the KU parking department.
The athletics here at KU are a huge part of the campus life! the student involvement is incredible here and we have such a great student section at the games that I have been to it is a ton of fun!

it snow a lot here and classes never get cancelled. the one time classes got cancelled in years was this year and the dorms seem so far away from the classes. and they do a terrible job scrapping the sidewalks and pushing the snow out of the parking lots.

The night life if for students who are 21 and older. There are very few 18 and older clubs. But they do cost to get in. If you don't mind paying and enjoying yourself with a few friends out then that is the way to go. But it also depends on the bar scene you prefer. I have never been to a party on campus so I like to go out to the bars.
Scholarships are definitely not as easy to get as I had previously thought but if you work hard, you can probably land some. The financial aid process was VERY easy and straight forward for me.
Nightlife can be found anywhere in Lawrence. There are a places for 18 and older and there are many for the 21 and older crowd. It really can be a lot of fun and a great experience.

Greek life is everywhere on KU but it is also pretty easy to avoid if that's what you want. Personally, I'm not into the Greek life and it doesn't bother me but if you are interested, there are many ways you can become involved and there are many of them so you really do have a choice.

I haven't encounter any internships yet, but I'm sure I will within the next year or so. It'll be something in my field, coping with hospitals, clinics, etc. Internships are always something you can feel good about, knowing your doing something special for someone or something without pay is always a good thing to look back on.

The atmosphere is fairly nice. It's a college town, which consist of mostly students that attend the University of Kansas. They are plenty of activities that goes on during the day and night. The people are very friendly and easy going.

I love it! I've always liked helping others out no matter the situation, so I thought entering the health field would be a excellent fit for me. The school work is getting tougher, but thats just life and welearn to get better at what we do day by day.
I don't have a food/meal plan considering that I live off campus. I shop about once or twice every two weeks.

Right now I'm just talking pre-prerequisites towards my bachelors degree. In my department you must maintain a 2.5 gpa or higher in order to continue into the KU Med Center. Tips: Focus on what you're trying to pursue. Don't expect an easy way in for any type of degree or situation. Have a positive mind-set and continue working hard!
There is so much to offer in Lawrence. Mass St is where most of the shopping, bars and fun restaurant places are in Lawrence. Its the place to be on Thursday, Friday and Saturday night.
The drug scene in Lawrence, KS is moderate to high. However, on campus it's not really big, depends on who you hang out with and if they are people who do drugs.

I am a double major at KU in Spanish and Speech Language and Hearing. I do enjoy both of the programs, but I feel like the Spanish department leaves something to be desired. Half of the faculty I have loved. The others are hard to work with because they are so unorganized. I feel like this is a result of KU being a research school. All of the professors are busy with something else. It would also be nice to get out of the basement of Wescoe for Spanish classes. I really enjoy the opportunities available through the SPLH department. There is a clinic on campus for observations and practicum. They also have many undergraduate research opportunities. The intro to speech language pathology and intro to audiology classes allow interaction with clinicians and current graduate students.
Parking is awful. The permits are expensive and it's hard to find a spot close to campus. There isn't even anywhere to park for free around the health center. Remember change for the parking meters!

Campus does have wireless in all buildings, which is very helpful. However, it can be a bit slow occasionally. Overall though, the wireless is very nice. The dorms also just switched to wireless, which is a feature I wish they had had when I lived there. The computer labs in the larger libraries fill up during busy times such as over lunch and finals week, but the smaller computer labs spread throughout campus that are less popular are a good place to look! Ku does provide some money for printing on campus, but I always use it up too fast. I feel like printing should be free for all the money we spend to go to school there.

I gave the off campus housing a C because there are many options; however, it's difficult to find one that is in good condition, close to campus, and not ridiculously overpriced for college living. Decent apartments can be found, but usually just out of walking distance. I have also had bad experiences with management companies and have heard of other students having management that takes advantage of their college student tenants by withholding deposits or not taking care of facilities.
Good if you have money and over 21. but otherwise its only a drinking and eating scene, we're not to heavy on clubs
not part of the greek life seen, they tend to make asses of themselves
The university is in Kansas and Kansas weather is the most unpredictable weather out there. One minute it could be pouring out rain and the next the sun could be shining.
The school goes crazy during basketball seasons. We have one of the best basketball teams in the nation.

I give living on campus a solid B, because, unlike most people I've had a lot of problems, I'm very allergic to mold and dust. And a lot of the dorms are full of dust and mold and other mysterious things, so that is something to be cautious of. Most of the dorms are very old, but there are some that have been remodeled and are a lot cleaner than the older dorms. Th dorm like is very interesting, a lot of interesting people that you'll meet living in dorms. While it is an ideal place to live on campus, it is quiet expensive, and the food is not that great, it's a great experience to have, and I encourage you to live in the dorms at least one or two years.

Unless you're 21 and over most of the bars in town will not let you in, but there are several house parties and frat parties that are also available. But get repetitive after a while, but are still really fun to go to.

Basketball is the main attraction for many, but in order to get into a game you must wait outside the building for several hours and this goes on for several days. It is understandable why this is done, but it is seen to be ridiculous. The games are fun and full of energy. While football is seen to be something that we shun, because we are not as good as we are in basketball.

I give the the food and dining option on campus an A- because there is a nice variety of food selections. I wish the dining hall was still in my dorm like it was when my parents attend K.U. I have to walk two dorms over to the dining hall. It's not always fun when the weather is bad. Also there are alot of nice eateries throughout campus, which makes it convenient when you are on campus.

The University of Kansas has a nice selection of off-campus housing. It has a range of less expensive apartments to expensive apartments. It all depends on what you are looking for that fits your budget. The apartments in the downtown area are older apartments. They are located near the bus route, which will allow you to ride to campus easily. The more expensive apartments are in riding distance as well. These apartments offer more amenities. Lawrence is known for a college town environment. Overall, the off-campus housing offers plenty parking space and are pretty safe.
The computer labs at the University of Kansas are well stocked in the dorms as well as the libraries. I have my own computer. The school has excellent WIFI throughout the campus.
Drinking at Kansas is a very big thing, and a lot of it is being done by underage students. Therefore I would say the campus strictness is not very high.

The transportation at Kansas is excellent. The bus system has a new bus making a pickup every six minutes, so missing a bus does not mean you will not make it to class. It also holds a lot of students.

Living in the dorms in my opinion is a great thing for incoming freshmen. It's a great way to make friends, and stay involved with the school. Even though the dorms may not be as nice or kept up as an apartment would be, but the friendships and memories you make in them are absolutely worth it.
Anthropology is so dope and interdisciplinary. I feel very supported.
A huge queer community (Bi,A, Trans, Les, Gay) here. Even an on-campus drag show. Several queer instructors. A very artistic town.
Very diverse. Excellent organic COOP store. A lot of tasty joints.
We have an excellent public transit system free for all KU students and staff.
Wouldn't know about such things, I live off of campus.
Fairly everyone is materially oriented and identify themselves with the things they possess.
I do not live on campus so am not too informed on these issues.

I don't even know what Greek life means. Is it a way of life? If so, by observing the hyper-material and sexually repressed nature of this specific subculture I see no true value in embodying any of their practices. Negligent consumers that are destroying life on this earth is what I see.

The nightlife is pretty good. There are many things to do for students 18 and up and 21 and over. However most places that people attend are 21 and over. There are a lot of bars in our downtown area and are always packed during the weekends. People also have house parties, frat and sorority parties off campus that most people go to. There is always something to do.

Parking is horrible. It is extremely difficult to find parking if our have a permit without getting a ticket, and even with a permit at times it's hard to find parking in the parking lot. You can't park in any parking lots during special events and game days, even with a permit. Parking is a nightmare!!!!!!!!!!!

Athletics is a very big thing at my school. Since we are a D1 school it's no surprise that almost everything is based around athletics. We have the most supportive fans and they will camp for days just to get in to a home game and travel for away games. When a basketball game is on, nothing else is Lawrence is more important. W have the best school spirit.

Not a very diverse campus, so most guys and girls look the same. The outfits they wear are pretty similar, I.e, boat shoes, uggs, polos, athletic gear etc. Some are extremely fashionable, and some don't really care.

The Greek life at my school is very vibrant. We have plenty of Greek houses everywhere and they always doing something. They do a lot if during during the school year, especially in the beginning so people know more about them.
Only good if involved in school groups and clubs, otherwise you are on your own.
Freshman are able to live off- campus. Just depends on your personal preferences. Housing is easy & avaliable!

Parking near campus at KU can be a hassel. Parking spots are limited and at times, expensive. Students must apply in advance for parking in several different areas. The best spots are still a ways from most buildings but the walk isn't too bad. Parking downtown and parking during football games is a NIGHTMARE! Police officers enforce parking policies heavily and it can be frustrating to find a parking spot that is not 2 miles from where you want to go.
There are plenty of options close to campus with a variety of apartments, houses and town-homes. Most options are fairly priced and nice to live in.
There are all kinds of guys at KU. Frat guys, hipsters, athletes, and just plain normal guys. Most of the girls are nice and easy to talk to!

The athletics at KU are amazing. This is especially true of the track program and Men's Basketball program. Every home basketball sells out and numerous websites and magazines have called Allen Fieldhouse the best place to watch a college basketball game. The fans go crazy and it gets LOUD! Despite poor success in football, the student section is always packed and game days are a lively and fun experience in Lawrence. Students also show up in large number to track events, volleyball, baseball, softball, and soccer games. In conclusion, school spirit is high at KU and so is athletic performance.

KU is pretty terrible with providing scholarships for their students, especially compared to other large universities in the area. There are scholarships that exist, but they are almost all for very specific types of students and the vast majority do not qualify for them. They just started a new freshman scholarship program, but that was implemented after I started here so I was not included in that. If I was, maybe I would have gave them a higher grade in this category.

It's good. There are good and bad dorms to live in, but many have been renovated lately so nearly all of them are good places to stay. The cafeteria food is good most every day, and you can eat at chain restaurants on campus with your dining plan card. Most students live off campus after their freshman year.

I have been happy with my education at the University of Kansas. I am currently majoring in Speech-Language Pathology. I have had excellent professors in my field. The head of the department sends out emails to students about research and job opportunities for students to gain experience.
Most of the girls and guys on campus seem to be athletic because they dress in t-shirts and athletic shorts. Most students seem that they are in sororities and fraternities.

The weather is very random, so it can be difficult to figure out what to wear to stay warm. However when the weather is warm, everybody likes to go outside to study and hang out with friends. Although when it does start getting cold, there are bus systems that students use to get on campus because the dorms are pretty far from the main campus.

I also like how some of the classes have discussion sections that students have to attend. These discussions are useful to attend because it lets you hear other students' opinions about the book material and lectures. have to say about the lectures and book readings. Some popular study areas are the libraries on campus that have computers and laptops that students are able to use. Studying at the libraries can also be helpful because you can find other groups of people that are studying for the same test, and you can work together with them.

KU offers multiple majors that will fit anyones interest. There are several professional schools at KU including Business, Engineering, Pharmacy, Liberal Arts and Science, and Social Welfare to name a few. These programs are just a couple out of the wide variety that KU has to offer.

There are many apartments that surround campus. Some even stretch out as far as the edge of town but are connected through the bus routes that go directly to and from campus. These college friendly apartments make it easier for students to wish to live elsewhere than living on campus.

On campus places are good but they are pretty expensive. I would recommend going off campus and venturing out to what Lawrence has to offer. The main food courts on campus are in the Kansas Union and the Underground in Wescoe Hall. These particular venues give students a wide variety of food, but at a expensive price.

The diversity is great on campus but it isnt that outstanding. There are people from many different ethnic backgrounds and are inclusive in their activities and open to the public. But you have to dig deep in order to find these particular groups on campus.
Theres almost everyone for someone out there. If you look hard enough you will find yourself surrounded by thousands of people with the same interests.

The students at the University of Kansas come from all over the country as well as internationally, so there is a range of students. The ones that I have built friendships with are very nice, outgoing and well rounded. We all pretty much dress in tee shirts and jeans. We sometimes dress up for special occasions. Overall most students where the school's logo shirts and blue jeans. Most students develop friendships on their wings of the dorms and mainly socialize with them.

The University has such an excellent bus transportation system most students use daily. There are parking garages and parking spots throughout the campus. I don't have a car on campus so I am not sure how much parking permits are. I take the bus everywhere on campus and it works out really well for me.

My friends and I have found some clubs downtown near campus. We have always had a good time. We also go to fraternities parties and other on campus parties. We have always had a good time and have meet a lot of new people. They have transportation to these locations on campus.

I have always felt safe on campus. They have evening buses for students to use to and from campus. There is campus security to escort students to cars and different destinations. Overall, I rearly heard of any crime activities on campus.

As a biology major/ premed, I will be working for an orthopedic surgeon this summer. My responsibilities will include observing surgeries and office administration. I hope to acquire the experience and knowledge that will add to my portfolio for future references.

I am a biology major and am very happy with my major. The courses I have taken have been very beneficial towards earning my degree. Although, the courses have been somewhat challenging, I have persevered to maintained good grades. I would not do anything different. I am very happy how my education is progressing. My career goal is to become a pediatric cardiologist and practice in a hospital that has an excellent reputation in child medicine. I hope my career choice will have a promising outlook for me in the future.

Computers and printers are available. Wireless access is available but subpar. A personal computer is not absolutely necessary, but it is more convenient than having to go to the library to use a computer, especially during crunch times like finals. A printer is not necessary and most people do not have them; the printers are located at various locations around campus, and while there is a fee of 8 cents per page, it works fine.

I have used the campus and Lawrence transit systems regularly to get to class and stores in the community. It is available throughout the day every day but Sunday, and there are many different routes. All routes are free for KU students. The only complaint I have is the lack of nighttime routes. If I have a function on Mass Street past 8 p.m., I have to walk home (which is doable but not recommended). However, Lawrence is implementing a nighttime route service (that will unfortunately have a cost for KU students).

My experience with campus housing has been optimal. I lived in Ellsworth and Templin, and both are more recently renovated dorms on Daisy Hill. I made some of my best friends through living on my floor in Ellsworth freshman year, and we did many things together and became closer than most floors become. I lived in Templin sophomore year and had a different experience (the dorm is known for being quieter and more academic-minded), but I enjoyed it nonetheless. There's a reason I continued living in student housing after freshman year.

Sports at KU are essential to the atmosphere of the campus. People go to football and men's basketball games -- every game. Men's basketball is the main sport on campus, and we regularly do well and make it to the tournament. The other sports are not as popular, but as a volleyball fan myself, I find that when Jayhawks are playing, the people will come.

We have all sorts of guys at KU from city boys, country boys, athletic, rednecks, africans and foreign. The girls here are most likely Soroity girls, groupie girls ( for our Mens Basketball team) .They are attractive and smart and if you are not a Jayhawk girl then no man will want you we are the Cutest and Smartest.
F***ing hot all the way through January, and then it became f***ing cold and made us miss school with a s*** ton of snow in March and stayed cold all the way until the beginning of May. KANSAS!

You want to drink? Head to the Hawk if you're under 21. Over 21, right next to Mass. St. Want to eat? Head to Mass, or get delivery. Free cosmic bowling in the Union. Usually a movie is playing there too. SafeBus is free to ride, and goes through Mass, if you don't mind wasted kids. Also, fast dorm internet means you can have a great night in too, watching the Netflix.
The food at Mrs. E's is pretty alright, the floors tend to become a close knit community, and Ellsworth and Templin are nice places to live. McCollum is a s***hole though, because it is the oldest.
You have to have a parking pass to park anywhere on campus, and, even those are limited!
There is only one main bar where you can drink underage--The Hawk. Other than that, there isn't much but house parties.
KU basketball is half the reason I come to this school. Athletics are a big deal.
So many good restaurants downtown! And all the delivery places will deliver food to you at the library at 3am so that's a plus.

It's really not that strict here. Our campus has been known to have some pretty high amounts of underage drinking and although the official word from KU is that they are strict, they actually really aren't. It's strict enough that you'll be safe from crazy drunks though!
Very diverse, something for everyone. It really is the most diversity you're going to find anywhere in the state of Kansas.

The process is that you are required to have a certain gpa. once that is handled you need to fill out an application and a drawing of your shoe to test your drawing skills. that's the basics of the application process.
I have yet to have one but it is required and they help you along the way to get you into a internship.
At the moment i have yet to be accepted in to the architecture program but i'm sure it would be fun. Getting my basic requirements them self are fun so i can't wait.

I'm in University of Kansas and the majors that i am interested in is architecture. The architecture program is a well known program and is hard to get in but well worth it. its also very hands on and gives you the experience that is needed.
People sell Adderall for finals outside the classrooms. Weed smoking while walking to class
Good facilities. But, if you are not part of the sororiety or frats you have no life.

There's pretty much any kind of person you can think of here. There's a massive amount of preppy, sorority/fraternity types as well as lots of more alternative sort of people. Lawrence itself is kind of an offbeat town so you'll meet a lot of different people. The school is so big that you're bound to find someone you like. Some of the people can be kind of stuck up and snobby though.

I lived in Hashinger and there was only 4 computers. The 2 Macs wouldn't open documents and the mice often were stolen or disappeared so it usually was more like one computer. The printer broke a lot as well. I'd definitely recommend bringing your own laptop, though I will warn that ResNet (the internet you are Required to buy) constantly goes down.
Unless you apply by November 1, you won't get any scholarships at all and the ones that you do get are usually pretty small.

A lot of the classes are taught by TAs so it's likely that you are paying to be learning math or econ by someone only a year or two older than you. Until you get in higher level classes the class may consist of upwards of 600 people. One of my professors last semester even had to have a microphone to teach. The professors for the most part are really great but it's hard to get a one on one experience unless you're in the honors college, and the requirements for it are so difficult that if you had the qualifications for it that you'd be going somewhere other than a basic state school.

I never felt really safe on campus. I didn't join a lot of clubs because I didn't want to have to walk alone at night and there wasn't any transportation after 5:30 except on the weekends. There was also an armed robbery not far from my dorm on campus so it's really scary sometimes.

The process of getting into the School of Engineering for Chemical Engineering was relatively simple. In order to get in, High School grades must be up to par, as well as ACT scores. There are prerequisites for the Engineering program regarding each individual score on the ACT for each individual topic. After applying to the School of Engineering, you will receive a letter in the mail stating whether or not you got in.

There are a lot of options for housing; although, a lot of the housing has various stereotypes that are proven to be true. The only dorm that does not have a viable stereotype is Ellsworth. Oliver reserves the stereotype as being sketchy, just like McCollum, Templin is very intellect orientated, which is not a bad thing. If one can see past the stereotypes and think positive, it will definitely be a great experience no matter what.

Sports are supported by not just students, but all around the town. You could greet people with a rock chalk and most likely they would say jayhawk, and it doesn't get much better than Allen Fieldhouse
Social scene is awesome mostly all the students are friendly and full with school spirit. KU also has tons of programs ranked in the top among the nation.
Lots of buses for class. SafeBus and SafeRide is awesome so you don't drink and drive.

I lived in Ellsworth Hall in a 2 person room. Our room had a sink, cabinets, and mirror. We lived directly across the hall from the community bathroom. People who live in suites on the floor never used the community bathroom. A total of 12-15 people on the floor used the community bathroom.

Most of the nightlife is for 21 and up. There are still opportunities to have fun if you are underage. You can always find really fun house parties to go to because there is always one going on. If those aren't your thing then there are usually campus activities you can go to every now and then through the schol halls and dorms. The music scene is GREAT for anyone. There are multiple spots downtown where you can see music groups. A great way to scope out events is going to like coffee shops, stores downtown, and buildings on campus for fliers that are posted on bulletin boards.

I love the restaurants downtown! If you don't want the typical fast food kind of places then I would stick with mass street. My favorite place is The Burger Stand! They have vegan, vegetarian, and meat eater options, and the food is AMAZING. There are some restaurants that are kinda expensive, but there are still great cheap places to eat. Another great place would be Pepperjax. Soooo good!

The dining hall food is ok, but you get tired of it pretty quickly. I would suggest bringing little meals of your own if you are able to when you want to change things up. If you don't have time during the day you can always pack food the night before to take with you.
I feel that our school has some of the best transportation.
I love our computer labs, but the wireless internett in the dorms we have to purchase and it doesn't always work good.
I like the classes for my degree, they really challenge you in keeping you interested in several specific masters you could pursue.
Weather in Kansas is crazy, one day it's snowing the other it's giving you a sunburn. We've had snow and 70 degree weather in the same week. However, when it's nice out campus is awesome.

Like most schools, some classes are easy and some are difficult. Most professors care about what they are teaching and have experience in their subjects. Classes taught by TAs are great because they are closer in age and are more relatable.

Getting into the business school requires you to take pre-requisite classes(weed-out classes so some are more difficult). Then you have to apply and wait to hear if you go in or not. The Business school is very well respected and has great connections.

Greek life is present. Ever guy's first question is are you in a sorority which can be annoying when you aren't. They have events all the time but there is so much more to do in Lawrence that you don't have to be greek to have a good time. So many groups and athletics that offer the same things as greek life.

There are multiple computer labs on the KU campus, you can always find a open computer. The wireless is easy to connect to. There are computers set aside for only quick printing which is very nice, every student also is given a set amount of free printing at the beginning of each year.

Lawrence is a great city with a lot of options. We have basically everything we need there, shopping/ dining/ movies etc.
Also, Kansas City is only about 30 minutes away so you can have a big city feel close by if you want.

So far I have liked a lot of my professors and some have been very helpful.
I have been very pleased with most of my classes and have a good balance of hard work and feel challenged at the same time.

The campus police are ready and available to enforce the strict rules of underage drinking and speeding in vehicles.
Also, they will randomly check for fake identifications at the local bars.

There are plenty of options with the public transportation here on campus.
I know plenty of people who are satisfied with this.

We have campus police, but it seems like they are performing more traffic violations on the outskirts of campus rather than actually assisting/patrolling campus at night. There are a number of safety phones placed throughout campus. KU uses an alert system that texts and emails when something is happening on campus. It is very specific and very quick. However, campus seems pretty dark at night. While there are usually a number of students out and about, it can be a bit creepy at times when walking back to the dorms or to your car by yourself.

The weather is typical Kansas weather. The only downfall is that main campus is up on a hill. When it is cold and windy, it is extra cold and windy on the hill. However, there are buses to get you to class when the weather is bad. Campus has a number of places to lounge and relax when weather is beautiful.

It is a bit of a preppy school at KU. It is very Greed oriented, with a number of fraternities and sororities. There is a strong emphasis placed on self-care and attention. Campus is really split into thre groups: Greeks, GDIs (Goddamn Independents), and athletes. Both girls and guys tend to travel in packs. There is a bit of diversity, including a large acceptance and welcoming of the LGBT community. KU is welcoming of everyone and every type of person. While campus has 30,000. it is easy to become friends with people. Campus has a small feel as everyone is friendly and wants to be friends with everyone. There isn't that desire to avoid that awkward, "ohhh, you're in my class." People tend to get to know each other quickly and are not shy to become friends with anyone and everyone.

We have a large and easy to figure out bus system on campus. It is free to all students. With this option, there is also a safe bus offered on the weekends. This bus runs through our main going out street and stops at a number of residential stops to safely deliver students from their outings to home to discourage drunk driving. Beyond this is an opportunity called Safe Ride. It is a service offered free to KU students that will pick you up from a locaiton and deliver you home, no questions asked, no feel required.

I don't personally ride the buses, but I always see them running and if, for whatever reason, I needed to ride the bus, it would be very easy for me to find one. They even have the Jo from Johnson County come, which would make it very easy for me to get a ride home if my car broke down.

As far as I know the cost of a parking permit is reasonable-until you factor in that during basketball season you get kicked out of the spot you paid good money for. Even though this college is big on basketball, there is no excuse to kick STUDENTS out of the STUDENT parking lots.
Lawrence isn't huge but it's bigger than where I grew up. There seems to be plenty of things to do around town and Clinton lake isn't too far off.
Something for everyone in this town! Drinking or no drinking, there's millions of options.
Student Health services are not the greatest, but safety is good.

KU is pretty big on drug and alcohol safety. They have us take a short mandatory class almost every semester for it... It's a little time consuming but at least you learn something that you didn't know before.
living on campus is awesome. It is always easy to stay involved in activities living on campus
The price was reasonable and I could usually find a decent spot.

Kansas basketball is quite possibly one of the most appealing factors of the university. Allen Fieldhouse is electrifying and dynamic, and the football program is looking to take a positive turn this year a under second-year coach. Never before have I seen a student body rally behind a basketball team like the students at KU rally behind theirs.
Campus feels incredibly safe. Campus security is constantly patrolling to ensure that if an issue ever DOES arise, it is taken care of swiftly and accordingly.
Tons of bars and other places to hang out for people of all ages. Everything is accessible, no car/cab is needed for a good time!

In regards to racial/ethnic diversity, the University of Kansas is predominantly white. There are many students with different ethnic backgrounds, but they only make up a small percentage of the student population. I personally see more diversity in the students' religious beliefs and sexual orientation. Through my experience, I've met many people at KU with different religious belief systems or lack of a religious belief system, making it a place where anyone is bound to fit in. One may also find that there is a vast array of sexual orientations here; gay or lesbian couples can be seen holding hands while walking to class and there are student organizations, such as LGBTQ, that both people of those sexual orientations and straight people who support those orientations can be a part of. No matter what feature one has that makes them diverse, this school is very accepting and respectful of everyone and his or her differences.

The University of Kansas campus, though large, feels very safe to me. There are emergency telephones dispersed around campus, the campus police (who are actual police officers, not just security personnel) are always patrolling the area, and there are multiple street lamps throughout campus as well. Students can be seen alone on campus at almost any time of day or night, so it seems to me that most people feel safe here. Some people put so much trust into their environment and fellow students that they even leave their property unattended at the library if they need to take a phone call or go to the restroom (I have done that before). However, it is just as important to take security measures into your own hands no matter where you are, such as locking your car doors, using the buddy system at night, being aware of your surroundings, and keeping an eye on your personal items. In terms of health, the student health center is a high quality facility with a fully capable staff. I have been there many times for many different reasons and have gotten upstanding treatment (and prices) every time. Unfortunately, the facility is closed for most of the weekend, which can put students in a bind, especially those who are conscientious of their money. Overall, I'm glad to say I've never had a bad experience with health and safety at the University of Kansas, nor do I forsee myself having one.
The biggest "drug" used at KU is alcohol, regardless of age or location. Everyone here drinks and they party hard.

I didn't receive any aid but since entering the school, KU has revamped their renewable scholarship program so even if you don't qualify for financial aid, you can still get free money every year based on your ACT/SAT score or your GPA entering school.

Lawrence is one of the best college towns in the nation. It is a very vibrant place and there is always something to do. Downtown Lawrence is a lot of fun with its unique restaurants, shops and bars. Nearby Clinton and Perry lakes offer mountain biking/fishing/etc. Lawrence is a beautiful town during the Spring/Summer/Fall months and is a really enjoyable place to walk around. Cost of living is low while quality of life, especially for college students, is high.

Lawrence is regarded as one of the best college towns in the nation for a reason. For the 18+ there are a couple clubs, tons of house parties, open frat parties, and you can get into the Hawk by using a joke of a fake ID or simply passing said ID back in line. Fakes are very common and can get you in to nearly every bar in town (not Louise's or The Sandbar though).

Lots of options from apartments to old Victorian style houses. If you are into partying, the student ghetto or some of the larger new apartment complexes are definitely for you. If you want to live somewhere quieter there are many rental options in family oriented neighborhoods. Rent in Lawrence is very cheap. A few of the houses are run down, but you can usually avoid those by looking for a place early in the year. To find the best house for August you should start looking around December/January. Parking is never usually a problem and there are many options within walking distance to campus.
Lots of options in the Union and Underground. Lots of snack type cafes around campus especially in the libraries. You can use Beak 'em Bucks at many places around Lawrence.

Absolutely beautiful campus! Many state of the art buildings that offer the latest technology. With a very large number of majors to choose from its safe to say Kansas will have something for you if your interests change during your college experience. If you are into watching sports, there is no better place to watch a college basketball game in the world. Allen Fieldhouse is the mecca of college basketball. Even if you aren't into basketball, you will be by the time you graduate. Football games are fun too, even if we don't win. There are a million groups to get involved with on campus whether you want to support a cause or make new friends. Lawrence is one of the best college towns in the nation with its unique social scene, locally owned restaurants/bars, and a thriving nightlife. Rent is cheap as are the drinks!

KU provided me with the education to get my dream job in engineering! They prep you for the outside world and are eager to help you find a professional job or internship. The course load can be strenuous but when you land a sweet job you will think it was worth it. Lots of major-related projects to get involved with that add to your knowledge and experience. Campus is beautiful with plenty of library space to post up in and study.
Great and informative financial aid office. Always available to answer questions.

I'm not into drugs, but I am into partying. Never been pressured into anything. If you are into weed, you won't have a problem finding it. At the same time, I have never been bothered by it. Lots of friendly pot-heads in Lawrence.
Lawrence is a great town for foodies. Many local owned options. This small town can easily hold its own against major cities.

Lawrence is definitely a college town. The Jayhawk can be seen everywhere around Lawrence. Most of the local people are very involved with KU basketball and are very friendly with KU students. There are many places to go to around Lawrence including Mass street. On the weekend Mass street is always busy and if you are willing to drive farther you can go to Kansas City.

KU is probably one of the most prideful colleges in the US. Most of the students are very involved in campus activities and sports. There is something on campus for everyone. Many students frequently work out at the rec center located right next to Oliver. The night before tests you can always find students crowded around tables cramming or in the many study rooms available. There is always something going on at the Union and even when there isn't anything you can always find many people there meeting up with other people.

There are many options for off-campus housing. Some are very expensive and some are pretty cheap. The cheapest I know of is called Meadow brooks and it's very close to campus and the public transportation there is also pretty convenient. Some of the nicer off-campus apartments are the Grove and Legends. They are very nice but more expensive. The good thing is that even though they are more expensive, they are still cheaper than the dorms.

Living in the dorms is possibly one of the most important experiences I had in college. It's a great way to meet new friends, hang out, and learn. I currently live in Lewis and I love the atmosphere, the way the rooms are set up, and the proximity to the dining hall and bus stop. Hashinger is also a great dorm; it's also close to the dining hall and it's where The Studio is located. Even though McCollum is much older than the other dorms, it's where you can meet a lot of new people.

As I mentioned previosuly, I have been at the University of Kansas for two years now. I have gotten to know some wonderful teachers, awesome peers in my School of Social Welfare and have learned so much. The reason why I gave this facility an A- instead of an A+ is that the University does not have a lot of diversity. I believe diversity is important an any college due to the fact that diversity brings other cultures, backgrounds, beliefs, values, and so on into a community. MORE diversity in KU would win an A+ for me.

There are buses that can take you anywhere on campus so there really is no need for a car if you live on-campus. Public transportation is also really helpful if you live off-campus; there are always buses near most of the apartments. The only problem is that buses usually stop running in the late afternoon. If you are stuck out late at night you can always contact safe-ride and they will take you back home no matter where you are in Lawrence.

I transfered to KU from a community college in 2011, I wish i could have gone to KU my four years of college. I have enjoyed meeting so many friendly, outgoing people. There are many organizations to join, where you can meet people, get involved and make friends. There is nothing I regret about attending this Univeristy!!

Lawrence has so much to offer- mostly on Mass Street. The music scene is awesome, and local events are always going on: like parades, block parties, art in the park, the sidewalk sale, etc. There's a lot to do around town if you're actively looking for opportunities.
The state of Kansas's weather is bipolar. Yesterday, it was 85, today it was 52 and there are still snow piles on the ground from last week.
There is a lot of very nice houses to choose from around KU. I pay about $350 for a very big place. On-campus living is another good choice if you do not mind dealing with RAs.

Availability and Affordability – The University of Kansas is a very large school, but each of the seven libraries has computers open to students, and tons of printing areas. One may simply rent a laptop for a few hours for free, using their i.d. Printing does cost $0.08 per page, but each semester every student gets 100 free pages of printing, and in some areas of study, printing is free (ex. Engineering).
I would say it's pretty safe. I mean there are people that do drink or smoke weed, but overall you don't see a lot of it out. There really isn't a pressure for you to do that kind of stuff.
I haven't ever had times that I felt unsafe on campus. There are always safety phones you can use in case of emergencies and it's easy to alert campus police if something happens.

There are a lot of places (clubs, bars) on Mass street that you can go to, for both 18+ and 21+, and there are usually house parties every weekend, where you can go for free or just pay a small fee (like $5). Student organizations also organize parties quite often, so you will not miss out on the party scene no matter who you are.
The dorms are standard, bunk bed rooms. There is plenty of space, good parking, and several cafeterias and shops on campus close to the living quarters.

There aren't many drugs or drug consumers, most people drink occasionally, but it is generally not a big problem. The university does take care of its residents and drinking as well as consuming drugs is not allowed on campus.
Lawrence has something for everyone. Lots of shops and bars and places you're sure to find something that suits you.

With everyone complaining about obesity in America, KU is extremely fit. The best part about KU is that there is a style of person for everyone. It is not solely sorority girls or hippies or hipsters, KU has every sort of style available.

The buses are now included in your fees, something that upperclassmen my freshman and sophmore year complained about. However, nobody seemed to mind after the first snow. The buses are great on campus but can be late if you rely on them for transportation from your home or apartment.

Campus is very safe and police are very quick to respond. Their presence after dark is definitely felt. Incidents do happen, it is a school of nearly 25,000 people in a town of 100,000. The one thing that they are improving since my undergraduate years is lighting in neighborhoods surrounding campus and near downtown. This could still be improved.

The University of Kansas is commonly downgraded and stereotyped based solely on admission standards (which are dramatically changing). However, the University is tremendous in its rigorous academics, great professors, and definitely a strong study abroad program.
Living on campus sucks. It's expensive, the food is horrible, and parking is a pain.

The area is very different from the rest of Kansas. The downtown area is fun and has a bunch of restaurants. But I do not enjoy the weather here. It makes it hard to go out in the winter because it is so cold and the summers are blistering and dry.
It is a good school but kind of a joke. Anyone can get in and they claim they are all these good things when really it doesn't mean crap because the are the only school out here.

Nightlife here is alright. There are plenty of bars and clubs for anyone 21 and over, and a couple of dance clubs that accept 18 and over, but those are harder to come by. For freshman, it's easiest to hit up the house parties (and there are plenty, believe me) down by Memorial Stadium. SafeBus and SafeRide make it pretty easy to get around without a DD.

I wouldn't suggest walking around KU alone at night for very long. My freshman year, the spring of 2012, there were two separate attacks of girls walking on campus on Friday nights. (They weren't horribly harmed). That and people will steal anything if it isn't locked up. But Campus Security is around and we do have a safety system in place.

The KU bus system is pretty solid. It's usually relatively on time (give or take 5 minutes) and has enough lines to get you where you need to go whether you live on campus or somewhere else in Lawrence. (And free for KU students, though some lines require you to show an ID). SafeBus runs every Thursday-Saturday night and while I love that they have it, it takes forever to come. Find some other way to go out during the winter- you'll freeze to death waiting for it.

Most of the people I've met in classes are all right. It's the ones who live in my dorm who are irritating. Most of the girls dress in yoga pants/leggings all the time (even in winter) or in minis and boots. The guys dress sloppily most of the time. Maybe I'm just biased against such attire, but I don't think that's what they ought to be wearing to class and around campus.

I'm majoring in Classical Antiquities (ancient Greek and Roman culture, very cool). The instructors are polite and available when you need them, as well as being highly qualified and knowledgeable. I'm only a freshman, so I can't tell much, but the head of the department often sends out emails about graduate programs at other colleges and notifies us of scholarship and study abroad opportunities also.

KU obviously has an amazing basketball team, and most of their other sports are good. However, the fan base is rabid, and if the teams have less than optimal performance, it bashes the players, the opposing team, and anyone who questions such crazed devotion.
The rec center is fully equipped and available to any student with their ID.

The classes I have taken are challenging but rewarding. The professors are friendly and always willing to answer questions. If you want to get a B or an A, study often and do the work, and you will receive a good grade.

For students living on-campus, many restaurants are nearby on Mass Street. I don't eat at restaurants much, but the options range from ethnic Greek and Arabic to burgers to vegetarian to ice cream. I you want it, chances are that it'll be there.
If you're into the Greek scene, go to the Hawk! There's also the Cave, and Chateau too.There's always Mass St. too where places will be bumping, like the Jazz Haus, the Granada, the Hookah House...
KU has a alot of good majors to chose from. It's not to difficult to double major or minor either.
I would not do the BS in Economics. The math classes tore up my GPA. I would probably do a business major because it's easier to do well there and the internship opportunities are way better.
Goof Facilities – The Watson Health Center is good, there are always people on hand to check things out and appointments can easily be set up.
Some schools require you to take Gen Eds before admissions, like the Business and School of Education. But others allow freshmen with good records to be admitted at once.

KU has plenty of majors including the more obscure ones like Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies and Petroleum Engineering to name a few. Most departments are very helpful in finding internships and jobs as well.

The housing off-campus are excellent. The pros are that the housing off campus are close and available buses to take students to class or parking in campus if you chose to drive to campus. The student are available to get transportation that is offered by the school. The housing off campus are safe and convenient.
The University should add more parking for students. The cost for the parking is reasonable however.

The campus is fairly safe, but there have still been reported attacks and muggings, and the like. There are "areas of rescue" lights with 911 buttons, but they are spaced very far apart. I have night classes, and, these do not make me feel any safer than I would without them.

There is quite a lot of diversity on the campus, but the only flaw is that people from different countries and cultures tend to travel in ameoba-packs and make sidewalk travel a little difficult at times.

Lawrence is a beautiful town filled to the brim with all kinds of hipsters and academics. The restaurant scene is absolutely glorious -- nearly everything on the main drag is local, and everything has history. The student slums are somehow not too terribly slum-ish, and almost every home has some wonderful quirk about it. Very artsy.

Most of the computers work just fine, but I have had some trouble with the online portion of math classes on different levels of Watson. The availability of computers depends on how bad you need to get something done. If you have 3 minutes until class time, you're screwed. If you show up at 8 in the morning with a fresh coffee and papers to print ahead of time, the computer gods will smile on you with generosity and favor.
You can find anyone you want. Any genre of partner is to be found. The campus is especially great if you are LGBT.

Finding parking when and where you need it is hard. Very hard. I have my car with me, but I never drive it to class. Walking won't get you a parking ticket. The permits are hella expensive, and everything, if a video game, would be considered "expert" levels.

Parking on campus can be confusing, if not nearly impossible. There are several different lots, each with their own color. Parking passes will only allow you to park in a certain lot (for example, a parking pass for the dorm parking lot doesn't guarantee you access to all the parking lots across campus). It's difficult to determine which lots you're allowed to park in, on certain days, at certain times, with or without a pass. Often, the lots aren't marked well, making it more difficult to determine where you can and can't park. And parking is pretty strictly enforced, so parking in the wrong lot could get you a $25 ticket.

I'm a Resident Assistant in the dorms at KU, so I'm familiar with the policies and what happens if you break them. Since KU is a dry campus, no alcohol is allowed anywhere on campus (including the dorms) for any reason. If you're caught in the dorms, you are written up and have to schedule a conduct hearing with a supervisor. Based on the situation, they will assign an appropriate punishment, such as taking an alcohol education course or writing an essay about their behavior. In the dorms, residents can also be written up for multiple noise violations after quiet hours, disrespecting staff, being in possession of illegal drugs, vandalism, etc.

Lawrence, Kansas is definitely a college town. Because the university and the city are so closely intertwined, the school spirit doesn't end when you walk off campus. The Jayhawk is a one-of-a-kind mascot - and you'll see it everywhere! The school spirit here can't be beat. Our men's basketball team is fantastic, the students are proud of their school, and even the locals aren't afraid to sport the crimson and blue. On game days, the campus is electric, and watching a basketball game in Allen Fieldhouse is an unreal experience. Mass Street is the main cultural vein through Lawrence, and there are tons of great places to shop and eat. There's always something new to do on campus, and with so many student groups, there's bound to be something for you. The best part is that the school spirit will follow you across the country. The Jayhawk is one of the most widely recognized college mascots in America, so no matter where you go, you'll see someone smile your way, tip their hat and say, "Rock Chalk!"

I lived in Lawrence my entire life and the Jayhawks were my team. I came to KU because I thought it would be my home away from home but I immediately got slapped in the face.

The girls I met were really snobby and materialistic. They only cared about their sorority and their alcohol. I didn't realize that the only way to have fun on this campus was to drink. If you don't drink, it's really hard to have a good time.
