I am an environmental studies major. Finding interesting people to talk to is never hard, however, I'm having a hell of a time finding a minor that I won't have to scrimp and save for the extra classes. I feel like some of the other majors get more attention and funding.

Everything is walking distance on campus. If you're headed to the far reaches of somewhere, there are buses that go everywhere. Buses that are free, with really awesome drivers. Biking culture is huge-- people are on bikes all year round. Driving, however is discouraged by comparison. Having a car is quite useful for going other places in town, but the parking permits will cost you your favorite limb.

Courseload varies; take care when scheduling, the professors are about half and half as far as quality goes. The registration process sometimes can be a little stressful, especially if you're a baby freshman.

The food isn't fancy, but it's manageable. Certain meals get old, as any would, but there is fair variety. I don't think it's well suited to vegans, and it is very expensive compared to how much I spend at the grocery store to feed myself what I actually want to eat

I don't feel a rating is accurate, because I'm from Kansas and I understand Kansas weather. It's warm then cold in the same day. Expect Kansas weather if you're coming to KU. If you want warmer, obviously choose somewhere consistently warm.

I didn't realize, as the first child going to college, that when you applied to the school you should also apply for financial aid/scholarships. I'm not sure why there's even an option not to, but somehow I chose that. The 4-year renewable scholarships are only open to incoming freshman, so I have no way of getting financial aid from KU now that I know. Outside scholarships have processed and are easy to handle, however.
Campus has tons of history and just seeing the old architecture on buildings is pleasing. Tons of places to study, tons of tradition, and always an activity going on

I lived in Templin Hall, which was nice because we had our own living area and a shared bathroom between 4 instead of the entire floor. Being on campus is a luxury for proximity. The meal plan is pricy, however, and some dorm policies are strict. A good RA can make your dorm experience. Housing process isn't too hard
Great Rec center, Basketball atmosphere is amazing, tons of clubs and success in other sports like Track and Field. Friendly staff everywhere
You may have to walk but there is always a spot somewhere on campus
Everyone is diverse and very friendly and many different races.
The weather is changing everyday, could be snowy/sweaty/rainy on any given day. The KU buses will always be your best friend in bad weather. And buy yourself an umbrella.
You just have to decide to do it, and then you're in...for my department at least. No gpa requirements or specific classes to take first.
There are many times when you are unable to get a computer for schoolwork because they are all being taken for personal use. Also, the limited amount of free printing is very annoying.
I have always felt safe on campus. I have never felt at all threatened and there are always helpful people around I were to be in an emergency situation.
Best to bring your own in order to avoid having to share or get administrator approval to download the latest java, adobe, etc.
Great professers, great student to teacher ration, and work is manageable with extracurricular activities if you put in the effort.
For the tuition prices and other college costs, you recieve a quality educationa and great college experience.

First off, most of the campus is completely closed to student motor traffic during the day, and as such, parking options are more limited than you might find at some other universities. Furthermore, the parking police at KU are extremely diligent- unless you procure a parking permit early on and do everything by the book, it can be difficult to avoid fines (although they are thankfully small, on the $20 scale). Finally, if you must drive, arrive at least one hour before your earliest class; parking fills fast.

Given the vast population of KU and the many countries and corners of the United States that it draws from, there are many attractive guys and girls of all cultures! In general, individuals are also fairly attractive, so that's a definite plus.

As one might expect, however, pickings get more slim in the hard sciences and school of engineering- girls are few and far between in most engineering classes, and guys tend to be a little more introverted. That said, there are still plenty of guys and girls of all types within these majors.

The dining hall experience at KU is decent enough- getting one's needed nutrition is certainly easy and at no point do you have to stomach unpalatable foods, but mass-produced, processed food is mass-produced, processed food. In short, you won't cheer, but it will keep you full and decently happy.

I am not going to say that Greek life in not important at KU, but it is not completely going to ruin your life forever if you do not join. All of the Greek houses are beautiful and if the frat/sorority you fall in love with happens to be on West Campus Road, all the better for you - it's in the middle of campus and great for walking to any and all classes.

I love the Genetics program (this in turn includes the Biology department). As you get into higher-level classes, there are so many opportunities to take a course that you will actually enjoy - compared to the general education requirements that are so awful. I personally don't really have any worries about finding a job as a researcher, but if that doesn't work out I would feel very comfortable getting a position as a scientific writer.

KU has the greatest basketball program, let's just get that straight right now. In terms of academics, our honors program is unrivaled. There are so many opportunities to make the time you spend here your own. You can study abroad, go greek, join one of the over-600 clubs. There is truly something for everyone here.

KU has traditions that cannot be rivaled by any other school. In terms of aesthetics, sure - some of our buildings are the prettiest (here's looking at you Wescoe) but they all serve their purpose and give campus a great feel. The libraries are fantastic, the rec is great, and I don't even really need to mention the Field House.
The Shuttle is very good about picking people up everywhere, and no matter what people have cars to take you places...or you can walk.
KU has everything to offer, there is never a dull moment in this community. Everything that you need is there for you and is super close!
Amazing school spirit! Especially when it comes to basketball! Allen Field House is the best place to go to a game.
I would say that KU is very diverse. I know people from across the country and even some people studying abroad here. Different sexual orientations are common and from what I can tell very accepted.
The dining hall is pretty good. They are very accomodating for people with allergies, which is a huge plus, but they do not have a big variety of different meal plans for purchase.
Lots of things to do during the week and of course after Basketball games, Mass Street is rockin.

The Exercise Science program here is great. The professors are extremely intelligent in their respective disciplines and truly care about developing a rapport with the students. A majority of the professors work in research and/or a clinical setting and thus are encouraging students to participate in their own studies and are frequently offering students opportunities to get involved within the department. The courses are appropriately challenging and do a good job to prepare prospective PT/OT school applicants.
It is fairly easy to print when at a campus location. In the dorms they have business labs where i can print to and enter a code for pick up later.

The process of getting into the Exercise Science program involved taking required general education classes and maintain a particular GPA throughout such classes. Upon completion or during the final semester of these required classes, an electronic application is filled out through the program in the School of Education. The application involved proof of completion in each of these required classes or proof of taking the class during the semester you apply. An additional application with an essay can be fulfilled for scholarship opportunities within the program.

As an exercise science major an internship is part of my curriculum and must be completed in order to graduate. The internship has requirements such as being unpaid (compensated by receiving college credit), and is typically a 15-week 40hrs/week internship. For my program in particular, the department offers links and contact information to most of the various companies and organizations with which students have interned before and thus I am able to contact them to set up my own. If looking to go anywhere away from campus or out-of-state, there is a minimum GPA and paperwork requirement to fulfill
Computers are very accessible on campus at coffee shops and libraries and in some rooms
They are amazing they have calendars with activities.

There are a lot of places to park at the dorms but not a lot of places on campus where classes are held. A lot of the houses and apartments have to park off the road. There is no place on campus with free parking during 7am to 5pm and they give out parking tickets really well if you dont have a parking pass.

There are a lot of restaurants off-campus. All the major chains are close to campus like buffalo wild wings, McD, Dunkin donuts, etc. There are also a lot of asian restaurants and a nice greek restaurant. Its not difficult to find places to eat!

The cafeterias inside the dorms are okay. Not the best quality food but decent. There are other on campus places to eat that have chick-fil-a, pizza-hut, sushi, chinese, and other places in a food court under the Wescoe building.

The financial aid I recieved covered all my tuition but not my living expenses. I am no where close to being a 4.0 student but they still gave me this great scholarship. Living on campus is really expensive and so are books, but KU's financial aid covered a big chunk which I am super grateful for!
There are so many options in Lawrence it's ridiculous. It ranges from cheap to extravagant, dirty but delicious to downright gourmet. It's phenomenal.

When it came to financial aid I'm too "rich" to receive any type of grants and my parents didn't want to take out any loans so it sucked because they had to pay for my first year of college by themselves. Their payment plans aren't too beneficial either
You aren't guaranteed a parking space in the area you want with a parking pass. There are plenty of places to lock up a bike though.
KU basketball is awesome, and students get really cheap tickets.
I absolutely love the University of Kansas in all aspects of the spectrum
There are many options when going out to eat, Mass St. is the main source of restaurants around campus
One of the complexes recently caught on fire so it made me change my view on how off campus housing was
There are house parties, frat parties if youre in greek life. Lots of bars for 21 and up. The Cave and other clubs have 18 and over nights.
More Than Good – There are tons of computers to use on campus and campus wifi is almost everywhere. Printing is easy with your KU card and the cost is reasonable, too.
The downtown/campus area of Lawrence is awesome. Everything is so close if you live in that part of town. The local attitude has nothing but love for Lawrence.

There are plenty of routes and they run on well-timed schedules. Once you're enrolled, all public transportation is free. We also have a program called safe ride. If you need a ride home from the bars, they will come and get you for free as well.

Straight out A. We have an excellent gym. The libraries are also great places to study and on-campus wifi has never failed me. KU has a beautiful campus and Lawrence nightlife has something for everyone.

The weather is crazy some days. In the span of two days it went from 17 degrees to 74 degrees. Other then that the weather is generally fine. It obviously gets cold there but as long as you are prepared for the weather you should be fine.

As a freshman living in the dorms, the parking sucks. There isn't always room for you to park in front of your dorm so you usually end up parking about three dorms away. They give you tickets for literally everything. If your car is parked on the line, ticket. If you don't fix your car right away they will continue piling on the tickets.

There are not very many things for underage students to do but there are a few clubs. The down fall of that is they are only 18 and over a few times a week. Other than those select few days it is impossible to get in. The only other option you have is house parties, which are generally pretty fun but can get kind of sketchy at times so you just have to be aware of your surroundings.

KU has over 600 clubs and organizations that you be a part of, intra-mural sports, $75/semester tutoring for the majority of undergraduate courses, 2 rec centers/2 unions with extended hours, and is just a few minutes walk away from the vibrant downtown known as "Mass St." The basketball is unreal, boasting five national titles and I forget how many big XII titles. It has the loudest sports arena in college basketball and is the most historic venue to be at. The atmosphere is contagious and truly is a phenomenol experience to be a part of. Student packages for all home sports games are priced at $150 the past three years so it is easy to get tickets as a student.

The KU bus system runs all over campus and to all major apartment complexes (and some smaller ones). In addition, students can ride any Lawrence bus for free just by showing their KU ID. And it's included with your campus fees so the cost is minimized. Hertz car rentals are available on campus parked next to the Union and the residence halls. In addition, it is easy to give a friend $20 to take you to the airport in KC.

Campus is dry so any underage drinking in the residence/scholarship halls is prohibited and grounds for removal. However, typically first offenses are more of a slap-on the wrist. Most other behavior is lenient up to the line where it infringes on others students. I would consider the rules and laws to be reasonable, with very few students complaining.
Wind can be strong up on the "hill" and Kansas winters can be rough but overall, weather is pretty moderate
I park at my dorm, so therefore is not an issue with me. There are shuttle buses available all the time which are very helpful.

It is typical midwest. You have 4 seasons. So far the winter has been mild. The main campus is on top of a hill, so in severe icy weather you want to be careful and give yourself extra time to walk to class.

I am a member of a sorority. Therefore there are always activities and parties to attend. There are a lot of bars at KU and very easily accessible. There are basketball games as well. There is also a good downtown in Lawrence KS. A lot to do(ie movies,bands etc)
The dorms are all pretty good, but the food is bad
The dorms are pretty strict, but on campus its easy
There is a Mac lab and all the others are usually up. You can often find computers in places you would not expect
Great musical entertainment regularly, cool vintage shopping but not much other activity other than the bars
Its pretty poor but it is affordable depending on the meal plan you get
Dorms here are better than my other friends dorms but they are still dorms
They don't care about underage if you don't have the drink in your hand

Lawrence has quite a few options for off campus housing. The cost of rent is a lot higher than what I'm used to though (small Kansas town). There are a lot of complexes that are students only, these tend to be kind of noisy with paper thin walls. But there is always something available, you just have to do your homework and open your eyes.

The bus schedule while classes are in session is pretty convenient, but if you plan on being in Lawrence over break don't expect the buses to run when or where you might need to catch them. Campus parking in EXTREMELY limited and expensive!!! I chose the Park and Ride option which shuttles you from on off-campus parking lot, but that's still pretty pricey.
Mass Street is not too far away, but not many restaurants within walking distance.

The main road through campus that contains all of the most used buildings is blocked off during school hours for school affiliated vehicles only. This makes maneuvering through campus a pain and any other parking around requires a permit. As a city in general, tickets are easy to come by. If you park illegally and leave your car for 5 minutes it is likely that you will be ticketed. A good thing I have to say is Lawrence/KU has a great bus system. I lived 15 minutes south of campus and the school bus came to my apartment complex for pick ups every 30 minutes.

KU is in a great location. Lawrence, KS is a small town but there is a lot of college feel to it. Many employers around here are specifically looking to employ students so job searching is not always difficult. Our basketball team has always been highly ranked and we have really fun seasons so jayhawk spirit and school games are great to attend. We have a great abroad program that offers opportunities to all majors and all departments. I have received financial aid every semester and they are accommodating to my needs, making it easy for me to attend school even with low funds. Overall, professors are effective are willing to put in their time to help students learn and progress. I will say that I don't like the size of the classes. For gen eds I am usually in a classroom hall that fits 400 but as I get in to core classes for my major the size decrease greatly to 30.

In my opinion, greek life is beneficial for a certain dynamic of students. I don't think it's meant for everyone and I don't think there should be negative connotation for those who don't participate in it. I think greek life has become something very different from what it originally was intended for. If fraternities and sororities weren't associated so much with partying, gossip, cliques, etc I would be interested in joining one. The process has become way too selective on levels that students shouldn't be judged on.
You hear a lot of stories of drug use and excessive alcohol use.
There's a ton of variety when it comes to the guys and girls that go to the University of Kansas. No matter what kind of guy or girl you are looking for, you're sure to find them at KU.

There is a lot going on all the time on the KU campus, no matter what you are interested in. There are hundreds of clubs and intramurals to join and there is something for everyone. Greek life on campus is pretty prevalent but it's not for everyone. KU is a college full of traditions, we even have a "Traditions Night" every year at the start of the fall semester. The most popular hangout is Wescoe Beach, especially on sunny spring days.

Around finals is the prime time that people on campus start to abuse drugs such as Adderral and Ritalin, for the most part at other times no one uses them. However, pot and alcohol are often used during the entire semester. Though KU is supposedly a dry campus, there is often alcohol and pot in the dorms and drunk people are often wandering around the halls of any dorm.

The libraries and computer labs can be crowded close to finals, but there is usually not a long wait to use a computer. However, one of the best things about the KU technology department is that they are always looking for ways to help the students. For example, near finals, they added extra money to our printing accounts so we could print final projects without worrying about scrounging up the quarters to print ten to fifteen pages of work. Another great thing that they have instituted is phone charging stations. They will be beginning to set up phone charging stations in many computer labs and libraries with iPhone and other phone adapters so that people can charge their phones on campus without having to remember to bring their chargers with them.
Though sometimes it can be difficult to find an apartment as close to campus as one would like, there is no denying that the prices of Lawrence apartments close to the KU campus is the best.

"The Legends" is extremely afforable for people who aren't the richest but don't want to live in the dorms. It's location is almost 5 minutes away from campus and they also have an tight security team who protects the building.
It was very easy and simple for me to get my federal finanical aid but when i came down to the school's finanical aid it was and still is very difficult.

Univerisity of Kansas has a heart warming welcome to any kind of ethnic background, political beliefs, religion and sexual orientation because we are all mature and wise enough to let people express themselves in any way they please and won't feel uncomfortable about it.
When I lived in the dorms I thought the food was very good. Not everything was spectacular but they have tons of options so there is always something good to eat.
The scholarships that you get at KU are awesome, it is just really hard to get any that are worthwhile...
The only bad thing about the parking is the cost. It is very expensive and there is no place on campus that you can park for free.

There are many students at the University of Kansas with different nationalities, religions, and backgrounds. However, the majority of the student body seems to be upper-middle class and white. While the university boasts a large population of study abroad students, a large percentage of those students come from one country (China).

There are so many different types of people on campus. There are a lot of international students, especially from Asian countries. All different religions and sexual orientations are present. The political beliefs aren't as diverse, as many people are liberal. The differences among students seem to be easily accepted by others.

There isn't a great parking situation for students at KU. A parking permit for an entire year costs $200 and the only lot that guarantees a spot is by the rec which you either have to walk up the hill or take the bus up to class.

Lawrence has plenty of off-campus housing options. There are places available for any type of housing one can be interested in. The dorms weren't what I was looking for and I was able to find an apartment for the same/less price that is a good quality. There are also specific apartment complexes specifically for students that are cheap and convenient.

The weather in Kansas can be a little crazy sometimes. It can be sunny one hour and raining the next. Also, we get both hot and cold extremes. I'm used to this as I have lived in Kansas my whole life, but I always check the weather before leaving and I carry a little umbrella just in case.

I love my major, which is Electrical Engineering. I want to be doing something either with synthesizers and design of said devices, or something with motorsports, and my college has people that specialize in both of those things. My school is pretty good at helping people find jobs after college, and if you don't want a job at one of the companies that the school pretty much feeds into, you have to find your own way into those companies, but you are really well qualified to get into those companies. I'd love to do this all over again, because it's so much fun to learn things!

While there has been some criminal activity on campus, it feels pretty safe to go out late at night, simply because you can't go five minutes without seeing a police car pass you. During the day, most people around you are just trying to get to class, just as you are, and there are so many people around, a mugging seems absurd. Plus, there are emergency phones that you can activate, and police will be at your location within two minutes.

Extra-person charges may apply and vary depending on hotel policy.
Government-issued photo identification and a credit card or cash deposit are required at check-in for incidental charges.
Special requests are subject to availability upon check-in and may incur additional charges. Special requests cannot be guaranteed.

KU feels like a very safe campus and my experience at Watkins has been excellent. The only time I feel a little iffy is when I'm walking away from my car (which is parked at the Lied Center) to the dorms really late at night, but its really well lit and there's an emergency phone at the edge of the parking lot.
I partied mostly on the weekends and only after I had completed my school work. This way I felt more free while partying and I wasn't really wasting any time.
Mrs. E's loses its luster early in the semester.
I have not really began to dig deep in to the Business Major at KU.

I am currently undergoing transferring majors. It is difficult to understand the requirements for each program. Though explained online; the requirements are not made very clear. The advising center is great for helping students understand what a major or program entails.

The few times that I've needed to use the computers on campus, I never had a problem finding a spot. The reason I gave a B+ instead of an A is that, as a grad student, there is no printing allowance given as there is to undergrads.

There are a lot of people on campus at KU. There are a high number of students from Asian countries, especially Japan, so foreign languages aren't rare. There are also a lot of people from Kansas, who haven't looked very far outside of Kansas. Overall, dress is pretty much college chic, with guys in KU apparel and some sort of pants, and girls in KU apparel and leggings. There are some that are more fastidiously dressed, but they are the minority. Guys are tall, and girls are short here. However, as far as interests go, there aren't too many students that are passionate about what they do, unless you go to the schools of music or engineering.

There are restaurants for everybody near the University of Kansas. The campus is in the heart of down town Lawrence, where ethnicity isn't rare. Walking down Massachusetts street is never a disappointment and no matter what mood you are in you will find a restaurant that will simply "hit the spot". There aren't many chain restaurants in the area, which personally is my favorite part. A majority of the restaurants are active in the social network scene, tweeting deals for students daily. Whether you're in the mood for a dollar margarita and some Mexican food at Tapas or a $3 bottle of house wine with italian food at Genovese, you'll find something delicious and affordable for the typical broke college student. There's also a gluten-free fried chicken restaurant which is absolutely scrumptious.

Lots of options for every interest. Apartments 15 miles away still are 99% students if you want that, or you can live 1 block from campus for the same price in a house. Buses are free and run everyday from all over town so you're pretty much always going to pick a good place. Prices are reasonable, safety is good, and landlords vary.
With 30,000 students on the Lawrence campus, there's something for everyone

After my first semester here, I am very pleased with the variety and effectiveness of their courses. You can go bowling or even do Zumba for college credit. After taking my classes, I feel I have learned a lot without even realizing it.

The school provides some resources and brochures to look at when searching for a place, but that's as far as they go. I've found apartments simply by doing my own searching and through the talk of friends.
Everyone is able to do as they please without the approval of others. Everyone is welcoming and polite.

As is typical for Kansas, the weather at KU can be a little unpredictable and ever changing at times. For the most part, however, it's never too extreme, and in the case of bad weather there are buses constantly coming to and from campus.

Compared to the rest of Kansas, KU (and Lawrence itself) is a haven for interesting people. You'll find guys and girls from all walks of life, and a lot of them attractive. There are people from all subcultures, if that's what you're into, and it'll be no challenge finding somewhere you fit in.
I have never felt unsafe on campus. It is very beautiful, safe place to be. I would keep the door locked at night because of pranks but that will be over before you know it.

The nightlife at the University of Kansas is pretty big. The only problem is that you have to be 21yrs or older to enter most of the bars and clubs. There are a couple of places that are available for 18yr olds and these are enjoyable places to go to. The transportation at KU is pretty remarkable. They have "safe buses" that are available for students who have had too much to drink and these run almost all night long on the weekends. The parties across the campus are pretty hard to miss. Almost every fraternity throws a party on the weekends and the houses around the campus are always throwing lawn parties.

The Greek Life at the University of Kansas is pretty big. Being in a fraternity myself, I see the Greek Life as a mainly positive influence on the campus. Every other week, I see some fraternity or sorority sponsoring some sort of fundraiser for cancer patients or for the St. Jude's Hospital. In my fraternity, each active or pledge is required to get a certain amount of community service hours each semester in order to stay in the house. So all in all, the Greek Life may get the bad rap for all of its crazy parties and the wild stories you hear, but if you care to take a deeper look at the system, you will be surprised at what you see.

The diversity at Kansas is unreal. After my first semester at the University of Kansas, I have seen and experienced things that I had never seen before. I came from a private high school in Wichita and so I lived a pretty sheltered life. But this diversity that I have experienced was not always bad. I became friends with students from China. I have been challenged in my beliefs and moral values and I enjoy a good argument. Finally, the University of Kansas has opened me up to more of what the world believes in and what the world expects of me.

Initial scholarships are really easy to apply for at KU; it's practically formulaic. You just punch in your ACT/SAT scores and GPA and you automatically qualify for a scholarship based on a tier system. They offer some really attractive renewable four year scholarship and just overhauled the system, enabling them to give more people money. Beyond that, it becomes a little confusing. The online system is a hassle to navigate and a single scholarship can be broken down into different chunks, making it appear like a different one. There are plenty of opportunities, you just have to go a little out of your way to find them.
KU is great at providing a healthy campus. There are campus police and security ready available. There are lights and emergency phones all throughout campus. I always feel safe walking home alone.

The drug scene at KU isn't very noticeable on campus. It really depends on the groups that a person hangs out with. I have a few different groups of friends. Most don't take part in drugs. There are a few cliques though that revolve around drug use, unfortunately.

KU overall is a very safe campus. If you use common sense (not walking alone in the middle of the night, keeping an eye on your surroundings) then you would be golden. There have been a few instances of campus crime (robbery more than anything) but you can always call the campus cops either from your cell phone or from one of the call boxes on campus. I have never felt in danger on campus.

Lawrence is a vibrant college town. There are things to do no matter what you like. Like clubbing? Mass St. is your place - there are a ton of good bars. Like cultural activities? There are group performances, holiday activities (like sugar skull decorating for Dia de los Muertos), exhibits, and more. While there aren't very many chain stores in Lawrence, the town boasts tons of local shops for everything from sports apparel to instruments to clothing.
It is very strict, but very necessary. I wouldn't change it.

The people in Lawrence Kansas are very friendly. I've yet to see any fight, and or any reason for the police in KU. If your studying all night and come out the library you find this crowd of helpful people that will assist you if needed to walk you home. There is a very secure and safe system setup at KU.
There really isn't anything on the school its self, but maybe stashed away in the dorms.

We have a well-kept gym. If you wanted to take a class most of all the classes are $3 a class. If you are a student you can get in for free. It is open pretty late on most days it closes at 10 pm. We have four libraries and they stay open till about 1 am but on finals week they stay open till 3 am. If you don't want to study in your room the library is the best alternative. In each of the library there are different places for group study and individual study.

If you are going to class the only option you really have is takeing the bus which is free if you are a student around campus. Those buses usually run from about 7am-9pm on M-thur. but stop at 6pm on friday but if you have to be somewhere and it is on a gameday it's best that you walk there the buses usually run REALLY slow.

I gave it University of Kansas an A is because it is really safe there. We have the SafeBus(buses) which runs from Thurs-sat. from 9pm-2am and SafeRide(sort of like a taxi company) which runs from 9pm-3am,which are both free get kids home safely after for example a party home.

Alcohol is far more visible than drugs at KU. I see and here very little about drugs. Alcohol is more prevalent and there are a number of bars around campus that many students go to. Overall I would say there is little pressure from peers and policies are enforced pretty strictly.

Off campus housing is very good. There are tons of fraternities and sororities for those interested in greak life. The price is a little higher but the friendships that are made can be well worth it. There are hundreds of houses made for college students. Many of these houses fit anywhere from 6-15 people and can be a lot of fun. Parking can be somewhat of a challenge as most parking lots don't hold as many as they should. The houses are very safe and overall I think off campus housing is a great idea.

Football at the University of Kansas has been terrible over the past few years, but people still really enjoy gamedays on Saturdays. The turnout at football games is average but not great. Basketball is huge at KU and everyone loves going to the game. There are many great traditions for athletics and KU is a fun place to be.

Computers are always available at the libraries, I typically bring my own laptop though. Wireless can sometimes be slow, but printing is great because they provide you with $8.00 which is hard to exceed.

There are several options for living off-campus. Apartments, houses, greek life houses. Call around and you can find several different prices and availability. I hear that the Connection and Legends can be pretty pricey, but they are both super nice. Just far from campus!
Variety of nightlife places to go! And safebuses are helpful, just not timely.
The university is fairly key on enforcing drug policies on campus.
There are plenty of available computers through the computer labs and the libraries. Connection might not always be optimal, but it is a rather large campus.

The dorms are not horrible, some in better conditions than others. There are plenty of nearby off-campus housing apartments in the area at affordable prices. The campus is on a hill though, so no matter where you are, you will eventually face walking a steep hill for classes.

At the University of Kansas, you are very challenged. The classes are hard and very large, especially the introduction to chemistry and biology classes. Be prepared to teach yourself several of the lessons. Studying is absolutely mandatory! There are plenty of resources to go to such as the learning centers and TAs available to you. Attending lecture is always a great way to maintain coherence of a subject. I am currently getting ready to apply to the Biology program. I still have one more pre-req to be completed before I can apply. The advisors are very helpful and I highly recommend seeing an advisor at least once a semester to keep you on track. My work load is always very full so I will only work on weekends once the Spring 2013 semester begins.

As a freshman, I lived in both GSP and Oliver. My first semester, I lived in GSP, the all girls dorm. It was a really great place. The girls were extremely friendly. However, since I have lived there, they have newly remodeled the dorm, so I'm sure it is even better! Oliver wasn't the best experience. The hot water wasn't always working, so I had to take cold showers sometimes in January and February. It was not fun.

Lawrence has a wide range of apartments and duplexes available to students! I found a duplex, that I share with three other people, and I only pay about $300 per month, and that is including utilities with cable and internet! Housing is very abundant in Lawrence and the city is still expanding!
There are numerous computers available throughout the campus. Locations include libraries and other on-campus buildings. Speed of the WIFI could improve.

For the most part the guys are pretty outgoing at the University of Kansas. There are a lot of fraternities, so sometimes they get a little overwhelming. The girls are really sweet too. Again, there are a lot of sororities so they too can get a little overwhelming sometimes. Altogether, very lovely atmosphere!
DO NOT STAY IN MCCOLLUM!!!!!!!!!!!! IT WAS THE WORST EXPERIENCE I HAVE EVER HAD!
I don't have a car, so I can't really tell you much. I heard that parking is expensive though.

The Lawrence and Med Center campuses provide great facilities for students. Everything is clean. Both campuses should focus on becoming more wheelchair accessible for all students to enjoy facilities.
Parking is expensive. I usually park on the street for free and walk to class.

The Lawrence and Med Center have lots of different organizations for any student to join. There's plenty of cultural events and activities in close proximity. The restaurants in Lawrence and KCK are delicious!

Kansas weather can be wild, so make sure you check the weather before you get dressed in the morning. This week started with temperatures in the 60s and now it's 20 degrees outside. I kind of love experiencing all the seasons, though. If you get too uncomfortable, just hop on a campus bus.
There are many computer labs on campus. All computers are equipped with a lot of fun and useful programs.
As it is a big University, there are a lot of people who do drugs. Thankfully, everyone is really cool, and if you refuse no one will pressure you into anything.
There are SO many yummy, cheap places to eat around campus. Mass Street especially has TONS of options which some are even open late after the bars close so you can get a cheap late night snack!
Everyone is really nice and there are many various groups in which you can easily find one that you click with.

The food is overall good. The dining hall on Daisy Hill is pretty hit or miss, but the Underground on campus is better! It can be pretty congested, and it could probably be better organized, along with better seating to accommodate more people.

All of the dining halls on campus offer something different. Mrs. E's is the mother of all dining halls. The Underground has good food. It has a lot of options including chic-fil-a. The union has a ton of options as well. If u don't branch out and try new things, it can get old. But if you keep it interesting you shouldn't have any problems.

I love the free bus system for all students that runs on campus and all throughout the city. The buses stay on schedule for the most part and the buses are nice. The buses start running early in the morning before classes and don't stop running till really late at night. There are even bus routes called Safe Ride that run till early in the morning for the partiers.
Tons of parties, bars, and things to do on mass street!
Cops dont care if you are drinking, just DONT HAVE ANY ON YOU. they will give you a minor in posession if you get caught with it outside of a party. other than that, its lenient.
Great environment, lots of fun and great place to grow
going to court for having 2 people over. "noise"
I don't feel as though drugs are a major problem at KU. But students are required to take an online alcohol EDU class and I think that policies on drugs and alcohol are definitely enforced.

I was undecided when first coming to KU. And I'm very glad that so many different majors are offered here. I got a lot of help from my counselor in choosing a major and looking at different programs. I am now on a path to do pre dentistry and am majoring in biology.

Food on campus at places like the Underground and the Studio are very good. However, the food at Mrs. E's is steadily sub par at best. The food is either over or undercooked, vegetables are not fresh and are soggy, and overall, food is just bland.

I am from Maryland and came all the way to Kansas simply because I am in love with the school. They have so many options of majors to choose from and the campus is gorgeous. People are so friendly and classes so far have been fun yet challenging.
There are many places to dine and they offer many discounts to KU students.
Financial Aid is decent I do recommend that they offer more scholarship programs for students.
It is your typical Kansas weather you just never really know!

Student life at KU is amazing. The facilities are great. The recreation center (the rec) is very nice and big and has everything you can think of to get a good workout in. The underground is a nice big cafe area where you can meet up with friends between classes or if it is nice out there is plenty of room to sit outside. Traditions at KU are so important. Especially if they have to do with basketball, KU is the birth place of basketball. Game days at KU are so much fun! Campus life is what makes KU feel like home.

There are a lot of different kinds of guys at KU. Even if you are picky about what kind of guys you like you can kind that at KU. There are guys from all over the country that come to KU. You have frat guys, athletes, nerdy guys, really funny ones. Most of them are really nice. Very attractive too.

Most of the professors are very good and helpful. They really try to help students and have available office hours you can attend. There are a lot of tutors you can get for many different subjects. There are a lot of libraries on campus to study in.

Lawrence is a great town! It may be small but there is so much to do. Mass street has many cute shops and restaurants. Facilities at KU are really nice. Sports life at KU are crazy! Allen Field house is the loudest gym in the country and games are so much fun to attend.
Being a nursing major at the University of Kansas is great! There is a pre-nursing group where you can meet other nursing majors.
Mass is a great place to hang out and there is plenty to do! You will never get bored with the amazing concerts of indie bands to local bands, and Kansas city isn't far either.
There are a variety of options for practically any type of food that you want!
Drugs are used by most students, though, it is not openly used.
Campus Housing can be very expensive, but is a great way to meet new people and to get involved!

Our dining options are pretty awesome. The dorms have places to each which are buffet style and the food is usually pretty good. There are a couple of coffee shops in the union as well as a little quick stop stop for random things. everything is decent priced. There is also a floor with different food options such as Pizza Hut and a sandwich shop in one of our buildings.
Everyone that I know who has lived in on eof the dorms has really enjoyed it. In fact, a few of them even became RAs so they could stay in the dorms!
I am a psychology student and I love it. I have awesome teachers who do their best to help and are always there to give extra help when needed.
It is just like any other town really. A number of fast food chains everywhere and some really good places like the Salty Iguana.

I have never had an experience with anybody using drugs here and neither has anyone I know, however, it is a college town so there is use here just like everywhere else. And you have to try and avoid some areas just to be save.
Very strict on certain issues like sexual harassment and drunken driving
No financial aid offered to international students
The community is very friendly especially to international students like myself
It's good but not as diverse and the nearby Kansas City night life.

There are loads of libraries, some even have specific reason. There's an engineering library, and a music library. There are lots of places to hang out, and many traditions that students can get involved in.

I absolutely love Lawrence. The town is just the right size to not get lost, but still have a lot of stuff to do. There are many restaurants and stores on Mass Street, there's a farmer's market, and the people are so friendly. I love it.

Parking on campus can quickly diminish because of the many people who live off campus. I use the Park and Ride. I park in a parking lot away from campus, and take a five minute bus ride to campus. It's cheaper, and there are always spots, no matter what time you get there.

I am a mathematics and computer science major. The engineering department is decent. There are some bad teachers/classes and little support when it comes to getting into the classes you need, but overall it isn't too bad. As for the Mathematics department, it is horrible for undergrads; very little help, involvement, and opportunities to get involved with your choice of major.

I'm in the School of Engineering and since day one I've felt the welcoming factor from being in the engineering program. It may not it the top of the list for some majors, but the professors still expect the top work. There are many challenges that the school has for standards of the students, but they are possible to be achieved with some hard work. It's college after all.

Lawrence is a medium urban town. There is always something to do whether it be going to the gym, being outside, seeing a concert, or hanging out. The people are nice and have the love for the university all throughout the town.

There are many healthy options on campus for those with specific needs. The campus has much variety, however there are not a bunch of dining halls around campus and stores in every building. The majority of them close pretty early, dining halls around 7-730 and some others around 5-530, so students have to make sure to eat before then because of the limited amount of time. Meal plans are good for the first year and if you are living in a dorm, however not necessary for the rest of your time at KU.
The school runs a shuttle service day and night and on the weekends. The schedule is easy to fllow and runs throughout the town of Lawrence. Plus, it is free to the students!!
The greeks are very involved in social events on the campus and add too the college experience.
There are a number of dining halls on campus. There is tremendous variety in food choices.
They are all new and work well, the printer system is great

The town isn't large, so using your own car can really waste time and bog down traffic. Public transportation is free for students, on campus it is exemplary and off campus is pretty manageable. There is also saferide and safebus for weekends and long nights.

Non-Greeks look down upon the Greeks and I'm sure it's vice versa. They seem more outlandish here than other colleges and are made fun of as "frat-tastic" and "sorostitutes" or "so-ho's" as they seem trashy and full of themselves. I'm sure there is a good networking built up and the social possibilities are probably beneficial if you can keep your partying under control.
Drugs aren't that big on campus. They also have an online course you have to take about Drug Safety. There are drugs present, but in small groups.

Dining halls are okay, ratings go: North College Cafe (GSP/Corbin), Mrs. E's (Daisy Hill), and Oliver Dining Hall (Oliver). Options are available each day and have quite a variety of items to choose from.

The classes are all unique and interesting. The Department of Architecture, Design, and Planning is very well-rounded and helps all of its students get ready for not only classes, but the future as well. Campus is large and has lots of clubs and organizations to be a part of. Great school.

If it's basketball......all out A+
Other sports, not so much. but still supported pretty well.

Our campus is very diverse. We have many different religions as well as races. They definitely comprise a good percentage of the student body. However, they do not intermingle very much. Many of the ethnic or religious groups band together.

There are a lot of options for off campus housing that are close to campus. However, many of the options are expensive. Greek is probably the way to go when it comes to off campus housing. These are the most affordable living arrangements, as well as close to campus.
The food is good, but very repetitive. A greater variety and healthier choices would really be better.
I am getting my degree in psychology and then I plan on going to nursing school. I love the path i am taking and I'm really excited to go to KU nursing school.

Kansas weather is crazy. It changes a lot and can be totally random. When its nice its really nice but when its nasty it's really nasty. Most of the time the weather is pretty nice but it can be really windy, most of the time.

The process of getting in to the Psych program is fairly easy. You only have to take a few pre-requisit classes to apply and have a decent GPA. IT doesn't take that much time, and all the classes are really interesting.
So far right now its only rained. But the school does offer buses for people that would have to walk a long way to their classes.

Nice college town. The local residents and business owners treat students very well. It's definitely a college sports town. The KU Jawhawks are tops in this town and supported throughout the US, and are even well known abroad, not just in Lawrence or Kansas. It's a safe and nice place to live, work and go to school. Many of my friends live here!

I'm an English Major and I'm very pleased with my education thus far. The workload in all of the classes is fair. I enjoy the professor/student interactive teaching style that my instructors use. The curriculum is kept current with the changes and the facilites are well maintained and anesthetically pleasing to the eye. Internship/job opportunities are readily available for just about anything one might be interested it. They do make it possible for a student to get hands on learning in a job setting.

The KU Police are very visable and available to provide escorts for students back to their dorms when unable to park in their cars in dorm lots and must park on the street. They're always available to provide assistance to the needs of the students. They're are cameras which are on and watched by KU Police dispatchers. They also provide a good response time when called.

I love the psychology department and the applied behavioral science department. Between the advisors and the professors, you can get help and/or answers quickly and efficiently without feeling like you are bothering someone or taking up too much of their time. They want to help and you can feel it.

plenty of buses going in every direction. Off campus parking is cheaper and the buses are clean and friendly, on-time and abundant. Whether needing to go to WalMart or just to the other end of Jayhawk, it is awesome!

A lot of fun people and professors. Many opportunities to help with research in a wide variety of areas. The psychology advisor is a wonderful person who is always willing to take time with you to answer even the smallest questions with a smile.

Most of the professors are super great and love the subject they are teaching and love the art of teaching. Most professors want their students to learn and do well and succeed. Occasionally, a grad student gets stuck in and is not quite up to par, but, I suppose everyone starts somewhere. Sometimes, I wish we got a tuition break while they break in the newbies though.

The anthropology department is incredible. By its very nature, the department is interdisciplinary and inclusive of objective and subjective methodologies. Such a variety of interesting courses and influential worldviews presented over the course of each semester.
Tons of music venues and art locales. The bus shuttle system provides a 'Safe-ride" transportive route to help move the populace about safely on drunken evenings.

There are a variety of places to grab meals on campus, usually each library and student union has a place to purchase food. However, it is difficult to find a spot on campus to feed yourself after 6pm unless you are willing to settle for the gas station menu equivalent. Not very many vegaitarian options.
Lawrence is a diamond in the rough when it comes to kansas. In the non-diverse sea that is kansas lawrence is a pocket filled with diversity. The community is extremely accepting of everyone.
Lawrence is a lot of fun, there's always stuff to do, great concerts, good food and nice people. Also there's no traffic and its a safe place as well.

There are numerous types of resturants. We have good ole American, Thai food, Chinese, Mexican, Indian etc. We have the fast food resturants that everyone loves. And we are not too far from Kansas City and Topeka where the options are more plentiful.
Just like any school, the diversity is everywhere. We have all different types of men and women. From different countries, different races, different religions, and different sexualities.
There are houses/apartments all over Lawrence. That the students can live in for relatively cheap. And have great transportation to the university.
The compter labs are easy to use. However they are slow and million of people always on them so hard to get a turn on them.

the social life at KU is hard due to so many people are in there own world and really not open to new poeple. It super hard to make friends when you are the quit one and have a large class and so many people around that have there own groups. it sad
Many places for a mix of talents, sexual preferences (LGBT), student groups regarding religion, advocacy and ally groups for mental health and physical disabilities.

In the world of acadamia, any program or policy that is not conducive to a learning environment is stamped out by administration. However there is a lot of choices about what is considered learning. There really is no Taboo subjects.
In passing I have heard conversations about class size and instructor availability that may have adverse effects on a students grades.

There is an amazing variety of restaurants on our downtown strip (Mass. Street) and since it's a college town they're very affordable. You'll always find coupons and deals as a student for off-campus food.

This is a college town so finding a sublease or an apartment is going to be easy but not necessarily cheap on your budget. Find housing and get it set up as soon as possible or you might miss out on some major deals.

Bars are all over town, and to be honest you don't have to be 21, it's beyond easy to get into a bar with a fake. That said I know students who've gotten in trouble and if you go in and talk with people they will lower the charges. With quite the student ghetto house parties are abundant.
There are a lot of options for all different kinds of preferences.
The drug prevelance at the University of Kansas is apparent if you seek it out; however it is not something you would encounter on a daily or even weekly basis if you avoid it.

The drug scene at KU is mostly smoking. I have never seen elicit drug use. I think that alcohol use is more prevalent here, but not mainly on campus. If you go off campus into the restaurants and pubs and such you will see more alcohol use then drug use. In fact I am not bothered by the drug scene here at all. As far as peer pressure goes, I have never been asked to use any drugs.

The work load seems to fit a graduate program. In fact I was pleased with everything. The only reason that I am giving an A- score is because I applied to the graduate program from my home in Idaho Falls Idaho. I found out that i got accepted into the program only three weeks before orientation was. That was a short time for me to apply for student loans, find housing, pack my whole family up and move all the way to Kansas. It was really stressful and my wife and I wished that we had had more time.

As a grad student in the business school, I expect the work load to be advanced, which it is. The program is uniquely organized two build on the experiences I have already accumulated in the workforce. The courses that I am enrolled in are testing my knowledge, and strengthening experiences with knowledge and theoretic knowledge that teach how to make the best of everyday circumstances, and lead effectively. This program has a great following, so internships are are almost limitless. The facilities are specifically designed to meet the needs of my peers and self. Just recently we traveled to Ashland Kansas to practice business consulting. This is great because it is putting me in a real world setting with real situations that I would be dealing with in my job after I graduate. I am pleased that I got into this MBA program and I am looking forward to next semester.

There are computer labs all over the place, sometimes you just have to look for them. The computers and network speed are tip top. There are quick-printing locations in all the libraries on campus for your quick-use needs. There is great wi-fi service if you bring your laptop to school. If you don't have your own laptop or forget yours, you can rent one from Anchutz library!

I came to KU to pursue the Environmental Studies program, it is one of the oldest in the nation! KU also has a great architecture program, many of my friends are in it. If you live in Missouri and want to pursue architecture, you can get in-state tuition!

Corbin = Sorority Girls

GSP = Sorority Girls/Weed Smoking Guys...it's a weird mix

Hashinger = Pot Dorm

If you aren't in a sorority or fraternity, your social life at KU is pretty limited your freshman year. If you are not greek, the greeks will not talk to you or treat you as an "equal." Try to join other clubs and organizations to meet more people that are not a part of the Greek system.

It's so hard to get into the Education Program at KU. They are way too picky and don't accept people that they should. They look for GPA which is strange, they should look for experience. The process is normal. Just try hard and have a good GPA.

I am relatively happy with the Education Program. I want to teach kindergarten, but I dislike how picky they are about the applicants for the program. I am concerned I won't get it, because they are so picky about who they take. I feel like you don't need the best GPA to be a teacher. I have had teacher's that barely made it in college and they were the best teachers I have ever had. I have also had teacher's that had straight A's at private schools and they were the worse teachers I have ever had. It goes both ways and it's unfair to take someone because they had a rough semester.

I will be student teaching in a few years, which will be an internship. We are unpaid, but we put a lot of time and effort into making lesson plans for the week. It's a lot of work, but it's completely worth it.

I believe that KU well prepares students for life after their degree. My major in the Biological Sciences has a pretty heavy workload, but it is manageable with the right skills that will be needed for Medical School. The facilities are above average and many opportunities are available.

The prices are very high for places off campus but within walking distance, and you don't receive a good quality for the price you would pay. Most apartments close to campus are unfurnished, adding extra expenses, and those farther away lose the luxury of closeness. However, there are many options for off-campus living and apartment communities are safe and convenient, most with bus routes that regularly go to campus.

Most classes are very large, and registering for classes for the first time can be very stressful. However, there are many libraries with various hours, and one is open all night most nights of the week. The AAAC offers tutoring opportunities and the quality of the classes is admirable.

There is a wide variety of people on campus from international students to people from all over the US. I've met people with widely different beliefs, orientations, and economic backgrounds, and overall people here are very tolerant of differences.

Get it done as soon as possible, don't dilly dally at all or you could be missing out on scholarship money. My parents wouldn't get their tax information for the FASFA to me in time and it really cost me alot.
I'd say it's about average for a Midwest college. Most people are white and the rest are a minority but I haven't seen much intolerance of any ethnicity.
KU sits on a large hill which can make it treacherous when it snows. But there is a very good bus route all around town if you have to walk a ways.
pledge life is like so awesome. we all have our own houses in our own little community
Not enough student parking. We have less parking but we seem to keep expanding in the buildings.
My school does a wonderful job of getting minorities to join research programs by allowing them many options

One second it would be hot and sunny, the next it's windy, cold and rainy. The weather is really bi-polar and it doesn't help that the campus is on top of Mt. Oread. When the weather is nice, almost everyone is outside.

The computer labs at KU are all very up-to-date and useful. They recently just updated their wi-fi services so if you have a laptop and are a student, you get free unlimited wi-fi on campus! Even if you didn't have a laptop, there's so many available computers around campus that would be easy to find.

There are a lot of places to go. Dining halls within the dorms, the Union, or the Underground. The dining halls are just what you would expect - cafeteria food. Some of the meals are excellent, but some are below average. The union has a small variety of food and there are daily deals to save your money. The Underground has great food, even a Chick-fil-A, but is usually pretty busy.

Above Average – Everything is within walking distance, so getting a good parking spot isn't really a big deal. There are plenty of lots around campus, and the permit system is very good. My only complaint with parking is the high price, but what can you expect from a University? All they want is your money.

Not a Big Deal – Nobody really cares if you're involved in Greek life or not. There's so much diversity at KU that everyone fits into their own mold and nobody really judges anybody else based on their activities and involvements. The frat parties are entertaining and anyone can go, but nobody cares if you're not actually Greek.
Pretty Strict – I don't believe that there's much tolerance for underage drinking or drugs.
Everything is pretty straight forward and the teachers are helpful.
It's a pleasant campus, couldn't ask for much more. Parking sometimes sucks, but other than that, A+

University of Kansas is nationally ranked in a ton of programs. Here you can study to be an astronaut, take courses in pre med, or even be a psychiatrist. Your dreams start here, tradition lives here.

A Variety Is Key to Sucess – KU has everything. A Variety of cultures from all over the world and it just doesn't stop there. A very opinionated school has gays, and lesbians and anything else you can think of! KU is just a place to feel at home.

Parking on campus is somewhat not needed with the bus routes that continuously move around the campus. Every building is in a nice walking distance from each other, and the campus is too beautiful to drive around anyway (:

Absolutley Amazing Bus Drivers! The bus drivers here at KU are amazing at getting you to where you need to go on time, and if you accidentally miss the bus and are crunched for time, there is always a bus right behind that one ready to pick you up. The bus routes are easy to read, and guess what. It's absolutely FREE to ride any bus with your KU ID.

Process Went Pretty Good. Tips are starting fast because KU offers so much, and deadlines are quick and they give out to the quickest. KU Is a very great school to attend with a beautiful campus and very great people.
All You Can Eat – Seriously all you can eat. Everywhere around town from the newer parts to Mass street--there are TONS of options and ethnicities to choose from. Tiny mom & pop shops to chains

Fun for All – Nightlife at KU is awesome. On campus is dry, but if you go to the greek houses for house parties or down to Mass street, you'll have a ton of fun. Try the Oread hotel--a few different bars in there are fun. Sandbar is best for goofy fun.
KU is a very seemingly safe campus. I haven't had any issues, ever, nor have I felt scared to walk alone even at midnight

Variety on Mass. Massachusetts Street in Lawrence, Kansas is undeniably the town hot-spot. It offers various restaurants, bakeries, and dessert shops that can fit most dietary needs. Vegan and vegetarian options are easy to find. With Brazilian, Thai, Vietnamese, Indian and Greek menus, the wide variety of eateries can suit any mood.

Greeks are known to party. But I've noticed the Greeks at KU do a lot of community service projects as well. The white, black, and Latino organizations also work together. It's not as hokey as you are in the movies.

You Name It, You'll See It – Yes, the state of Kansas is predominantly white. However, Lawrence is one of those pocketed areas with ethnic, religious, and political diversity. I have seen and heard from several ethnic and religious cultures from around the world, both on and off campus. And there are many interest groups on campus devoted to ethnic diversity. I join them to learn about different customs, make new friends, and eat good food! Not only does it enhance my education, but I'm learning to be a world citizen. No matter when I go after college, I'll have been exposed to people from places all over the world - right here in Kansas!

Eclectic and Close to KC – Lawrence is growing bigger and offers a variety of things to do, both on and off campus. They residents are are friendly and welcoming. Kansas City is a much larger city about 30 minutes away. Both the Kansas and Missouri sides of KC offer fun, food, and friendliness. That's a the closest airport, train station, and they have MegaBus as well. I feel safe in Lawrence and for the most part of KC. I also think they are both great places to live after graduation and if you want to raise a family.

School of Social Welfare – I feel I'm getting the best education in my area. In fact, the school ranks 9th in the nation for social work! I get a generalist education, and I can then choose a clinical or administrative path in the last part of my curriculum. You can go for one year in the master's program, provided your bachelor's degree is in social work. Or if you're changing careers, like I am, you can go part-time...up to four years! Again, everyone is there to help you succeed. The grad assistants are wonderful and the professors are awesome to get to know, answer questions, give advice, and encourage and motivate. There are offering in Lawrence, Kansas City, and Overland Park. And if you live in the KC metro area on the Missouri side, you may qualify for a discount on tuition, which helped me tremendously.

Something for Everyone – Not only does KU have the majors, departments, and degree offerings that most colleges have, they also have some unique minors and certification programs to enhance your degree. There are almost a hundred class offerings that I was amazed they could offer credit for (ethnic studies, cultural types, religious ideology.) They also offer a general studies degree so if you're truly undecided, you can dabble in just about everything and still walk away with a degree. The professors know their subjects, and they are approachable. They also have great study tips and tutoring help, should you need it. It seems like everyone is wanting you to graduate and succeed, and they will help you along he way - which is rare that a 4-year university as large as KU can do!

There's Lots of Variety – There are several dining halls on campus. In the student union, there are several popular chain fast food options. And in town, not far from campus, there are lots of places, local, regionally, and nationally known, that serve a variety of ethnic and alternative-diet meals. There's something for everyone!

Extreme Craziness – Summers are normally hot, but this summer was brutal! Winters can be really cold and windy with some snow, but mainly ice. Fall and spring are pretty; however, they can get a bad storm popping up and tornado warnings at any time.

These Buses Go EVERYWHERE – The University of Kansas has a bus system that seems to span the entirety of Lawrence. All buses that go from dorms to the actually Halls circulate about every 6 minutes! This is good news because that means if you miss your bus another one should be right behind it! The buses also go down to the downtown or across town to the out of campus apartments. At night the "SafeBus" starts up and gets people safely around to where they need to be in order to avoid drinking and driving or walking home alone in the dark. There is also a "SafeRide" which will come pick you up like a free taxi cab during the night to avoid the same dangers.

Why Is Everyone So Good-Looking?? Pretty much everywhere you turn here on the University of Kansas Campus there is going to be someone attractive. It seems like all the girls are pretty, and all in different ways. Here we have the artsy types, the athletic types, the sorority types, the modest types, the nerdy types, any sort of girl you can think of is here and she is 8 times out of 10 going to be gorgeous, which can be a little disheartening sometimes. As for the guys, they range from average to way above average and also cover the whole spectrum of nerdy to frat to athletic and beyond!

They Mean It When They Say, "You Belong Here&quot – The University of Kansas postcard that many potential students receive says, "you belong here", and they definitely aren't kidding! There are so many different things to study, places to go, and people to hang out with that no matter who you are you really CAN feel like you belong. The town is great, the campus is beautiful, the classes are insightful, and there is so much to do!
In every single class I have ever been in there is a pretty even amount of each race, religion, sexual orientation, etc.

There has never been a time where I have been walking around campus and felt unsafe for any reason. Campus police are really nice and the campus has services available to pick you up from lets say the library late at night and drive you home so you don't have to walk in the dark.
Above and Beyond – The school actually created an office (Office of Multicultural Affairs) to lead the way in school diversity. They have done a great job

Find Your Own Way – So I'm one of those people that like EVERYTHING, thus choosing one thing to major in was extremely difficult. While the university does do a good job of guiding you along your chosen major, and even being actively involved with you in SOME majors, they dont do a great job of helping you choose A major. People in the undecided field feel like their being pressured into finding a major and when I was semi-undecided, they encouraged me to drop different classes and stay on the career track because "I might like it in the end". Bottom line, I had to go to a completely different school over the summer to figure our what I wanted to do.

The Liberal Experience – Kansas has been notorious for being a conservative state, but once you step onto the Lawrence campus, you seem to be entering almost a whole new world. The social scene is always live, and if your not careful you will start to live for the parties, which can get out of hand sometimes. Lawrence caters to every personality type: the nerds have quid-ditch, the jocks of course have state of the art training facilities, artsy people have Spencer Art Museum and their creations displayed around the city, etc. The academics: the professors really want you to visit during office hours, they try to make jokes and have class seem lively and fun instead of a chore

The Old and the New – I love how my school has all these new and entertaining things going on in the new/ renovated building, but step in one of the older building and it feels as if you were transported way back in time. Especially in the dorms. Those should have been renovated first because you can tell some were built in the fifties.

Lawrence: the Ideal College Town – The title says it all. With so many unique local restaurants, cool places to shop, fun hang-outs, and active bars/clubs... Lawrence is exactly where you want to live as a college student! Be sure to check out the Java Break off Mass Street if you like coffee, or Abe & Jake's for a hopping nightlife. Really, Lawrence offers something to everybody.

Avoid the "Student Ghetto"! In southeast Lawrence, there is a moderate span of apartments and rental houses known as the "student ghetto" - sure, they're cheap, but be prepared to deal with bad plumbing, absent landlords, and zero deposit returns! It's worth it to splurge on a nicer place like The Reserve, The Legends, or Campus Court. The Park & Ride is a fantastic system, so if you want to live further away from campus, that's also a good option to look into.
Here Is Like Melting Pot. So many international students are in Lawrence. and Many organization really support them. I like it

Bus System Is Very Good – Bus system is very good. It is free for KU student.
and even It run break time.
Hot & Cold – Kansas weather is always unpredictable. It pretty much gets really cold in the winter and really hot in the summer. Fall and spring are nice!

Ease and Affordability – I have lived off campus now for two years at two different locations. My first place was a little farther from campus, but it was still only about an 8 minute drive. It was very easy to get an apartment there. They have many amenities and it was very nice. Most complexs off campus have a bus route that goes directly to campus and it is free for students. The cost was affordable, but not the cheapest there is.

Little Big Town – Lawrence has all the ingredients of a big city. Attractions, interesting hot spots, concerts, venues, diversity, and people. All of that is wrapped up in a city that is not too huge. It's perfect. There is always something to do either with the university or outside it. There are concerts going almost every day. The downtown (aka Mass. street) is a great place to be. It has great food, live entertainment, and good people. Musicians play in the street and after a big game, it is definitely the place to be.

Computer Availablity – They have a ton of computers in both libraries, and have printers. You get $8 worth of printing at the beginning of each semester. ($0.8 per page). You can also rent laptops if needed. Most every student has thier own laptop and they have wireless everywhere on campus.

KU basically only has on campus housing for freshman. There is one set of apartments for upperclassmen but are expremely hard to get into because it houses mostly athletes. There are close to campus apartments which are nice but also kind of hard to get into. Have to apply really early. Living on Daisy Hill as a freshman is the best option because most live there, and it is social. Most upperclassmen live in houses that are close to campus
School Spirit – KU has insane amounts of school spirit! Everyone in Lawrence is always wearing KU stuff, and the basketball games are a HUGE deal and so much fun.

Exercise Science Program – This program has good professors and smaller classes which is nice. They also have a ton of labs and studies that you can participate in and volunteer for which is good to put on a resume for graduate school (PA, PT, etc). Emphasis on the sciences which are hard but managable. You have one semester that is purely an internship which is nice.

Frat Guys – KU is big on greek life and a lot of the boys you meet out are in a fraternity. Some are very nice but when they are together they aften act too cool or like tools. But I have met plenty of friendly ones.

Registration Process – If you know exactly what major you want to get into then it is pretty simple to get into the classes you need for that major. However, if you are undcided, as I am, the advisors have not been the best at helping with what classes to for sure take. Also classes fill up fast and are hard to get into after they are full.

Parking on campus is expensive and often hard to find. Parking passes run around $250 for a year, which to me is way too high to be worth it. Students can park at the expensive parking garage or at the Rec center, which is at the bottom of a steep hill. I prefer to walk or take the bus system... a much better (and cheaper) option!

The Eaton Computer Lab Is the Best – Being an engineer, I am always around Eaton and Learned. It is by far the best computer lab on campus. The computers are almost always open, there are at least a hundred in there. They are fast, the printing is free there, and someone is always at the front desk to answer questions, should you have any.
The fall and spring are absolutely amazing on campus, especially on sunny days. But during the winter, it can get pretty bad. Snow storms and freezing cold weather with no snow happens a lot.
It's There, but Not as Popular – Most sorority girls are big in to drugs, but you don't really see much of it or hear much about it. It's more about the parties at KU

Still New – All I can go off of is the advising I have received over the last 7 months with regard to the Social Welfare Program requirements. Everyone has been great and I officially started the program in 3 weeeks.
My Program Is Ranked #1 in Region – KU has a long history of being a prestigious university with very knowledgable staff.

The Shuttle Buses Are a Nice Touch. I think it is a wonderful benefit to KU students to have the ability to ride a shuttle bus to and from campus. Students can avoid having to pay for expensive parking passes and the buses go throughout town.
Be sure not to over eat! The freshman fifteen is a real thing! Watch out for the buffet, because it IS extremely good! Get a respectable meal plan.
