A Joy. Get involved. Meeting friends is so much easier if you live on campus. Also much more convenient than living at home if you plan on doing better in the class room.

Extremely Disappointed!!!!! I maintained a 4.2 GPA throughout high school at a very prestigeous and difficult Johnson County High School. Numerous Universities offered me as much as 32k a year. I was very involved in athletics and clubs throughout high school. Kansas University did not offer me a single grant or scholarship. . . I have applied for every possible scholarship. I intend to major in Special Education and there just aren't any scholarships availiable for hard working, driven students who strive for excellence. .
Parking Tickets – I don't agree with how often parking tickets are dished out. . I think our campus police should spend more time cracking down on drug abuse than on parking infractions.
Immense Diversity – The ethnicities, as well as, interests on campus vary widely. I enjoy the amount of choices I have in which friends to choose from.
Good Looking People – You will find that there are quite a few good looking women on campus and around town. The majority of them are smart and are looking for someone with goals.

Very Good – I have never had any issues with safety on campus nor have I heard of anything going on either. With that being said, the best thing for anyone on a college campus is to take preventative measure themselves.

Parking permits are oversold and hourly parking is high. It is possible to use the bus system for most people or park and ride from a remote location. Students do lots of walking, but it is pleasant most of the time.
Most Diverse Spot in the State – Due to the university and it's reputation, I see a more diverse group of people than any other place in the state.
No Major Problems – Any questions or issues I have had have been explained and addressed easily.
Helpful and Resourceful – The professors help you in class and if you are friendly with them they will give you opportunities around campus/town to do something related to your major.

Drugs and Alcohol Sort of Hand in Hand – Alcohol is definitely more favored compared to drugs but with alcohol there is always a drug to follow along if wanted. Marijuana is pretty popular along with drinking.

Attractive and Engaging – Both genders are very attractive and all of them have different interests and personalities. There are definitely many social groups and interests out there. There is pretty much always going to be someone out here that will match a person's taste.

Don't Come Here If You Want to Study – I am in the process of transferring away from KU. I immediately got involved in the greek system. Even though there is only like a small actual percentage of people that get involved in greek life is small, there presence is very loud.
Ok but Repetitive – Eating small variations of the same thing every day just gets kinda boring after a while. And all of the dining halls have pretty much the same food.

Basketball Rules All – The football games in the fall are fun to go to and hang out with your friends. But the basketball at KU is just on a different level. College students have to "camp" out early just so they can get seats in Allen Fieldhouse. The basketball games at KU are something that you don't want to miss
Accessible Locations – Although the University of Kansas is a huge school, the campus is not too overwhelming large. Jayhawk blvd is where pretty much every thing stems from.
Incoming Freshmen Have It Best – Incoming freshmen have plenty of scholarships available, but if you want to study Political Science or International Studies, good luck.

Tons of Fun, but Be Smart – There are plenty of places for people to go all throughout the week, but you really have to be careful around big weekends because the cops are always on the prowl looking for stupid minors to arrest and give tickets to. If you hear "ABC" by the Jackson 5 in any bar, GET OUT.
Hashinger is definitely my favorite dorm on campus.
The parking fee is expensive and there is never any parking spots available. On top of that, the tickets are expensive as well.

About 90% of the Students Already Have Jobs Before Graduation – In the business school at the University of Kansas, they provide many career days. On these days students of all grades are able to go and meet the many business owners that come. Through these days students can earn internships and learn more about the companies. After a student has interened for the business and the business is happy with their work, many students already have jobs while they are still finishing their degrees.

KU promotes studying abroad and has one of the top ranked study abroad programs in the country. So, with that we also have a good amount of international students. Most students seem very accepting of all ethnicities, economic backgrounds, political beliefsm religions, and sexual orientations.
KU makes it a priority to make all students feel comfortable. All the buildings are very welcoming and I've never had a problem with any of the on-campus facilities.

Average Strictness – KU has a great balance with their policies and rules. They don't just jump to harsh, unrealistic rules, but recognize the normal life of a college student and just focus on providing safety to what college students inevitably will do. Academically, most the teachers are understanding and will tell you ahead of time their expectations. Socially, they provide resources to go to if you get in a bad situation, that will ultimately protect you, as well as promoting awareness of problems with taking part in risky situations.
OK Choices Around Campus – The places around campus are mediocre. I was hoping for more options that were healthier and cheaper.
Drug Use is forbidden on Campus at all times. The school views this as crucial matter that they're always focused on every semester.
Best Places – I think the best place to get food is in the 'Market' at the Kansas Union center.
It's hard to find open dining at night. For students that have night classes, the'll have to carry a little snack for class.

Need for a Car on Campus – To tell you the truth, you don't really need a car on campus. The school offers free buses to the students. They go all over the city. I normally leave my car at my apartment.
You never know the weather so you just have to deal
The off campus housing is close but far. If you drive your car its only 10-15 minutes away but if you ride the buses the university provides it takes almost 45 minutes.

Plenty to Do – Downtown is littered with bars and clubs, so much so that Lawrence has been rated one of the top-rated college towns in the country. Many clubs, such as Abe and Jake's, are even 18 and up. Tennessee St. features some of the biggest house parties in the state. The Kansas Union features free cosmic bowling every weeknight, and there's plenty of non-alcoholic fun venues to visit, like the Cupcakery, Sylas and Maddie's ice cream, the movie theater, or concert venues like the Granada or the Bottleneck.

IT Provides Campuswide Enterprise Technology – The computer labs in libraries and buildings are constantly receiving upgrades: nearly all computers are running either Windows 7 or OS X Lion. The campus is undergoing a huge transition to seamless wireless coverage, that is your connection will not be interrupted between buildings or even outside at campus parks.

KU oversells all permits, so it's first come first serve (first come being an hour or hour and a half before class or work). The parking department is also a separately funded entity from the University, and is unforgiving with their citations, and oftentimes incorrect.

Prevalence of Drugs – Nearly everybody drinks some at my school, but probably half of the student population engages in marijuana consumption, LSD, or some other drug like Adderall, Xanax, or salvia. The problem is mainly combatted by negative reception on the students' part.

Excellent Faculty and Students – The Classics department at KU is small but close-knit. It's a very supportive environment that at the same time does not sacrifice professionalism or academic standards. The faculty members are all easily accessible, the classroom environment inviting. No complaints here.

Gtaships Easily Accessible – Though I myself never worked as a TA in the department (I already was employed by a private school), most of my confreres did. Almost all taught their own section of a Greek, Latin, or myth class; one girl I knew assisted a professor with a 500-level History of Greek and Roman Architecture course. All the students I spoke with were very happy with their financial packages, which included tuition waver and a generous stipend.

Wonderfully Helpful Faculty – When I was going through the process of applying to KU's Classics MA program, I was 20 years old and somewhat daunted at the prospect. Having come from a tiny Liberal Arts college, I expected a much more difficult experience this time around. However, I was pleasantly surprised at how straightforward the procedure. The program's graduate adviser assisted me every step of the way, even offering to contact administration for me in one instance. It was all smooth sailing.

Diverse and Friendly – Lawrence, Kansas combines the best elements of small-town friendliness and urban accessibility. Within forty-five minutes from Kansas City, Lawrence offers proximity to a thriving arts scene while maintaining the convenience and ease of some of the best shops and restaurants right in the city itself. The locals are friendly, environmentally conscious, and probably connected in some way to KU. Two thumbs up here.

The University of Kansas provides multiple pathways to get to campus. For long-distance transportation there is a bus system that you can use to commute from counties nearby (Johnson County, Olathe, Shawnee). It does have a fare but much cheaper than driving and still gives you the convenience of a direct route from home to school. Local transportation to campus is very cost effective and convenience. On campus buses are free and often go outside of campus with no cost. All buses include bike racks for those who use multiple forms of transportation to commute. There are also local and long-distance park and ride stations where you leave your car in parking lot and you ride the bus to campus. There is a fee associated with that service.

What You'd Expect – For a so-called "liberal" university that has the highest tuition in Kansas, the diversity is what you might expect: there at surface-level- and perhaps deeper- but still of a certain rather "posh" flavor. As long as you don't investigate too deeply, it looks pretty good.
There Are a Lot of Grants – There are plenty of grants for those who need them, less for those that have great grades :(
I think KU is very reasonable. The parking tickets however are kinda ridiculous! Even on spring break when there are no buses running, you still can't park on campus to get to any meetings.

Quick Service – I haven't eaten in many dining halls. But i hear they are just OK. But they also have food courts that I eat in and those are pretty great and they have a nice variety. they are located in the heart of campus and in little corners everywhere

Its a D- for Drunk and Failing to Become Viably Intoxicated With a Purpose. pubpc08@yahoo.com

I would say that becoming intoxicated on or off the campus of the University of Kansas isn't; ADULT. It's more... identity related or

B+ for Business Administration Is Like an a+ Without the a If You Are Crazy. pubpc08@yahoo.com

It just isn't real to receive an B+ for a Bachelors; people begin to hum; however it's better than a C which is moderate. But a B+? doesn't that

I Guess B+ Is for Business With the a Removed and the + Attached to the B.! UMPH. pubpc08@yahoo.com

I can literally tell you a B in any course is tough; a C grade you know you are moderate but a B? Definitely, losing or pronounced idiot. I am content with my career planning at the University of Kansas; I, intend to study abroad or take a few at other Universities before returning to KU-Lawrence.
One of the reasons I picked KU was because it was diverse. There are many different types of races, religions, interests, and majors. Every person you meet is different in some way.
Good Food and a Variety – The dining halls all have similar menus. They all have a variety though and many things to choose from.

Campus Life Is Fun, Gives Great New Experiences, and Is Safe. The campus is a great environment. It is not only fun but safe too. There are many things to do and great people to meet. There is a variety of things to do from going to sporting events which has always been fun to do at The University of Kansas, especially basketball and going to a museum or just hanging out outside with friends.

Maintain a Safe and Fair Environment for the Students – The strictness makes campus safe but it is also still fun hanging out on campus because the rules and regulations and what people expect from the students is fair.
Our campus facilities are the best! I love all of the opportunities and surprises that us, the students, are treated to on a daily basis
There is a lot of food to eat, however, what makes the experience better is the option to dine out of the dining halls with an optional package that allows you to go to restaurants too.

I have visited many colleges throught the program Kauffman Scholars and have visited the campus on other occassions prior. I would rate the dorms as okay because they serve their purpose but are not, to say, state of the art praise worthy.

Eager for You to Learn – Professors repeat again and again that they have office hours and are always available for questions and assistance. The few times I actually visited office hours the professor was actually pleased to have someone there asking questions and wanting to understand the material. Most professors also have TA's if you feel weird about talking to your actual professor.

The one complaint I have about KU is parking. Students pay a lot of money in "campus fees" but aren't allowed free parking anywhere on campus. Parking passes can be up in the $300 per semester. There are red, gold, yellow, green, and blue spots that all have different required passes. And the busses that are included in our campus fees and are therefore free to ride are unreliable and slow. It takes over an hour to get to my apartment off campus which is a 5 minute drive. There are times that I was late because one of the busses was broken down (and with no notification system) I had no idea and stood there for an hour waiting for a bus that never came. With all the money students pay to go to KU they should offer free parking SOMEWHERE on campus, and put up-close parking as parking pass only.

Clean and Safe – All of the buildings on campus are clean and up-to-date with the most recent technology. The libraries have plenty of space and computers available for demand. The tables at the library come equipped with power strips and WiFi for laptops.

You Always Have Help – The Accounting Program at the Business School is a really great environment for all students interested in it. The professors are usually around until you graduate and some of the professors you have as an undergrad turn out to be important stepping stones to the CPA exam. There are so many resources available for internships, career opportunities, practice CPA exams, and tutorial courses. There is a larger workload but that is only because they want you to be prepared for the CPA exam and your future ahead.

Mechanical Engineering is a very difficult major, but not impossible. The workload is large, but manageable. The curriculum is relevant and the facilities are state of the art. Mechanical Engineers are in high demand so finding an internship is not too difficult.

Basketball, Need I Say More? Kansas has the best and most historic basketball program in the entire country. They are ranked in the top 10 every year and in the recent years Kansas has won the national championship (2008) as well as making it to the national championship again in 2012 before losing to Kentucky.
Depending on major/discipline the academics can be as challenging as you want them to be. If you choose easy classes, they won't be very difficult and vice versa if you choose difficult classes.
The cafeteria is similar to most large school campuses, it will fill you but will not be a very healthy or enjoyable meal compared to some good old home cooking.

Not Too Many Minorities – In all of the visits to KU before I enrolled there the people always said that KU was extremely diverse and I believe that they aimed this statement for the white kids. Coming from the city, my high school was EXTREMELY diverse, white people were the minority. The information given about KU was very misleading for me because I do not see many people who look like me or who I can share cultural similarities with. If you're looking for true diversity, I wouldn't suggest KU.

Stay Away from Abe & Jake's! I had to learn the hard way to stay away from Abe & Jake's. This is the only 18 and older club that I know of in town and when they say older, they mean OLDER! The creepiest thing about Abe & Jake's is that there are old nasty men always trying to pick you up. I suggest never going there. I have found that I have more fun relaxing with my friends and staying in on the weekends.

Mccollum Hall Is the BEST – I lived in McCollum hall my freshman year and plan to live there again my sophomore year. The hall is the most diverse which is why its called the International Hall and you really get to know people of different backgrounds. This is great for people interested in International or Foreign Language Studies like myself. The people are also very friendly.

Several of the athletic teams are very successful which makes it a lot of fun to go to games and meet new people. Particularly fun is Men's Basketball where students will camp out for weeks in advance of games to get the best seats in the house. We also boast the loudest and greatest home court advantage in college basketball, the most conference championships in the nation, as well as 5 national championships.
Delicious but Repetitive – The main dining hall is great but at places around campus the prices seem to be a bit high.

Difficult and Rewarding – Engineering school is very difficult and arduous and not for the weary minded. It is also a difficult school to get accepted to, mainly because mathematical and science skills are a must. Most of the prerequisites for engineering classes are math classes, so having a solid mathematical background coming out of high school is a must. We have some really great faculty though.

Good Prices, Bad Service – It's easy to find a decently priced apartment or house for rent, but often times the landlords don't care too much about fixing broken equipment in a timely fashion. It sure will make you impatient!

The University of Kansas is an accredited research institute which means there is always a lot of funding and opportunities for advancements, provided you go into a lucrative field. Some class sizes are very large which makes the faculty more difficult to get a hold of, but overall the faculty is very good with students. One problem is that professors' first priority is their research and teaching classes comes second.
Great Bar Scene – The bar scene is the best and the club scene is pretty decent too. Some bars have 18+ nights where people below 21 can hang out.
Everyone in Lawrence on and off campus has always been friendly and willing to help everyone!
Not Great – Tough to find parking if your planning on bringing a car. Not a lot of parking around the stadiums and the popular bars on the weekends
Downtown Lawrence – Great city with a lot of variety. Many great resturants that will appeal to any person. Great party scene overall.

Rock Chalk! Not only are we known from the Rock Chalk chant but our traditions in all of our sports; rowing, bowling, soccer, baseball, cheer and dance, every sport you go to on KU campus is working hard to strive and preform to their best ability.

Overwhleming Food – There are multiple coffee shops on campus, two different food courts, and a snack area in almost every main building. Just two minutes off campus as well there is a nice restaurant and several other food places to choose from. Your options range from wraps and sandwiches to Pizza hut or Chinese food.

Successful Study Areas – Multiple libraries or study areas are accessible at the University of Kansas. The main library or even the few scattered around campus all allow students to receive scholarly advice and help in a variety of subjects.

I transferred into the Mechanical Engineering program so they looked at my previous grades and GPA. It was not difficult getting into the program, staying in was the hard part. The advisers and faculty were very helpful! Fell free to call and ask them questions--- they love helping out!

Parking can be bliss or a nightmare depending on what time of day you are looking for parking and what color your parking sticker is. The best parking spots are going to cost you more on your tuition whereas the mediocre/ park-and-ride parking spots will mean you spend more time walking/riding a bus to class. Most students chose the park and ride option where you park further away from campus however you have buses that come every 15 minutes and will drive you to/from campus.

Overall, I've never been worried about crime at KU and feel like it is very safe. The parking lots are regularly patrolled and there are always people on campus regardless of what time it is. We do have the infamous "Lawrence Rapist" however as long as you are cautious of your surroundings and use a buddy when traveling at night, you shouldn't have any issues.

KU's rated as one of the top party schools in the country and it's easy enough to see why. There's a lot of free flowing alcohol on campus even though that there's a high police presence. It doesn't seem like enough to stem the flow of house parties, drinking in dorms or frat/sorority parties.

The Underground – The only one I regularly visit is the Underground. There's a lot of options to choose from like Asian Fusion, Chick-a-fila, a salad bar, sushi, etc. to name a few. It gets very crowded during lunchtime so go before or after the crowd arrives! Even with the remodeling, it's very difficult to find an open seat or table.
Financial aid is easy to obtain as long as you fill out FASFA. If you have outside scholarships, you need to communicate with the Financial Aid Office.

Exercise Science – Exercise Science is preparing me for graduate school. I intend to get my master's degree as a physician assistant. The program is set up to prepare a person for numerous graduate programs, including physical therapy and physician assistant. The work load is manageable but challenging at the same time. The curriculum includes several prerequisites such as chemistry, humanities, anatomy, physiology, and several other subjects.

Lots of It. There is always something to do in Lawrence. The clubs are always busy, there's usually something at one of the frats. KU sponsors lots of events if you choose not to drink. SafeBus and SafeRide provide transportation all around Lawrence, which helps greatly decrease drunk driving. Most clubs/bars are 21 and up.

There are some cute guys in on-campus living, but you have to find them. Pretty girls are much easier to come by as freshman in sororities live in the dorms, freshman in fraternities live in the houses. Lots of athletic-types here due to the draw from Kansas Athletics.

Completely Safe – I have never felt unsafe on campus. I have only heard of one incident of people feeling threatened, and that was when they were careless and left their doors unlocked. I have walked from the library to the dorms late at night alone several times. As a freshman girl, I never felt threatened or unsafe.

Positive Learning Environments – There are great facilities at KU. The first thing that comes to mind are the libraries. Watson, the larger of the two main libraries, is there 100% for focused learning. Anschutz, the second largest, is also a great environment, but it is more of a "social" library. You can study in groups and it's not against the law to have a laugh while learning. As for the campus itself, it's stunning!

The computers are fantastic, the printers in the engineering library are extremely hightech and require a student to login to their account at the printer to avoid printing unncessary items. All students are given $8 worth of printing money and personal computers are needed if one wants to do work in their room. Internet is usually reliable throughout the campus and the dorms became wireless this winter.

There are lots of options with a wide array of prices from McDonalds to Steak n Shake to Applebees to Free State. There are buses going by them all day long so access is readily available and often student deals are run to help students save money.

Housing Vs Bar – There's a couple of bars on the corner of Ohio St right down the hill from campus. This is also the location of the Schol Halls. For the most part Ohio's pretty okay. Sometimes you find a spot, sometimes not. But Thursday - Saturday it's a total pain trying to find a spot when most of the usual spots are taken by people only parking there for the bars.

Printing for Engineers Is Great – First off, every KU student gets $8 for printing every semester. That's pretty good and I've never had to use all of it. But for Engineers, printing is free at the Eaton computer labs and Spar Library. Which considering you'll be printing a lot for reports and what not, it's really great to have. Also if you live in the Scholarship Halls, printing is also free in your houses too.
Has a great music program, music therapy program is one of the highest in the country. Well known for basketball and home of the invention of basketball, Naismith.

Lawrence has a unique downtown with interesting stores unique to the town. Lots of cultural events and fairly safe not enough activities to do such as theme parks, ice skating. Lots of parks for and recreational centers though.

No Crime, University Provides Safe Bus and Safe Ride Service (Somewhat Like Taxi Service) – I have yet to hear about any campus crime. There are emergency safety phones set up throughout the campus. The university also offers a Safe Bus service to prevent drunk driving. There are 3 buses and they take different routes throughout Lawrence (mainly downtown and the student apartment areas) all the routes start at the dorms. The university also provides a Safe Ride service that is like a taxi service. As long as you are a student, you may call to ask for a ride.

Buses Available Throughout Town Along With Student Parking Near Campus – Buses are always running. The amount of time it takes to get to campus varies on which bus route you take and where you're living. Student parking is available. There is a small amount available on campus and then there is a Park & Ride area where you park near campus and bus will take you to the campus. The Parking & Transit is rather strict on their ticketing though.

At the University of Kansas you have two choices of which side of campus to live on. You can live on one side at Daisy Hill, which house most of the dorm. Its very close to allen field house. Or you can live in GSP or Corbin (All girl dorm) on the other side of campus by the football stadium. Daisy hill is way closer but GSP/Corbin have a reliable bus system, and even if you miss the bus it is only a ten mile walk. Corbin is the sorority girl dorm. Every girl in a sorority lives there their freshman year. Food is about the same. Daisy hill has Ms. E's, the largest food service on campus, with a lot of variety. Corbin/GSP shared a food place located in GSP. It is currently being renovated but will be open in the fall of 2012. It is said to be high tech and custom meals to order. Either way you can not go wrong, depends what you like. But remember whatever eating plan you get, I will work at any of the eating locations. Meaning you can live in Corbin but still go eat a Ms. E's

Popular Study Areas – Everyone also assume that you study at the library. Which is true but KU has several libraries, so which one do you choose? Watson library is the best choice. It is smaller so its not so overwhelming. Less people means less people watching to distract you from homework. I has both quiet and non quiet study areas. My favorite place is the 5th floor. It is a quite study that has the classic wooden chairs and wooden desk. However, If your back does start to hurt, large cushioned chairs are always available. Don't worry about there not being enough outlets for all your deceives. Most outlet up there have a power strip connected to it. Happy studying!

A Wide Variety of People – The university has a wide variety of race. I believe the ratio is very well evened out with the international exchange students being a bit higher percentage. They all get along very well.
My financial aid process was very smooth without any obstacles. I was able to get my grant money with ease. Bursar office was very helpful throughout the entire process. I was very pleased.

Apartments Are Reasonably Priced – After moving from Indiana University and comparing the two universities together in terms of off-campus housing, Lawrence was surprisingly cheaper. And most of apartments are cleaner and quieter. A lot of them, including mine provides a shuttle bus ,which is very nice for stingy college students like myself.

Not Much to Do but Great Nightlife – There isn't much to do on campus and out. But when the night comes, bars open and the Student union often open up an event. At University of Kansas, sports is a big tradition so naturally, when basketball or football season comes, its the best time of the year.

Game Over If Rains – University of Kansas is known for its hill-y landscape. It is fantastic to look at from a far on a sunny day, but when you are on campus walking to your class, it is total pain. Add pouring water into that picture, it creates a total chaos. Mercy street.

Good Eats on Massachusetts Street – In the heart of Lawrence where University of Kansas is located, is the Massachusetts street. The town considered on the liberal side, this one street has hundreds of different kind of restaurants and thousands of different exotic dishes. From Indian cuisine to Caribbean, Mass street will satisfy any of your food cravings. Plus, most of these restaurants are pretty kind to your wallet.

Great Quality but Limited Menu to Choose from – There are 3 major dining halls that you can go to at University of Kansas. One at the Union, one in the basement of a lecture hall and the biggest buffet cafeteria (Mrs.E's) located in Lewis Residence Hall. The food is fantastic but students are confined with little choices to choose from. By the 2nd year at the same institute, students will most likely be bored with the menu.
Love Them – love our frats and sororities very polite and fun.
We are huge sports fans and love our men's basketball team!

Public transportation is great. Bus is available to pick up students in evening/late at night if drinking,etc. and take back to campus or home. School has buses that run routinely through town to get students to classes.

Parking permit is costly and spaces are limited. Bus service is excellent so may not need car. Tickets are issued quickly and not forgiven. You need to get to campus early to get parking. Lots are restricted.

Fan support at KU is great, but fans can be finicky and sometimes unfair to coaches and teams when not winning. School spirit is awesome. All sports facilities are good, but basketball is more catered to than other sports. This is a basketball school. KU has an exceptional program.

You will see every walk of life on this campus from the Art students to the jocks to the computer science geeks. But there is never any issue among these groups and many times you will see them intertwine. KU is a school where it's ok to be different because we're all here for the same thing to learn and grow. Yes you'll have the extremely religious protesters every once in awhile usually when something major political is happening in the world but the next day you'll have the extremely liberal people protesting. But once they've gotten off their soap boxes everyone just goes back to normal and no one is hurt or truly upset about it. You just feel like you can express yourself with out judgement on this campus.

The campus alone is beautiful, full of trees and lovely landscaping. I love the way campus is laid out and the fact that cars aren't allowed to drive on campus during school hours, it allows you to feel safe crossing the street and avoids many traffic jams. The bus system is great and if you live off campus they have a park and ride system connected to the towns bus system that works nicely. There is always something going on in the afternoons on wescoe beach and almost every Friday there is some type of music playing outside of the union. It's a beautiful campus but it is a walking campus so be prepared to climb hills and walk to classes.
Pretty unreliable...2012 was the mildest winter since 1931...it didn't get below 50 degrees that often.
Diverse campus - segregation noticeable mostly with exchange students. Nightlife especially diverse.

"Student Ghetto&quot – Surrounding campus are many different areas of student housing. The only thing that separates the "student ghetto" (a misnomer- many of the houses are awesome) are the hills - annoying - but worth it. There are also a variety of extremely nice apt. complexes within 5-10 min drive from campus. Pools, tech labs, gyms, etc., all available.

I'm a freshman and didn't bring a car to campus since I'm living in the dorms on campus. I usually take the bus or walk to class. They are strict on parking tickets. You can by permits that allow you to park in certain lots.

Num Num Num – Lawrence has so many great places to eat. The best part is the variety. There are so many non-chain restaurants, which is a nice change of pace. Many great places are located on Mass St., which is just a short walk from campus!

Campus Life – The University offers more campus activities than any student could ever possibly imagine. There is something great happening somewhere on campus at all times. Campus is also very beautiful during the spring season with all of the gorgeous tulips in bloom!

ROCK CHALK! The city of Lawrence, Kansas is sure to have something for everyone. However, it is definitely a very liberal environment. I enjoy the variety of independently owned restaurants and shopping available on Mass Street. The University hosts several cultural events to get everyone involved in one way or another. Of course no one can deny the intensity that fills Lawrence during basketball season. Allen Fieldhouse is without a doubt the best place to watch a college basketball game and the energy is so powerful, words cannot even begin to describe it!!! Rock Chalk Jayhawk, GO KU!

The thing I like most about the University of Kansas is its traditions. Because basketball was started here, a lot of them have to do with that, but there are still others that are very unique. For example, it is bad luck to walk through the bell tower before you graduate and there is a fountain on campus that you get thrown into on your birthday.

Various Libraries – The University of Kansas has great libraries. You can't walk two blocks on campus without passing one and they are all so different. They range in size, topic, and atmosphere. Everyone I have been in has been helpful in some way. I spend most of my time in the Architecture Library, which is small and quaint and a great place to study and read.

Great College Town – Lawrence is a great city to live in as a college student. It is moderate in size, but has plenty to do. The local eateries and downtown strip are always busy with people. A lot of students stay in town on the weekends because there is always something to do. It is also a very artsy and dynamic town which also makes things fun and interesting.
Rec Center – Pretty good Rec Center, with a rock-climbing wall, and a lot of weight lifting equipment. Try to avoid it between 5pm and 7:30pm, because it is way too crowded.
Weather changes very fast. Very little consistency.
Something for Everyone – There is a place for everyone in Lawrence. No matter who you are, you will be able to fit in with a group that is right for you.

My Second Home – I love my dorm: it is only a 10-15 minute walk to any of the buildings, there is a dining center downstairs, and it is across the street from the rec. center. What I don't like is that we have to pay for laundry and the elevators jam often.

No Place I'd Rather Be – Every building on the KU campus was designed for its students. The recreational center is close to the campus and open from before dawn to midnight; the libraries are often open all day and night; and the Underground (where we get food in a rush) has many different choices including sushi, Asian, pizza, and salads. Plus it seems as if there is a different function every day and it allows students to make friends, relax, and have fun.

Lawrence, Kansas is a beautiful town, not to big, and not to small. There is so much to do every night of the week, and the people around are so friendly. I feel comfortable and safe everywhere I go, and never feel like I do not belong. Lawrence is my home away from home, and it is the classic college town.

Adds Some Flavor – The Greek life at KU is well-known. They host parties with different themes and people that are involved with the Greek life can be easily spotted on campus. The Greek life does a good job of recruiting people and trying to have a variety of "brothers" and "sisters." The fraternities and sororities are a big part of KU and for a good reason, they have fundraisers and encourage people to step out of their comfort zone.

Good Variety – Campus food is pretty good. The main eating establishment on campus besides the dining halls is the Underground which features a variety of different foods from Pizza Hut to sushi! It definitely has something for everyone and the other eating establishments at KU also have good variety so you never get tired of eating on campus.

Very Eccentric – Lawrence is one of those towns that surprise people. It has a vast amount of different types of people. The University of Kansas has a great deal to do with why Lawrence is filled with an amazing amount of uniqueness. Downtown Lawrence is where all the fun happens, great restaurants, locally owned businesses and a very accepting atmosphere. I've lived in Lawrence my whole life and have never become bored!
Party Heaven – The kids here love to party. Since I love to study, it drives me insane! Every night I can hear kids driving by or yelling in the dorm hallways.

A Very Diverse School – There are plenty of foreign exchange students, and tons of people with different ethnic backgrounds. I made five new friends the first week; four of them weren't from the United States.

Off-Campus housing is better than living on-campus. The only con is that you are farther away from the University. However, normally the housing will be near a bus route, which you can take every day to get to school at a descent time. The cost is about the same as living on-campus; it might even be cheaper because you can have a roommate.
For almost all of the school year, it is very cold here. We have buses to take us around campus but they are crammed with people trying to stay out of the weather
I Don't Get Any. My family is relatively well off and I had average grades in high school, so I am not getting any financial aid.
No Clue – I don't know anything about sports, nor do I care to. I know that people at KU love sports and they have many different types if you do like sports.

Diverse and Welcoming – KU is Incredibly diverse. If you are a bigot or a racist, this is not the school for you. We have students of all races, all economic statuses, and all religions. People here are very welcoming of the LGBTQ community as well.

Good Times – I have found that there is a very lively nightlife in Lawrence. It is always a good time to hop on safe bus from the dorms and see where the night takes you. If you are 21 there are the mass street bars and when there are good deals people will be there. The Granada has a lot of shows come through it too. overall, if you look for fun you will find it.

Not Bad, Not Great – I am a very picky eater. that being said, take my opinion lightly. I am also a vegetarian and they do have some options for me. Mrs. E's is a bit lacking in verity and quality. the studio is good most of the time. the market and the underground are the best but you will be paying for it. My advice?...When in doubt get the hummus.

The Middle – KU has mostly middle class students. This is not a complaint, simply a fact. If you do not fall in that same category it is not obvious to the other students. KU is very supportive for those who need the extra help in the funding department. The Endowment Association particularly helps in that area. You can get loans from the donations alumni have given. They really do a nice job of making sure you can stay in school no matter where you come from.

School Unique – The University of Kansas is a very unique university because it's located on the hillside. The location of the University is very close to all the places such as restaurant and shopping shops.

Huge Multicultural Populace – I was surprised by the number of international students that were here. This is a very good opportunity to know and learn about other people and their cultures and they are very happy to do so.

Quite Erratic – The temperatures here can get switch overnight and the weather is very much impossible to track. It doesn't really affect classes so that is a plus. But the sudden changes can cause you health problems.

Not Really Strict – I have found no rules in particular that can affect me or students in our academics or social lives, except maybe the no skateboarding rule. Then again, how many people skateboard?

Cashbar actually selling the best burger in Lawrence, kansas. The location of the restaurant is pretty convenience to student which can take No. 11 bus and straight reach the street of the restaurant located. The price for the burger is consider reasonable which is about 5 dollars for a big burger.
Parking is simply a b*tch! On game days, the parking police are like trained Nazis. They are inconsistent about ticketing too. Sometimes you WILL get ticketed, other times, you WON'T. It's a pain.

Revolves Around Basketball – KU basketball players are worshiped like gods. People attend the games religiously. But, football.... Not so much. Out football team is not touted so highly. They've been a joke the past two seasons. Other sports... they receive a bit of attention. We have a good quidditch team too....

OVERPRICED! But that is common on campuses. A smoothie is $5! It's ridiculous. We have one main dining hall because most student live off campus. Mrs. E's is decent, their desserts are good. It's not organic or super healthy though. We have a Chik-fil-A and Pizza Hut stations.

KU's academic buildings are nice. Both libraries are accessible and open til the late hours of the evening. Our Student Union has a bowling alley and numerous other things! Our fitness center is nice, although far away.

Can Be a Problem – once you get the "lay of the land" so to speak and memorize the least used parking lots you can usually find a parking spot. Try to park somewhere earlier on or else it can be packed

about average strictness, you're not supposed to drive on campus until most classes are over, parking can be a problem and sometimes the buses will make you late.Not really too strict.EXCEPT for parking.

The people here are pretty laidback and almost everyone wears something with KU on it..this is a really awesome place with UNMATCHED school pride! I have visited several universities across the country and there is nothing close to being a Kansas Jayhawk..Once you are a Jayhawk then you become like family to everyone. Also,Lawrence is one of the best college towns and on a basketball night all the TV sets in town are turned to the game(if you're not already at it). Seriously, you cant find a more awesome school in america in terms of both social life, school pride and academics. (our debate team has five national championships). When you come here check out the local pizza places and the nightlife on mass street! Seriously, this place is like no other, KU won the title in 08 and Mass street went wild, the people are so passionate about basketball that its something very special.

Multitude of Opportunities – There are so many people, groups and activities to become involved with at KU. There are always free lectures, programs and volunteer activities. You have to throw yourself into whatever event sounds interesting and fun. There are always new opportunities to meet new people and expand your resume.

Slow and No Free Printing – The wireless access has just reached the dorms on campus this year. The speed of the computers in the libraries on campus are slow at best. It can take up to ten minutes for a computer to log on. Printing is not wireless and is not free. It can be hard to print on campus because of the lack of computers in the libraries; especially during busy hours, such as lunch.

Secure, Welcomed, Informed – I always feel comfortable walking back from class late at night on KU's campus. There are clear lit paths from the campus to the dorms. There are usually police officers walking on campus or patrolling. It is always best to be smart but KU is a relatively safe and secure campus.

Most students on campus dress very casual. The typical student wears jeans and a t-shirt. I am always seeing very attractive guys on campus. From my experience most of the guys on campus aren't looking for a relationship just somebody to mess around with.
Lawrence Has a Variety. Lawrence has a great variety of places to eat. Most of the best restaurants are on Mass st. You can find anything from greek to indian food.

ROCK CHALK JAYHAWK!! I love the school spirit at KU. We don't have a good football team but we still support them. Basketball is HUGE here. This year is a rebuilding year for us but we are still doing good. KU basketball is the best experience I have had. Allen Fieldhouse is the loudest college basketball stadium in the country. We are 7 in a row big 12 champs and James Naismith (inventor of bball) was our first coach. Enough said.

Food Is...Alright. The dining halls in the dorms are not so great. There is always a good salad bar but that gets old fast. Otherwise sometimes it's good and sometimes you're better off going out to eat. But the underground and union have good food. There is chick-fil-a, pizza hut, sushi, wraps and other goodies.
Our rec center is very nice. There is a huge rock climbing wall and the classes are pretty cheap. The libraries have quite a few computers but they can be slow sometimes.

School Spirit – Something i wasnt prepared for was the amount of school spirit on campus, its wonderful and it really helps you have a sense of pride for going to KU. There is almost always a booth or table for you to get a free shirt or something else and it provides students with KU gear and also free clothes. If i had to chose all over again knowing what i do i am almost positive i would still chose KU because of the atmosphere

I really dont know what other schools are like in all honesty but the teachers within my specific major are awesome. I am constantly getting emails on new internship and job opprotunities as well as ways to help with my workload or improve my writing. The facilities are very good and offer both quiet environments as well as some where you can work with others to improve your work.

Shops Gallore – There is a main street called Mass and there are shops and bars and jazz clubs lining the street its a wonderful place for students to take a day off and shop and have some fun. There is also an on campus gym for students to work out at or just simply play a game or two of tennis. There are also often campus events for students to attend. There is an on campus police force as well as an off campus one and all students can feel safe within the town. There is also a wonderful attitude students.

One of the great things about attending a state university is the diversity that comes with it. There are people that are different races, religions, and practices, but everyone respects each others beliefs.

Food Choices – There are days when the food is great, but there is also weeks where the food is similar. Pizza and hamburgers are always served, but there should be more healthier options than just the mainline.

Know Your Permit – There are many random parking lots on campus, each with a separate lot number and permit required for certain hours of the day. It's honestly very confusing to a freshman. There are even parking permits required for the side of streets, which may be hard to see the sign. Students living on campus can only park in front of their dorms, and the rest driving need a certain permit. It's also hard to tell when the lots are open to everyone.

Police Aren't Too Involved – Not to say that the police let everyone get away with everything, but with so many students, they don't bust parties or get anyone in trouble for underage drinking too often. They are present on campus during events and every day class is in session, and I feel safe on campus.

Could Be Better – Financial aid is a lot harder to get through the university than I thought it would be. Try as many outside sources as possible and do not rely on you the financial aid office for all the help you need.

Houses Are Huge! The Greek houses on campus are huge and beautiful, they are quite the sight to see. However, non-greek students and greek students get along fine. There is no "outsider" feeling if you aren't going greek.

So Much Fun – There are tons of things to do on and off campus. Everyone, everywhere is a Jayhawk fan. It's unlike anything you've ever felt before, there's so much pride for the school. The campus is also very safe feeling.

BM Musicology Program – The program in which I am enrolled is unique; I know of only a couple of universities that offer an undergraduate Music History or Musicology degree, and most of those are very large music schools. I am the only student in the program here. The fact that there are only four faculty and about ten graduate students in the musicology program has given me many opportunities for research and mentorship than I would have had at a larger school. Most people come to musicology through performance or music theory, so I was excited to be able to start doing research and teaching during my undergraduate.

Poor Upkeep – Murphy Hall (in which I spend most of my time) has very little upkeep. Last semester there was an asbestos scare, which is still not resolved. Climate control regularly malfunctions; I heard some of the custodians complaining that it took two weeks for repairmen to come after they told them the fifth floor heating was inoperative this November. Next semester the heat will be off on the third and fourth floors until mid-March, in order to drive out an infestation of book-glue-eating

Too Many Hills – The many campus hills become dangerous in snow, ice or rain. I do not drive to campus, but I often hear of bad car wrecks because of people sliding down icy hills or not being able to stop at the bottom of a hill. I have gotten dumped into ditches because of ice on the sidewalks; when I only have ten minutes between classes at the opposite end of campus, it is nearly impossible to get there on time in bad weather because the sidewalks become so slick.

Limited Campus Police Presence – I have been disturbed by the limited presence of campus police. I walk to school at 4:30 every morning, and I am always nervous about walking alone through the dark. Walking back home after late recitals or rehearsals is even worse. I have heard veritable horror stories from dorm-dwellers and RAs about the situation of the dorms: drunkenness, drug use, unauthorized cohabitation and noise violations are all tolerated. One of my classmates has been waiting for three months for a simple floor transfer since the people down his hall have set up a regular 2:00 AM appointment to pound on his door and shout obscenities at him because he reported them for a noise violation.
I remember the financial aid being sort of a long process, but it worked out in the end. I got a small first year scholarship from the school.
Driving Safe – Getting around safely at The University of Kansas is relatively easy. Between safebus, saferide and badd duty there is no excuse to be walking alone or driving drunk!

The libraries have a variety of different environments to study in. From places to study as a group, to the quiet areas in Anschutz or secluded areas in the stacks of Watson there are places to fill every study need.

Local Focus on the University – The entire town of Lawrence is focused on the University of Kansas. I found that many landlords were unwilling to rent to non-students; many stores offer student discounts. As soon as the semester (in fact, the first half of finals week is over), the entire town becomes deserted, and stores and restaurants begin to close. The locals are all friendly and helpful to the student body.

Spencer Research Library – The main reason I decided to attend the University of Kansas was the Spencer Research Library. As a musicologist, I find it an incredibly helpful resource. The Shull Collection (in American religious literature) has allowed me to do significant new research in early American hymnody and music theory and notational practiced in dispersed-harmonic compositions without having to travel to other institutions or rely heavily on microfilm.
I haven't done one associated with ku, but I did one for a church and it as great.
The sorority was amazing. I met a lot of great people from many places

There are different people of all walks of life at KU. Many people of different races, sexualities, religions and still getting along as one student body. Overall it is good for acceptance and differences. That would be accepted only when not involved in Greek life.

Student Life – There are plenty of ways to spend time off campus in Lawrence. That's one of the benefits for going to KU. Massachusetts street is very popular with shopping and quaint restaurants. If needed, Target is 2 miles down the road on Iowa street. On Mass St. then you can get noodles & co, chipotle, buffalo wild wings and many delicious restaurants. There are many delivery services to the dorm which definitely is nice. Most of them run until 3 AM!

Computer Life – Living in the dorms thru the school them WiFi is hardly available. Living at Naismith then there is WiFi which, is poor for the entire Lawrence area. The television cable channels at Naismith are awful and they take away all of the channels that this age group typically watches. Definite need for a personal laptop. You do get $8 worth of printing through the school from your tuition.
The parking at KU in convient, although it is a great expence to the student. The access is close to the dorm rooms. I enjoy this parking, and comes in handy.

Our Social Life – At Kansas University, you will have many choices in the opposite sex. Students have a bright future if they intend to finish at KU. This ensures a bright future when choosing to date one of the KU attendees.

The different dinamics at the University of Kansas are almost all positive. They have a great range of people from all ethnic backgrounds and different beliefs in religion and background. The University of Kansas is currently the best rated college in Kansas.
In-State Shoe-In – As a Kansas resident, it was easy to apply for and get into KU. The application process wasn't abnormally long or difficult.

Packed Lots Pricy Passes – It's tough to park around campus and it's expensive to park on it. There are other transportation options, like the bus, which is included in tuition. Living close enough to campus is advisable, because it puts you in the center of it all; school, parties, bars, etc...

School Spirit to the Max – School spirit is insane at KU. People do go to all the football games and support their team, but it's basketball that the school revolves around. Students camp out for every game (even exhibition) meeting 6am the morning after every home game, sometimes outside in the frigid weather. The players are treated like celebrities and the whole town bleeds crimson and blue on game days. Basketball is certainly the biggest social event on campus.

Dinning on campus is all right, but very repetitive. If you live on Daisy Hill, Mrs. E's is the place to eat, and it's a LOT better than Oliver dining or GSP/Corbin. The Underground is a nice place to eat between classes, but can get expensive and very crowded at peak times

Rare Punishments – Since Lawrence is a college town, everyone understands what students want to experience. The only punishment that you would see somewhat "often" is drinking in the dormitories, but that's usually when students decide to pregame in the dorms and things get out of hand. They also don't allow smoking in the dorms but students often smoke right outside on the stoop. The ambulance, fire department, and police come to the dorms often but no one gets any real punishment. They just come to check things out to make sure people are okay. Police don't care much for parties, they'll come in and walk around and find a random person smoking drugs, but if it gets to rowdy they just ask people to leave. If you just drop your cup, they don't give you any consequences for drinking unless you're out of control. Most bars don't care about underage drinking. Almost everyone has a fake, or does pass backs. But if it's a slow night, they are a bit stricter. Bouncers often let you know if they don't wanna see a certain id passed back again. The University offers what we call SafeBus, which drives students to various locations on the weekend when they go out to party. It runs Thursday-Saturday 9pm-3am. The university also provides a "SafeRide" which is like a taxi. A student may call, or use an emergency blue phone on campus, to call SafeRide to pick them up and take them home. Overall, the city of Lawrence is lenient with students' behavior.

Food Worth Your Dollar – There are many dining options available on campus. There is a dining hall near every dormitory. How many meals you get depends on your meal plan but the dining halls are set up in a buffet style, so it's unlimited amounts per visit. The food isn't like home but it's decent and satisfying. When holidays come around, dining halls cook their best meals, and the halls are full. There are on-campus cafe shops and dining areas as well. There is a dining area at the Kansas Union that provides various mini restaurants at a facility called The Market with food such as pizza hut, Japanese & Chinese cuisine, deli, grill, vegetarian etc. A popular on-campus dining area is The Underground, which is on Jayhawk Boulevard near most lecture buildings. The Underground is somewhat a higher-quality version of The Market. It includes Pizza Hut, Chik-Fil-A, Japanese & Chinese cuisine, deli, grill, vegetarian. There many other dining facilities all over campus, over 20 locations. There's really no reason to go off campus to eat unless you're going for fast food or a local restaurant like Applebee's. If you get tired of the food, there are various places that will deliver Chinese, pizza, subs etc.

Lawrence is your typical college town. It is home to the University of Kansas(KU) Jayhawks who won the 2008 NCAA Basketball Championships. Lawrence does somewhat revolve around KU. The University often has events that are open to the public(i.e. carnival, comedians, musical performances, bowling). A popular attraction is Massachusetts Street (Mass). Mass is where the shops and restaurants are. Attractions all on one street. It's also very close to campus. You could walk or take the bus there. There are also local department and grocery stores off of Iowa street(JC Penney, Kohls, Walmart, Hobby Lobby, Target, Sears). There is also Clinton Lake, which is wonderful for camping. For students, everything is just a short drive away.
I dont spend much time on campus, but I never see security. It really isnt needed though
Up and Down – One day it will be 90 degrees and the next it will be 40. But that's what happens when you live in Kansas. The summers are HOT and the winters are COLD.

Our basketball team is the heart of athletics. We have won 5 National Championships and have over 2,000 wins. There are very many KU fans, especially when it comes to basketball. The whole scene and involvement is amazing. There is just so much love in the air and everyone becomes your friend while you're Allen Fieldhouse.

Very Safe – At the University of Kansas, there are always campus police and different patrol cars riding around protecting the students and the campus. I have never felt "unsafe" while walking around campus, even at night. I have heard the many stories of weirdos around campus, but I am definitely not stressing it because I am confident that KU will get the situation taken care of.
I am not involved, but know that there diverse frats and sororities at KU. Many people do pledge and seem to enjoy it.
Extreme school wide school wide spirit thrives at KU. Expect basketball obsession.

Very diverse food options are available, but are rather expensive compared to off campus meals. There are many places to buy food, however. It is extremely accessible. Meals are sold in every library.
Four Seasons – We have four distrinct seasons, we see a little of verything.
GSP Corgin – Great location, building is old and needs to be renovated

Girls, I think that this is the most important thing I WISH i would have known before living here.
I know when you imagine an all girls dorm, you may imagine a laid back environment that is more comfortable than a co-ed. Think again.. You should know before you move in that 99% of the girls living in Corbin will be rushing for a sorority and will form those "bonds" before you even move in (if you aren't rushing) If you do not plan on rushing, you are the minority and it makes it VERY hard to meet people.

At KU, basketball is the religion. From the day that James Naismith invented the game on KU's campus, the University's team has dominated the sport. There is no way to put into words the excitement that the sport produces. Cheering on the team in Allen Fieldhouse is indescribably amazing! And though the football team is lacking, the University comes together and has a great time.

The campus facilities on KU's campus are very impressive. There are two different gyms, both of which are state of the art. Both gyms have instructed courses, personal training services, and free equipment rentals which are convenient. The The Kansas Union is amazing. It is the mecca of the campus, offering: places to study, ballrooms, auditoriums, meeting/convention rooms, a food court with a wide variety of options from popular fast food joints to healthier options, two different coffee shops, a bowling alley, a movie theater, a convenience store, a bank, Student Involvement and Leadership offices, a campus book store, a KU apparel store, and much more!

You Choose – If you want to find drugs and alcohol, you can. Almost every party will have alcohol, but it's not a big deal if you choose not to drink. Alcohol on campus is strictly monitored though, so best to drink off campus. Drug scene isn't that big, usually just smoking. Drinking is more popular.

Many Options – Too many people go to the libraries and forget that there is almost one computer lab in every main building. Internet is sometimes slow, but the IT helpers are usually available to call if you have problems (if you have the number). You can get wireless in every building. Printing costs .08 cents a page, but the school gives you money on your KU card to use just for printing, they take it off at the end of the semester though.

New Words, Same Means. Even though the University of Kansas has let out new scholarships it is still expensive to attend to and even more hard to get the scholarships that are not worth all the hard work either way.

Buses Are Good, Students Not So Much. I love the bus system for students here at KU. But if you are some of those that don't live on campus, still having to pay the bill seems a little too much. But as for the bus drivers I give most them an A+ for their tolerance and patience, but the students should be less demanding trying to change the bus schedule for their own benefits. The buses are for everyone the buses shouldn't chance anything for a few people.

Unless Is Basketball – Unless is basketball everyone here seems to focus less in other sports. It is still tradition to cheer for other sports but it's not the same. As in for basketball games, the crowd goes wild and the good comments just keep coming.
No Judgement – As far as I have seen, this school is diverse and tolerance is practiced across campus.

Large Variety – There are many labs around campus. The main ones are almost always crowded, but there are also little labs in different departments that are very helpful and reliable. There has been one or two days where the wireless connection wasn't great, but the rest of the time, it is fully reliable.

It Is What You Make It – The professors are always there to help if you put forth the effort and seek them out. There are some fabulous faculty here, and the classes are very informative. The class sizes vary and it's a nice place to go to school.
Tradition, Tradition, Tradition – All of our traditions are most excellent. From our innovations in the classroom to our world famous chant: ROCK CHALK!!
Fall, Winter, Spring – Fall and spring are the best but the winters are super chilly. Sledding down the Hill is fun though.

Rock Chalk Jayhawk! In all honesty KU is an awesome school. Everything at KU has some sort tradition or purpose. Even though some of the buildings are very old they are all outfitted with clean facilities, air conditioning, and the latest technology.

Safebus Is Your Key to Friday/Saturday Nights – I love SafeBus. Not only because it's extremely convenient, but because you can hop on a SafeBus and easily find a party. Just follow the crowd. SafeBus is a lot of fun and half the people riding are already drunk.
It's not hard to find a house party where you can get a drink if you're underage. Most parties charge $5 for a cup.

I Live in Mccollum and. . . I love it. It is definitely not the nicest dorm but I'm getting the true Freshman experience. Rooms are bigger than the ones in Hash & Ellsworth but they aren't renovated. Out of Lewis, Ellsworth, Hashinger, Lewis, and McCollum - I recommend McCollum & Hashinger. The community of Hash is amazing. I have friends there & they're whole floor is really close. Only negative aspect of Hash are the stoop kids - they can be real ass****s sometimes. Mac is awesome if you're okay with living in an older dorm. I've heard tons of horror stories about it but none of it has been true. Example: the fire alarm has yet to be pulled. Lewis is boring. Sure, the rooms are nice but there isn't much of a community because people stay in their rooms. Ellsworth is okay. It's a mix between suites and traditional rooms and has been renovated recently. Some of the rooms in Ellsworth are TINY! I don't know much about Templin, Corbin, GSP, or Oliver!

I'm Getting My Moneys Worth – My classes are not too hard but they're not a breeze either. I'm a Freshman and most of my classes are taught by TAs. I got lucky though and they are all great. The classes I am in are small - 28 students on average - except for one lecture of 100 students (which is small compared to some other lectures I've heard of!). I feel like I am getting my moneys worth here.

on weekends you normally don't see the students drinking alcohol but you know at the end of the night they had some alcohol at one point of time. Possibly they get the alcohol from at parties or the have it hidden in their dorms. I have seen some of my peers with fake IDs so that could be a way of getting alcohol and how visible it is.

The common interest between both the guys and the girls at the University of Kansas is spending most of their time at the recreation (rec) center. As soon as classes are over or as soon as they're done with their studies, the rec is where they go to work out and stay physically active. Also the rec is seen as a place where students socialize and meet other students.

The diversity on campus is great, but the thing about it is that it is only on the campus. As for a resident's halls the diversity within the dorms aren't the same as the rest of the campus. While on campus there is an equal proportion of different ethnic groups, but life in the dorms there aren't a lot of minorities other than international students.

Beautiful Campus – The University of Kansas campus is beautiful. The buildings are all made of brick and limestone and they're gorgeous from every angle. The aesthetic of KU's campus was a huge deciding factor in my attendance.

Open Minded to My Success – I came to the University of Kansas because they have great programs in Music and Biology, and more importantly they allowed me to major in both! I've received a lot of support and encouragement in regards to my plans.
The Spanish program at KU is not excellent. A lot of the professors are good but you won't necessarily have them even at senior level classes.
Lots of Vegetarian/Vegan Options – Lawrence is super conscious of the vegetarian/vegan community with tons of restaurants offering a variety of options.
Libraries Are Great – The libraries at KU are awesome. Lots of room to study, computers, and tons of books.

Lots of Routes, If You Can Wait – The campus bus system recently teamed up with the city bus system and now provides free services to KU students to any bus stop in Lawrence. They are very reliable, even in winter weather, and the schedule parallels class times; however, depending on the stop location, you might have to wait 20-30 minutes between buses.

Computer and wireless availability is average at KU. There are computers for student use in the libraries and academic buildings, but not nearly enough- it is quite difficult to find a free one during the daytime. The wireless network is excellent across campus; however, the internet access in the residence halls is not wireless.

Safety Measures Abound – The University of Kansas goes to great efforts to keep campus safe and secure. There are blue lights almost everywhere on campus, and campus police patrol campus by car and bike regularly. They also offer the SafeBus and SafeRide programs, which run at nighttime and will give students a free ride home to anywhere in Lawrence.
Parking at KU sucks. They ticket you for the smallest infractions, the lots are always full and they are always far away from where you need to go. Walking is the best option at KU.

There a lot of dirty hippies that go to KU, but then there are also a lot of Greek people. Frat guys wear pastel and sperries and for the most part are decent looking. The girls are a lot more attractive, especially the ones in sororities. Most everyone here parties.

Overall we have a very diverse campus. White is the majority but acceptance is a widespread philosophy on our campus. Often when walking to class I pass by supportive Gay/Lesbian rallies that are promoting acceptance of all sexual orientations, and I receive flyers on campus that are in support of diversity clubs.

Men's Basketball – KU has the ultimate home court advantage when it comes to basketball. Allen Field house is the place to be when the Jayhawks are playing at home. Students camp out for games just so that they are able to get seats, since there aren't enough seats for everyone. Its loud, fun, and full of tradition like waving the wheat and the Rock Chalk chant.

This campus is a blend of many different types of people. There isn't just one way to dress, you are able to find so many different people from all walks of life that its not that hard to find some group you can be apart of.

Lawrence Food – When you get off campus you have a lot of choices when it comes to find something to eat. You can either take Mass. or Iowa and always finding something from comfort food to a nice sit down restaurant.

Bus Routes Are Great! The bus routes seem to come around every 15 minutes. It also picks up students at their apartments off campus. So there is no excuse for not having a ride here at KU. There is also bus routes for nightlife offered by KU. If you've had to much to drink they will have a bus there ready to take you hoe safely!
In my opinion the strictness is not very enforced here since this is a "hippie" community people are more excepting about others feelings and beliefs.
Safe Environment – Even though I only see the campus police once of twice around campus I feel safe. The crime here isn't that bad so I dont feel there is to much to worry about.
Not Very Diverse – If you are not White or Asian, there is little chance that you will find yourself on this campus. The black and Latino populations are very low.

Needs Diversity – All of the eating facilities in my opinion, excluding Ekdahl's, are above average. They are almost always open, and the Underground even opened more space to accommodate more students. However, the main dining facility, Mrs. E's is considered by most, awful. Even some of the foreign exchange students agree. Beyond the fact that you are required to have a meal plan at Mrs. E's when living in the dorms, and that its meals are repetitive and reminds you of an elementary schools cafeteria, it is not so bad.

Great Lawrence – people in lawrence are extremely nice to students, especially international students here. The sky is blue , you can enjoy so beautiful scenery here. Besides, you are quickly got involved in local communities by many programs, such the annually friendly family program.

The computers on campus are very good. You have access in almost evey building and in the dorms. You can print to a number of places on campus including the library. The speed of the computers is outstanding. In fact, it is frustrating when back home because the computers are not as fast in gathering information. A personal computer is a must because you will do many things after hours whether it would be in your dorm room or an apartment setting. The same for having your own printer. It makes things easier but that is not to say that you have to have your own technology, if you know how to get around the campus with this item.

I plan on majoring in Sports Medicine. The program is unique in a number of ways. First, I as a student will have to go through a rigorous process to be invited into the program as a sophomore. I welcome that challenge. Another unique aspect of the Sports Medicine program is that I will work directly with University of Kansas athletes and have to care for their well being.

Jayhawk Land – I live in a smaller community and have fallen in love with Lawrence. My father graduateed from the University of Kansas, so I have become very familiar with this town. It is fun to visit a town that is as vibrant as Lawrence.
Lawrence is a place where its' citizens embrace the student body. Whether you are on Iowa Street or Massachusetts Street, people are ready to look you in the eye and say "hi" to you. The citizens of Lawrence know you are a student and make you feel like you are one of their own. Clinton State Lake is very close and my family loves the water. I know being a student here will give me the opportunity to take advantage of the lake. The town continues to grow and the shopping area to the west are very new and affordable. Also, the many diverse shops on Massachusetts Street offer a wide range of shopping from dining to clothing to arts and jewelry. The University of Kansas makes Lawrence a hub of activity for cultural events. It could be a rock concert, a singer of ballads, ballet, or an art show, these things intrigue me. It will give me the well-rounded experience that I want in my college years.

Study Abroad – There are so many options for studying abroad. One could pick from a long list of places as well as who they would like to travel with. There are different groups one can go with such as the same type of major. There are also different options of the time of year one would like to travel during. Prices are always listed up front and scholarship opportunities as well.

Different Cultures – I have never seen so many different races on a campus before. There are clubs for specific cultures as well. I've even seen classes that help students with learning English. I would definitely say there is a vase range of ethnicities on campus.

Study Areas – The University of Kansas has two very large libraries. They have maps of the library at the entrances as well as what one can find on each floor. There are specific areas for students who want to study in total silence as well as areas for students to study out loud with other students. They also provide a comfortable environment with the decorations and furniture. It's not a typical wood table and hard chair environment.

Parking Is Crazy – Professors try and keep cheating to a minimum and the police are their to keep us safe. Most transportation is 'no questions asked' on weekends but parking strictness is ridiculous. It seems that you can't park anywhere on campus without getting a ticket. You can't drive on campus at all unless it's after five. Most people get multiple tickets throughout the year.

Greeks Are Good and Bad – A lot of people are in the Greek system and that's not a bad thing. The houses are beautiful and most of the people seem very nice. But there are people that judge others, cheat on tests, and just want to party. I have nothing against the Greeks that earn their degree but I have a problem with the ones that cheat their way through.
I Felt Safe – There is always crime on a college campus but as long as your smart, it's easy to stay safe on campus. There is security and emergency phones and campus police.

Lots of Drugs – Although the school tries to education every freshmen with an AlcohloEDU course, there is still a ton of underage drinking and drug use. Every weekend there were drunk people yelling and running down the dorm halls and some floors smelled of weed. No one pressures you very much and there are things to do for people that don't drink but you are a minority.

Very Laid Back – There is a lot of diversity on campus and that shows through different organizations and groups. While there are a lot of white students, there are also a lot of foreign students as well. I've learned a lot about different cultures and parts of the country.

Profs Really Care – The professors in the School of Education at KU really want you to succeed. They are always there telling you how to improve and what the real world is going to be like.
