On the first day of class, every teacher tried to get to know everyone and they seemed really passionate about teaching and shaping future teachers.

Unless you are 21+, there are not many options for an exciting nightlife unless you attend a house party. Many of the bars on Mass St (downtown of Lawrence, KS) are 21+. There is only one popular 18 and older club.

Here in Lawrence, KS, there are a wide selection of off-campus housing that can be chosen. Some are more expensive than others, but the differences in price is obvious for what you are paying for provided that apartment complex. There are many apartments that are available for every type of person.

The facilities here on the KU campus provide a very nice atmosphere to attend classes, overall. Some buildings may be older than others, but there is a certain charm to each building no matter the age.
Process Was Okay – Financial AId was very helpful but left me hanging on my books and supplies, so I had to come of out pocket hundreds of dollars.
I have the unlimited meal plan, in which I can eat anywhere and anytime the dining halls are available. My meal deal is perfect and Im glad the dining halls offer great meals.
the housing dorms of University of kansas are somewhat far away from the college which make it a little hard to walk to class.

Strict, but Fair – Overall, the academics are up to the student. With such a large school, not everyone can be kept track of. But, if you fall below a certain GPA, you are put on academic probation. Also, alcohol is prohibited on campus, including the on campus apartments and dorms. KU takes this alcohol rule seriously, but notification isn't sent home until the 3rd offense I believe. We also have on campus police that troll the premises in order to create a safe environment for students. Otherwise, the campus is very open and fun for students. There's not too many restrictions set that prohibits advertisement or functions.

We have one of the top basketball teams in the country! Go Jayhawks! Our varsity sports are pretty awesome and competitive, but we're a big basketball school. Our athletics department takes care of their athletes with lots of help, management, and benefits that ensure their best experience. Plus, we have a lot of club sports that other students love to participate in. There are more women's varsity teams than men's available.

Great Computer Access – There are many computers available all around campus, especially within libraries and computer labs. They can get crowded midday and around finals, but are usually available. The login process is fast and easy, but is known to lag. Even so, the internet speed is fast and efficient. The wireless access on our campus is wonderful, and is expected to expand even further to outside areas around our huge campus. You can pretty much connect any electronic that can handle internet to the network. Printing is available, and each enrolled student receives $8 in printing, but it can go fast. Scanners/copiers are also available.
Need for a Car on Campus – If living on campus there is really no need for a car because KU has an excellent bus system that will take you to the main part of campus where all of your classes are.
Typical Student Looks – For guys the most common look is the frat boy look of khaki shorts and a Pollo with sparies/boat shoes. The most common thing for girls is a dress or a skirt.
Personal Safety – I feel very safe when I am on campus. I never feel threatened and if I was I feel like there is plenty of protection or ways to get help.

The Lawrence – It is a school of diversity. You can just go to this school and interact with people from all different places; as many as 50 countries from all over the world. Its setting is urban, the shopping area is very closed by so you can enjoy your free time wandering around relaxing. It also is a place for change and creativity. For example last year a Quidditch team was created and it officially became a sports club. You can start whatever you like and get together with people with the same ideas.

I really enjoy KU, the campus is beautiful, the classes are very diverse and the design program is new but very strong and developing. I believe that any student who takes advantage of all the possible opportunities at KU will be very successful.

The campus is well-built for walking and the sidewalks are normally well-cleaned during the winter. However, winters in Lawrence can be very bad and last year resulted in 2 snow days. The buses are ill-suited to handle the snow, especially because of the large hills on campus. Ice can also be severe and I have personally seem about a million students face-plant within one winter at KU...amusing but probably not that safe.

The campus is well built for walking and there are lots of bike racks near all the buildings, though some are hard to locate at first. There are on and off campus buses that run from early in the morning until early evening and some during the later hours. However, some buildings are not on the bus routes and there are no late buses, which makes campus less safe for students at night. The "Safe Bus" system is unreliable and hard to use.

Seriously, Everything Man – KU honestly offers an armada of programs to help you get set for life outside of college. It's like all their programs had babies with each other to have other programs, and those program babies are genetically eager-to-please beings that want to prepare you for life afterwards. There are a lot of programs that always get positive reviews.

Mass Street Is Amazing – There are seriously so many places to dine at KU. Mass Street is definitely the place to go: it has the majority of the restauraunts, it's just one long section, they offer lots of student discounts, and the best place to check is the pub at the very end of Mass Street.

Professors: Your grade is HEAVILY influenced by your professor, not by the actual course since each professor is so different and has different levels of difficulty, to the point where it's unfair to some students

Curriculum: too many necessary credit hours

House Parties – Go down any of the state streets and you will find a house party. People are always friendly and you can just go in, even if you don't know the owners. It usually costs about $5 for a cup but you get unlimited beer until the keg is tapped. Most of the bars in town are 21+ (The Hawk and The Cave mainly) but Abe and Jake's is 18 to enter.

Dorm Living – I enjoyed living in the dorms my first year, but I would not go back. I wanted to meet new people, which I did. I did not like feeling like I had a babysitter (RA) and needed to check in whenever I came back. It is a good experience everyone should have, but not something that is needed for more than one year. It was nice to be connected to a meal-plan though.

Interest in Pre-Medicine – The core curriculum, other than gen ed requirements, are mainly science classes. There is little flexibility in what courses to take. I have had good professors within the Honors Program, but I have had some professors outside of this that have not been good. It is important to feel comfortable asking questions and getting help when needed even if you are in a giant lecture hall.

There is pretty much no where for students to park on campus unless you have evening classes. There is a park and ride shuttle that runs every five minutes but it takes 20 mins to get from the parking lot to campus.
I am unaware of the options of Greek housing. They don't really affect the social atmosphere and are seen as party going students.
Most of general education requirement courses are only offered during certain times and usually consist of class sizes of 500-1000 students.

Class Sizes – I'm currently in the Pre-nursing program. I have been rather disappointed as some of courses required for this major have few class choices and oftne involve groups of 500-1000 students at a time.
Best of Campus Choices I Have Seen – Being from California I was amazed to see such nice apartments for so little money. They are incredible and I am looking forward to living off-campus next year.

The food and dining on campus are interesting. The cafes and places that are not in the residence halls are very good. However, the on campus food is not great, especially in Oliver Hall, it is disgusting.

I came to KU because of the excellent academic standings and the college atmosphere. I was very pleased to see that the majority of the professors at KU are helpful and fair. The two things that are difficult about the school are the vast use of graduate students teaching and the lack of transfer student organizations.

Make Friends With Your RA – Policies are very strict when it comes to drinking or drug use on campus or in the dorms. It had escalated to the point where police were escorted through the halls each night in the dorms if there was a case of alcohol or drug abuse. The RA's generally run the dorms so if you're caught with alcohol or drugs your fate is really in their hands because they can choose to either let it slide, get you kicked out, or call the cops on you. It's a good idea to get in good with your RA and make friends early because they'll be less likely to gun for you then. That being said you might as well do all that stuff out of the dorms because as long as it's not happening in the dorms they won't give it a second thought, they're just thinking about keeping that cushy job not being the bad guy.

We Are Basketball – Sports other than basketball at KU are basically put on the sidelines. Football has some support and people will usually attend them for fun but it doesn't have the same kind of energy basketball sparks on campus. Whenever there is a home basketball game it's impossible to get anywhere on campus because so many people attend them, whether they're students or not. Basketball games also generate the best parties, win or lose.

Getting English Papers Done – As an English major the largest portion of my workload consists of written papers, critiques and reading which, to be honest, is a pretty large amount of work to have to do every week, especially when you have work in other classes too. Without proper organization it can turn into a real mountain of papers that will eventually start coming down if you don't take care of everything when it needs to be done. The English Department at the University of Kansas is a well established program with many facilities, such as the writer's corner located in every library, available to English majors as well as any other student looking for an ideal writing atmosphere. These places are great for getting a lot of work done at once and have been a godsend when I can't concentrate on my schoolwork at home. The curriculum has a variety of choices all leading to success in the major. Students can choose to focus there studies on their strengths or refine some neglected practices in the art with options ranging from creative writing to Shakespearian literature. The student advisors in the English Department are available on a regular basis and are extremely attentive to students with a real interest in their major. Many of the advisors are also professors so their availability is really important when it comes time to get some revisions done and they're aware of it. The campus newsletters and newspaper is a great way to explore the writing field and a step further would be to participate in the numerous writing contests or scholarship programs offered by the department.

None Available – If you want money from the University of Kansas, don't hold your breath. Unless you have severe financial aid, you will not receive scholarship or grant money. You may receive loans, however. To perhaps get some scholarship money, you must contact your major's department.

Good but Slow – Transportation through a bus system is great to have on campus, but our university system is intertwined with the city system. This makes the bus routes long and some very slow. They are great to get around, just not if you are in a rush.

So Many Options – The University of Kansas is very diverse in its academics. It is known for a few specific majors, but other major options are all still highly regarded. I am able to take all the classes I need, though I believe there are too many general education requirements. Some professors are much better than others as well.

Greek life is very strong at KU and nearly dominates. There are many Greeks involved in things such as intramurals and student government with the Greeks winning most of the time. As for nightlife, most of the bars are dominated by Greeks which makes for an awesome time and environment!
Down on Mass Street there are tons of bars and places to eat. You can use Beak em' Bucks at most places as well which is very convenient!

Although I have not been admitted to the business school of KU yet as the application process does take a while, my pre req have all been great classes with interesting and engaging teachers. The workload really isn't that much and the TA's and professors are always willing to help!

Constantly Changing – The weather in Kansas is always crazy. We vitually do not have a fall or spring and the temperatures vary weekly and sometimes daily. Since campus is located on such a large hill, there is always a lot of wind when walking to class. When the weather is nice everyone hangs outside of Wescoe Beach and enjoys the sun.

Pretty Attractive – In Lawrence you will find all types of people that definitely have their positive attributes. The girls are always well dressed and blondes tend to dominate the campus. So many beautiful people walk campus that it is impossible to go to class without seeing someone that catches your eye.

Plenty of Resources – There are opportunities all around campus to meet with advisors or faculty that specializes in an area of study. The courses are challenging but the professors and TA's are always available for extra help and tutoring. Even in large lectures participation is encouraged and keeps you involved in the material.

Pretigious Degree – If you seek a career in the medical field the University of Kansas is a great school. It has a history of producing successful scholars. The curriculum is a bit harder so your degree is weighted more. However, it is tougher material, and the professors are strict.

Being located in the middle of the U.S., KU does not have as much diversity as other universities on the two coasts. However, KU still has a decent amount of foreign students and the student body is not as heavily concentrated with white students as others would think. There is even a great studying abroad program here.

Great Campus – The facilities on the campus at the University of Kansas are all of high quality. The dorms are all very decent, with over half of them recently renovated. The dorm I am in even includes music practice rooms and sewing rooms. The campus is beautiful itself, not to mention the great activities that it hold. There are many activities, ranging from athletics to academic competitions, that takes place on campus. Having one of the most consistently great basketball team in the nation playing in the Memorial Stadium on campus, KU is a great campus for its athletics.

Great University – I chose University of Kansas for its amazing engineering program. I have heard great things of the program through many older friends that are currently enrolled in the program. Many of the professors that I have spoken to or contacted are all very eager to help. Furthermore, the tuition is very low compared to other universities with this level of engineering program. This campus able to hold such a large student body within a decent size college town, Lawrence. This gives me the chance to meet many new people without getting the crowded city feel.
Wide Range of Degree Options – There is a huge variety of degrees and educational paths to choose from at KU. Something for everyone. A big campus but it embraces you.

KU is one of the great colleges in America. Situated in a down home small town of Lawrence with tons of shopping, dining and activities to do in your free time. The education you will get here is limited only by your own motivation. A tough school if you choose correctly and a well rounded set of classes to choose from.

The availability of computers and wireless networks is very good. There are a number of libraries on campus as well as individual labs where you can gain access to a computer. Printing at the libraries is also available. For laptop users, wireless is available in every building and there are a lot of nooks where you can park it to get a bit of extra computer time on your own.
Zero Tolerance – Campus no drug policy is pretty strict. If they catch up with it you go before a council in the dorms and they usually move you out. Drinking is far more common on and around campus.

Safety from Academics to Parties – I was very impressed that the university provides the busing services that can take you home after parties. While colleges would like to think they can keep their campuses dry- they are smart to provide a resource that students can fell comfortable taking to get them home safe after a celebration. Safe Ride accomplishes that task.

You Know You Are a Jayhawk- Everyone Is – This college town is very proud to be associated with the university. There is a mascot on every light post. The spirit of the campus is alive from the modern city part of the area to the quaint older downtown entertainment district. Its impossible to refute the fact that you are a Jayhawk when you step on campus. When you can see the towering flags on the English building from interstate 70, you know you are entering Jawhawk nation!
Laid Back – As long as you are cooperating with the officers you won't have any problems and they are usually helpful.

House Parties for Under 21 – House parties are not always reliable but easy to find if you are in the right place. Bars are more frequented by people 21 and up but there is Abe and Jakes for anyone 18 and up.
Simple With Great Networking – The dorms are right next to each other and the social network is great so living on campus is a great way to make new friends
There are lots of local restaurants along with chain restaurants. A great variety for any taste or budget.

If you meet financial need you will get plenty of scholarships and aid. However, if you aren't need based you have the options of getting scholarships from your specific school which is nice. Just participate and have activities that look decent.
Great Academics, people are always nice (Kansas Friendly), we have usually a fantastic basketball team. Great overall atmosphere.
Fairly Visible – There is plenty of drinking...enormous amounts. Partying thursday through saturday for the most part. Weed is also fairly popular as I smell it fairly often.

Network Is Good, but Slow – The computers and the network itself and the amount of scanners, and pre-installed programs for students is very good at KU. However, the network login can be very very slow much of the time, which results is a rather problematic situation for students trying to get papers off in time.

Buses Unreliable – When it snows, buses don't run to my dorm...and parking and transit doesn't inform us about it. I was late to class at least 3 times because of it. However, the bus system is a good idea. If the schedule were followed more closely or revised it would be much better.
As with any school, parking can be an issue. My only suggestion would be to make all campus resident parking permits the same color.

Sports Are Supported by Tradition – No matter what the sport, the University of Kansas students rally behind the teams. The fact that the has school-specific traditions, such as waving the wheat, give sports events an originality and uniqueness that makes going to events ten times more fun for non-athletes. Sports bring the students together, creating a bond as strong as a family's and making the sports scene at KU unlike any other in the country.

Weather is typical of the Midwest region of the United States, especially during the winter and the spring. Weather is mostly cold but not too frigid during the winter. Spring is rainy with weather varying between snow, rain, and cold, and a mix of any of these.

Mostly Repetitive – Too many fast food options when one is on campus. Eating at the Kansas Union or The Underground is quite expensive, with mostly unhealthy food options, such as the Pizza Hut station. The dining hall hours for dinner are limited to about 2 hours.
Its Great to Be a Jayhawk – I mostly chose KU out of convenience, but I would do it again in a heartbeat. Everyone is so excited to be a Jayhawk.

KU has been upgrading most of their facilities, and the ones that have been done are amazing. Classrooms/building that don't have upgrades yet can feel a little lacking, but they are working on them. The libraries are amazing,truly a great resource. And there is always something to do.

Fun, Accepting, Open – The city my campus it located in is beautiful, and full of very accepting people. There aren't too many specific attractions but it is a college town so pretty much everything is aimed at students. Its this little piece of safe haven from the rest of the state.
Gay, Straight, Foreign, American, Male, Female, Weird, Normal, Short, Skinny, Fat, Tall, Whatever! - The University of Kansas has them all. Nobody and everybody is out of the ordinary here.

Endless Possibilities – Whether you wish to live with eighteen other people and share one kitchen or live solo, Lawrence has it all. Off-campus housing is a huge market for the city of Lawrence, so no matter what you're looking for you will be able to find somewhere that suits you fairly well. Although many of the better housing options may be a little ways off campus, Lawrence is a relatively small city and most of the major complexes offer their own buses to shuttle you to the university bus routes or directly to the campus.

Extremely Diverse Department – The English department is absolutely filled with highly intelligent, skilled, and published professors. The workload as an English major is as expected, quite a bit of reading and writing. It is all worth it though, the things you learn from the staff at the University of Kansas are invaluable. The entire department is quick to help when a student is in need of an internship, reference, scholarship, or any other personal matter. If you work hard for them, they will return the favor.
A More Open Area – Drinking is a very common thing to see. Drugs don't see to seem to be an issue but the drinking issue isn't that bad, because it is contained.
Well, whenever you wanna go out and party, you can! So get out there already
Just a Bunch of Friends – The campus is a great environment to experience. Everyone is accepting and loving. It's a very supportive group.

Kansas is renowned for it's athletic program in basketball. From a road named after James Naismith, to it's impressive basketball stadium in Allen Fieldhouse, to it's avid local die-hard fans including both the students, faculty, and even business owners and employees, the love for our team is apparent. Businesses will often have a TV playing a game that's on or feature a special depending on our performance in the most recent game. Aside from basketball, Kansas University has renowned programs in Medicine, Pharmacy, and Law. Many chapters of Greek life cater to these and other profession choices in order to aid the students towards their goals, and there are many student or peer led programs to help other students with their classes. Many of the professors are leaders in research and development of their specialties and much of the equipment and services are state-of-the-art on campus. Our recreational center has been cast on ESPN demonstrating alternative energy usage, and Kansas University is frequently voted as one of the top most beautiful campuses in America by several review sources. The student body is by and large helpful, friendly, assertive, and dedicated. The campus offers plenty of student activities through the union and the separate housing arrangements, and plenty of resources to help.

Prominent, but Not Stereotypical – Greek life is prominent at KU. I wouldn't classify it as a dominating social factor though. There are many people in fraternities or sororities, many people opposed to the concepts or houses, and many indifferent. There are definitely times where it is used as an icebreaker in social events, or even in classrooms with other students. There are more than 50 houses available, split up into several councils should an individual be interested in joining. These can come down to profession-driven ones as well with certain academic concentrations being a major factor. There are some negative connotations about fraternities and sororities by some of the student body, but the general population is indifferent or supportive if they're not involved.

Many people bring their own laptops on campus. If you want to use your own laptop or other wireless device, the network covers the campus and all you need is your online ID and password. Guests can access a separate network, but with decreased bandwidth and more limitations. On the rare occasion when I didn't bring my own laptop to school to the libraries or the labs, I used the computers provided by the schools. They are effective and the internet speed on campus is very fast and powerful. That being said, during periods where students flock to every available computer, be prepared to either have your own computer handy or grab one when you can. Most of the time, however, there are plenty of computers to go around, and the wireless speed is sufficient for either situation. Printers are provided in the labs and libraries, with a minimal charge after an initial number of pages. If you already have a computer and printer, bring them just so you don't have to solely rely on the campus equipment. If you don't have one or either, neither are going to cripple you. The devices provided are more than adequate.

Strict Policies but No Action – There are many speeches and fliers at the beginning of the school year about drugs and alcohol and the punishments involved. But, I have never seen anyone get caught. So, most people don't worry about getting caught and do whatever they want.

Great School to Attend – The school is a very welcoming and easy to attend and to feel comfortable, I am very shyu and have truely enjoyed the classes the the other students I have met. This university lets every one feel at home and welcome.

Parking on campus is very limited and there is a fee to park and then you must take the university bus to the class. The dorms are also far away from the actual classrooms. Fines are expensive and they do now forgive any. There is no actual parking oncampus, it is a closed campus and you must park on the outskirts and pay and then take the bus to class.

Buses Are Very Available – The buses are usually available for your convenience. My only complaint would be that sometimes it takes a long time for them to arrive, however they are very prompt at the on-campus dorms

2008 National Champions – The title says it all. Sports are a big deal at the University of Kansas and all the students get really in to the games. Especially basketball since we are one of the top ranked teams in the country!
Mass Street Has Everything – There are alot of dining options on mass st. Ranging from casual quick dining to nice restaurants like Freestate which are nicer.

Living in the all girl dorm provides convenience to campus and night-life activities within walking distance. It is newly renovated, even though the dining food isn't too yummy, it still provides a good social and studious atmosphere.

Athletic Centers – I have used the facilities and they are really good. There are different gyms within the facility to put on basketball scrimmages, hockey, volleyball or whatever your preference may be. The exercise equipment is very beneficial and some even have mini TV's attached to them that you can watch channels of your choice on when working out.
Fairly reasonable. English professors are more challenging.
Our Own House – Many individually owned houses for rent, close to campus.
The campus and surrounding activities are very electric!

Nice for the Most Part – Classes are never cancelled which is frustrating for students who live off campus. Those who live in the dorms have to leave for class extra early because buses are almost always full.
I don't go to the KU campus enough to know how well the security is there. For a popular school and well organized facilities I'm sure it is very important to them to keep their students safe
Being an out of state student I had hoped for more aid but KU is so worth the cost.
depending on the area, security can be strict. The local bar scene is usually crawling with cops. Campus police does a good job at keeping things under control.

The University of Kansas isn't a big scholarship granter, so looking elsewhere is a must! I only got a few scholarships outside of school so I had to apply for loans. KU does have a good loan program though! Plan ahead for what you need you end up paying out of pocket the differnce - not fun!

Venturing Off Campus for a Mean? If you're not wanting to eat the meals at the campus dining, try one of the dozens of other places in Lawrence! Driving down Mass Street one will see plenty of restaurants, such as Buffalo Wild Wings, Buffalo Bob's Barbecue, and more but there are plenty of other restaurants to eat all around town! Of course there are those quick fast food places but there are also my favorites: Steak and Shake, Five Guys, Jimmy John's and 23rd Street Brewery! There's always something good cooking in Lawrence, no matter what time.

Driving through Lawrence, one will almost surely recognize it as a college town. With friendly restaurants, plenty of shopping around the famous Massachusetts Street, educational attractions at the museums on campus, and tons of activities going on at the Union (such as Free Bowling, cheap movies, social events, and much more!). There is plenty of opportunities to get involved with the community, events from ringing bells for the Salvation Army to serving/cooking food at the local Soup Kitchen. Lawrence is a very friendly town, where students are apart of the community and work with other citizens to maintain an enjoyable city!
It takes awhile to get through the process of it all...but if you have a small department with lots of money like I did, then you might strike gold...almost literally.
Pretty Good – There are so many hills ice and snow can cause problems. But classes never get canceled because of snow.
Very Liberal – Very unaccepting of Christianity and major leans to anything morally questionable. Very free thinking and actions.

KU is the perfect balance of fun and seriousness. There is a ton of nightlife here, but theres also a lot of people in the libraries at all times. So many groups to join. Tons of activities and friends to meet.
Take the Bus – Don't waste your time with parking passes. There are tons of bus routes and they're free.
Repetitive but Yummy – There are not a ton of options, but the food is good.
Have Not Seen Signs – do not feel that drugs are very prevalent, at least in my peer experience
This course load is very competitive and prestigeous. Workload is tough at times, but I Love not having to share my studio desk with others and the environment

Bus Vs Car – The busing system for campus is great. It covers most of town in a relatively short bus ride. However, the farther from campus you get, the less often the bus comes by. However, there is not nearly enough on campus parking and it is very expensive to buy a permit and the parking attendants ticket consistently.

Housing is very easy to come by in Lawrence. It is a bit pricy, considering the size of the town, but they are very close to campus. The new integrated school/city bus system makes living off-campus a viable option for students.

Basketball the Best Tournament Ever~! Anybody can Join varsity sports and have fun~! There is no professional experience needed to join different variety sports; and I believe University of Kansas has the best sport and workout facilities compared to other schools in Kansas. Basketball tournament is the biggest sport event in Kansas University.

Feels Like Leaving in a Nunnery – As soon as you enter any classes, the first thing you'll notice will be "Where are the guys?" Out of 100%, I believe the population of the girls at KU is 80%! However, the girls are very good hot like Angelina Jolie and pretty as well.Interest of every student is diverse, but majority of students are involved in sports. Especially Basketball tournament is the biggest hit in our school, and it is easy to make friends because they are very friendly and there is thousands of different club or organization you could get involved with.

In Kansas University, there are Computer labs every school buildings and liberties which KU students have free access to; and each lab has laser printers. However, with fast WiFi, speed of 100.00mbPs, majority of students prefer using their own laptops, and prefer to have their own printers in their home because they don't have make a trip to computer lab every time they have to print something. It saves time.

The University of Kansas is a school that honors tradition. One tradition at KU is the Bell Tower. It is said that if a student walks through the Bell Tower before he/she graduates that student will not graduate in four years. Many student believe this curse and stay far away from walking under the Tower. We also used the Bell Tower during KU football games in Memorial Stadium. Every time the Jayhawks score a touchdown the Bell Tower goes off and the crowd goes wild. Another tradition at KU is our Rock Chalk Chant and the tradition of basketball excellence. Within the walls of Allen Field House are memories of many basketball wins for the Jayhawks. During the final seconds of a winning KU basketball game a chant from the student section erupts. "Rock Chalk Jayhawk KU!" The entire stadium vibrates with the sound. The players, the coaches, even the press cameras can here the erie chant. The University of Kansas is proud of it's many rich traditions.

At the University of Kansas we have a whole area dedicated to student housing. The area is called Daisy Hill. We have 5 residence halls named; Templin, Lewis, Hashinger, Ellsworth and McCollum. Usually freshmen live in the dorms but they are open to anyone. McCollum residence hall holds over 900 students and is open year round for KU's many foreign exchange students. For upperclassmen who want to live on campus we have Apartment Style housing. These are called Jayhawker Towers. Many star athletes live in these apartments as well as upperclassmen. The University of Kansas provides its students with many different places to live and study.

The University of Kansas has a vast amount of student facilities on campus. Our Student Union is always hosting an event for students. From poster sales to early film screening, the Student Union has it all. Also an important resource for students are KU's various libraries. We have different libraries depending on the main subject matter of the information. Watson Library however, carries the general information for English classes and Majors. Our athletic centers are always busy here at KU. Our student Recreational Center is never empty. Also our Sports Education building is full of classes for students to take to maintain a healthy life style. The University of Kansas has a wealth of facilities for students to use.

Pot Paradise – Depends on your scene, but drugs are quite common in Lawrence, KS, especially the Devil's Lettuce. Not a big deal if you do drugs, not a big deal if you don't. Every freshman is required to take an online Alcohol Education course that touches on drug use and smart decision making. Alcohol is far more popular, however.

Not a Greek – Greek Life is quite prevalent at KU, but for the non-Greek, it does not have to affect them. Certain Greek houses have reputations and are therefore stereotyped, but not all Greek houses are seen as bad. Some are just seen as "better".

Beer Booze and Alcohol – There are parties every night. Even during finals week. Harder partying starts on Thursday and goes through Sunday morning. There are dozens of bars right off campus and in downtown. The Granada and the Bottleneck have gigs every weekend. The Granada books gigs as small as local bands and as big as M.I.A., Lily Allen, Tech N9ne, etc. They also hold black out raves on occasion. There are many places for underage people to go and dance like Abe and Jake's Landing. Transportation- KU provides a volunteer-based SafeRide and SafeBus for free to any students who call to be picked up. For the non-drinking student population/Christian population, there are numerous Christian houses in the Student Ghetto that host dry parties. These usually involve dancing.

The Hawk Scene – The guys and girls of KU: you will get different types of girls and guys, you have your preppies, geeks, socialites, party goers, quite and shy types. All the guys and girls are pretty much cookie cutters especially the girls, blonde, big glasses and tan. It is fun to watch how people act for me, and for the most part the students of KU are fun.

Top Notch – The athletics are the University of Kansas are top north, the creme of the crop, the best of the best. They are not only outstanding athletes but have great fans, amazing support, grade A facilities, and are greatly involved within community service around town.

All Around the World – Diversity on campus can be compared to telling 100 different people in every country to come to one place to congregate. There are people from every end of the globe within the campus atmosphere. The only challenges faced are when communication is at a minimum, but I think it is great and allows for growth in all students.

Full Meal Deal – The off-campus dining options seem to never end. They have a large variety of different ethnic foods, as well as your average hole in the wall pizza. KU cards can be used in a large amount of the restuarants, so the prizes are always afforadable! I don't have one favorite, which is why it is so easy to not go to the same place everyday!
It is best for you to have your own PC for studies. The labs are good but not allways available, especially during peak times. Network is very reliable though.

L-Town Life – Lawrence, KS is one of the best places in teh nation to go to school. It is a well recognized school, for both acedemics and sports. A lot of pride and leadership have come from this university and it is reflected in the culture and vibrance of the students.

Good Shuttles – The shuttle buses on campus are very convenient and are free with your ID card, but don't really run later at night. There is also free cab service if you are drinking called Safe Ride.

Pretty Loose – There is a lot of partying off campus and a lot of people get away with a lot of stuff. It is a pretty big party school so it seems like maybe there is too much for the police to handle sometimes, and you can usually get off without getting into too much trouble.

Freshman Year – Living on campus my freshman year was a lot of fun. Naismith hall was a great location for me because I played on the soccer team and it was located very close to the soccer field and the weight room and fieldhouse. The food in the cafeteria was not all that great, but it was a great place to meet friends and socialize. Plus there was a lounge area with a big screen TV right outside the cafeteria to hang out and meet people. The campus also has it's main parking area right by Naismith which is convenient and all classes are within 30 minutes walking distance.

Parking on campus is hard to come by during the week. You need to get there early to even get a spot otherwise you park off campus or pay. Parking permits are pretty pricey considering you aren't guaranteed a spot.

Decent Options – There is a wide variety of apartments in Lawrence. You have your high class looking apartment complexes that are fitted with pools, work-out rooms, basketball courts, volleyball, grills, and come furnished. Those apartments usually come with all utilities included but are the most expensive. When you're paying campus fees for the rec and a pool, paying for one in your apartment for $400+ is a waste. The apartments look nice but are the most expensive. Then you have housing that are located in the area know as the 'student ghetto'. Those places vary substantially on price because of how close your are to campus, downtown, and the stadium. Those closest to all three pay the most for location. The pros to living in the student ghetto is the location. You're about five minutes away from everything. The cons are that it's completely crowded with students so parking is a problem, vandalism is high. Finding a cheap apartment is all about research and looking around.

Great Food All the Time – The places on campus to eat are in great locations and very easy to access. There is a lot of variety from quickly made wraps and salad bars, to the fast food joints. There is also various coffee stands around campus for the quick bites of food that you need. The only thing that is difficult is the underground food area. During peak times, the underground is completely full and there is no way of getting a seat without waiting half an hour. Besides that, there is always something there for anyone. They even provide microwaves for those who brought their lunch from home. The eating areas on campus are very accommodating to all the students!

Parking & Security – It is near impossible to park on the Lawrence Campus. Even when a parking permit is obtained, rather than checking their database to verify the fact or ticket you, they will IMMEDIATELY TOW YOUR CAR. Their administrative staff may say one thing, but the parking patrol must get a commission or secret joy to make your life hell. When you believe said vehicle has been stolen since you had a parking permit, you can't get hold of security after 5pm. Jumping through hoops, stranded in 100+ degree weather, hitching rides from strangers to get to the lot they towed your car to was not something this experienced 50 year-old woman enjoyed and IS NOT something I would EVER want to subject my child to. Things have sure gone even more downhill since my son attended at the Lawrence campus. He always had horror stories to tell, but lived off-campus and rode the bus. In the end, he was not even proud enough of the school to attend his graduation.

Edwards Campus Is Great – Edwards campus is a wonderfully welcoming facility with comfortable, well-lit meeting facilities, an accessible library, and a secure parking area.
Lawrence is not.

Closed Down After 5Pm – Whne my class dismissed at 5pm, I discovered my car was gone from the parking lot at Lawrence Campus. No numbers are posted outside for an emergency and after returning to the building and looking online, it was nearly impossible to locate a number to call. Locating a possible number in an obscure corner of a page, even then I had to go through numerous voice prompts. Perhaps this is why crime at KU has gone up dramatically the last couple years.

Had a Good Reputation – I chose KU because it had a good reputation for quality professors and courses. Ninety-five percent of my classes have been at the Edwards Campus which is absolutely wonderful especially for a non-traditional student. The two classes I've taken in Lawrence have been academically enriching but the staff there like to make your life hell whether you're a young student entering academia or the older non-traditional student.

A Place for Everybody – At KU, there is a place for everybody. The athletes often hang out in Allen Fieldhouse, there are all kinds of frats and organizations for people. Rush week for sororities is a huge deal on campus and all of the girls rushing parade around the campus fountain and stand out in front of their houses. There are opportunities for athletes who were active in high school to come up to the university and join a team as a walk on!

It can get pretty cold, but the buses are free and run on campus all day into the evening. School is rarely canceled even due to the snow... but the buses are heated. Warm weather is amazing for campus life. Everyone hangs out on Wescoe Beach and some people draw works of art across the sidewalk with chalk, and vendors come out sometimes and give out food, coffee, all kinds of stuff

I Would Advise You to Go to School and Study – There are a ton of house parties open to anyone but are always being raided by the cops because the open parties are on a common street. The bars are pretty strict on underage admittance and drinking. Undercover cops are often present.
Not Too Strict – I don't think it is too strict by any means. I think it is as strict as it needs to be to keep order and safety of the students and faculty.

Domination Station – KU is VERY Greek oriented. I believe they have a lot of control over the campus and offices held. I,personaly, am not especially a fan of the Greek system at KU. But, I would say for the most part Greek and non-Greek people get along well.

Perfect College Town – Lawrence is the perfect college town. It's not too big, but not too small. There are a lot of things to do in and around Lawrence. A lot of people like to venture 20 or 30 miles to Kansas City, where there are a lot of attractions, especially shopping centers. The town is electrified with school spirit and really is a great place to be.

The weather in this college town can change in five minutes! It's a great place to experience all the seasons and the beauty nature holds. As the boy scouts would say, "Be Prepared" with the proper attire when heading out the door to class!!

Unique Money-Saver, Parents Will Love It! KU offers a four-year tuition compact, so the amount per credit hour will not change for all years you remain enrolled. Tuition rates go up yearly, but increases have no effect once you are locked in at a certain rate. It only lasts for four years though, so graduate on time!

Mrs. E's – Mrs. E's is the biggest campus dining facility on campus, and the one that I visited daily. It has lots of options, and even when nothing looks good, there is always something to eat. They have special events that are very cool and probably took a lot of time. Mrs. E's is also a really good place for an on-campus job, they hire tons of students.
Parties usually require a $5 charge for drinks, but it can be worth it. They are usually pretty full of diverse people too. There are lots of bars and clubs on Mass St. where people like to go to.

Lawrence is a pretty liberal city so the students are diverse--gay, lesbian, straight, black, white, Asian, whatever. Everyone's pretty fit; there are quite a few bike riders in town and on campus. Everyone's pretty laid back and nice.

Pretty Safe and Secure – There are campus police driving around at night so if you're on campus at night you're safe. There have been a few thefts in the art department, but they're working on that. There have also been a few incidents that there could have been more security.

Close but Not My First Choice – Ku is the closest school in my area so it made sense to go there, but its npt my first choice. I feel like they just want my money and try to charge for everything they can think of; it's pretty ridiculous. Most buildings are in very good condition and the professors I've had are very good.

The most common parking area is off campus. Buses come around every 5-10 minutes to pick students up from the parking lot and take them to campus. It takes forever to get to class and would be much easier and faster if KU allowed more parking on campus.
mainly depends on who you hangout with but like most colleges students drink more.

Diverse for Location – very accepting of many different types of people. Not a lot of ethnic diversity compared to many big universities, but for it's location it is good. They seem to attract many students from out of the country too.
New Rec – there's a new rec center that is awesome and free for all students. they have about 7 libraries but usually are packed during finals week.

The University is set in a really unique town, which makes going/living off-campus much more fun and interesting. There is huge variety of academic programs, all with staff very well-respected in their fields. The study abroad program is much bigger at KU than the national average, as about a quarter of the students take part in these opportunities. The social scene is very vibrant so there is never a shortage of things to do.

There are many cool places to eat off-campus, especially on Massachusetts St. in downtown Lawrence. Greek, vegan, Latin American, Vietnamese and many other ethnic food is available for reasonable prices and with many student discounts. There are also all the major fast food restaurants and family dining establishments around town. The Mad Greek is awesome and 23rd St. Brewery is also a really good place to go catch an away game on TV.

There are computer labs available on campus in most libraries and even in the dormitories. Each student is given $8.00 in free printing on their ID, which can be used at the libraries and labs across campus. Reliable wireless access is available on 99% of campus, not including the dorm rooms. Dorm rooms have an ethernet connection for a fee each semester, but the access is extremely reliable. Having a personal computer is very helpful for studying in the library/on-campus or taking notes in class. Having a printer isn't necessary, but does make for one less thing to worry about.
It's mainly white people, some black people, as well as other races, but I honestly couldn't really tell ya.
Computer labs at school are great, and network is always reliable. Wireless is fantastic. Face it, Kansas is great!
There's lots of hills, so when it's icy... life is interesting. Windy days = make sure no skirts. We live in Kansas: "if there's a tornado, wait five minutes... it'll be sunny again."
We have everything. I was surprised at the racial, ethnic, social, and visual diversity of students that I see everyday.

Apparently our school cares more about fancy football stadiums than it does parking. We recently just built a brand new practice field elimnating a LARGE portion of parking options. A lot of people I know strongly prefer living in walking distance, as parking is never a guarantee which just starts off your day badly.

I would have to say that the University of Kansas is well known for having a lot of people who smoke weed. Lawrence is a liberal, "hippie" town with a lot of good concerts which only encourages this idea. There is also a smaller use of drugs in the ecstacy field but if you don't hang out with people who do this, you would never know.

I came to the University of Kansas because they were supposed to be number one in special education. In my first year, the deaf education endorsement was pulled and I was left confused with what to do. I enjoyed my undergraduate courses as their was a wide range in terms of subject, class size, and professors. It made for a great combination and allowed me to be opened up to more ideas of what to do with my life. Unfortunately, as I narrowed it down to Education, advising was poor and I am currently still confused. They expect students to know what they want to do at 18 years of age but show no strong effort in assiting you further beyond that.

Great Downtown Area – Lawrence, KS is a great little town. It is substantially larger and has much more to do than Manhattan, KS, where K-State is. the downtown area has a lot of shopping and restaurants. KU is well-known for the basketball program. Lawrence doesn't have a shopping mall, but Massachusetts street downtown and other major stores on Iowa make up for it.

The facilities at the University of Kansas are really nice. Especially the Kansas Union, which is used just about everything. The Union is used for meetings, classes, resources, and even bowling. The Kansas Union is a great building and people there are willing to help with any problem that a student may come across.

Basketball, Basketball, Basketball – Everyone follows KU Basketball. There have a really great team. However, there isn't much of a focus on the other sports and the overall sports attitude isn't very inclusive.

You Get What You Pay for. Housing at KU is pretty much on a "you get what you pay for" basis. If you work hard and get solid grades you can qualify for a scholarship hall which houses the more serious student. Also, there are a variety of other on campus housing options available to upperclassmen.

Safe as Can Be! The quality of public safety that I've experienced at the University of Kansas is a bit above average for a public school. I keep my doors locked when I leave and I keep the valuables in my car (i.e., ipod, phone charger, change) hidden when I exit my vehicle.
The University of Kansas offers a shuttle bus that is free to all students and facility. The buses are very accessible and run by almost all the major businesses and food.

The University of Kansas offers a lot of places to live off-campus. The off-campus living is close proximity to campus and also they have public transportation that goes through and by almost all off-campus living.
The University of Kansas offers a lot of places to dine while on campus. Students can eat at the dorm or they have the option to eat on campus at some restaurants such as Pizza Hut and Chick Fil A.

I absolutely love the University of Kansas. Being from Pennsylvania, I did not know anyone going out to college, and from day one I made a lot of friends and everyone made me feel welcome. I am so thankful that I am able to go to the University of Kansas. I am receiving a top-tier education for my field, journalism. Also everything at KU is great, the scenery, the buildings, the sports. I would not want to go anywhere else in the country. I love sing our Alma Mater at sporting events and I am very proud to call myself a Kansas Jayhawk. Going to the University of Kansas is the best choice that I have ever made in my life and I love going to Kansas. Rock Chalk Jayhawk!!!!

At the University of Kansas, students have a lot of choices when it comes to parties. They can go to random house parties, or they can go to a Frat and enjoy that party. It all comes down to what preferences the students has. But there is always somewhere to go and it is very easy to find.

Near the University of Kansas, there are a lot of restaurants. There is anything from huge chains, such as Dairy Queen and Chili's, to small local places, such as Papa Keno's and Tellers. The wide variety of places to eat, is really nice because people do no have to go to a huge chain, instead they can enjoy restaurants that were built for the city of Lawrence. The best thing about the restaurants, is that all the local places are essentially on one street, so they are easy to find. The huge chains are spread out all of Lawrence, but they are just as easy to find and get to.

At the University of Kansas, it is not necessary to have a car on campus. The reasoning is because KU offers a public bus system that is free as long as the person as a student ID. It is a great system and saves people a lot of money.

The University of Kansas offers computers to those who do not have one. In every dorm there is a computer lab that students can go and type up their project and print it for free. Also in the libraries, KU offers computers. Those computers students have to pay to print, but each student gets $8 free, and a page only costs $.08.

At the University of Kansas, I get to enjoy learning journalism in at a top tear level. Every year KU is ranked in the top 3 in journalism. It is a great situation for me to be in and having KU's journalism be amazing, it's unreal. KU has it's own school of journalism, which I can enroll in later this year, that allows students to get the best education for the major. Also, since KU's journalism program is so well known, businesses come there to recruit people to work for them right after, or during, they graduate.
Groups and Clubs – there are over 600 organizations. It is a school where everyone can fit in

Rules Within the Dorms – The University of Kansas is strict on their rules within the dorms. there are quiet hours from 11pm-8am during the week. This helps keep the noise down. Residential Assistants patrol the hallways during these hours to make sure that people are being quite. During the Weekends the quiet hours are from 1am-8am. This allows people to be up and socialize but by a certain time people need to start being quiet for their neighbors connivence. Residence Halls are strict on visitors. If a person enters the building after 11pm they must swipe their ID to recognize that they live in that particular hall. If they have a guest then they must turn in a non-student ID and sign the visitor in. Within the dorms the University of Kansas is strict on their rules.
they do their job very well and I feel safe everyday
Campus Life – The dorms are fun and it is a great experience with a lot of diversity

Diversity Among Students – There are a variety of different types of people at the University of Kansas. There are preppy Greek young men however there are also the artsy types of guys. The same goes for the girls on campus. Some girls are the stereotypical stuck up Greek girls and there are also the artistic quiet painter types. The University of Kansas has a diverse group of students.

There are many different people at the University of Kansas. We do a lot of study abroad and so we have many foreign exchange students. We have sister Universities are in Japan and Germany and we have many students from all over the world. Also many students come to the University of Kansas from different states. The people at Kansas are from many different places and they all add to the diversity of the campus.

The Rock Chalk Tradition – The University of Kansas is a very unique school. We are set in our traditions. At football and basketball games the "Rock Chalk Chat" echos throughout the campus. One of the best traditions at Kansas is the Bell Tower. The belief is if you through the Bell Tower before graduation you will not graduate in four years. Many students believe in this superstition. Tradition is rich at the University of Kansas.

The drug use on the University of Kansas is generally not talked about. There are, however, always cliques who participate in drug use. I believe the use is mild though compared to other schools known to be "party schools". The drug of choice at most colleges is alcohol and many student go to bars and parties. However there are smaller groups who smoke marijuana. But I do not believe that students in Lawrence do harder drugs then those.

In Lawrence Kansas there are many off-campus housing options. Many students live in apartments around the city. There are busses that go to all of the major apartment complexes. For the smaller areas the students may have to walk down the street but there are many busses to transport students to and from school. The University of Kansas very easy to get to for off-campus students.

Jayhawk Spirit – The University of Kansas is a huge basketball school. Allen Fieldhouse is packed for every game and the students are energetic for every game. However, we also get excited for other sports. There is always a huge turn out for our football games even though we are not a football school. Also our basketball team is pretty well recognized by our student body. The Jayhawk spirit is vivid in our student section at all of our sporting events.

In Lawrence Kansas there is a variety of dinning possibilities. A couple restaurants off-campus accept student ID's as a form of credit. The Student ID's have money on them called Beak 'em Bucks, students use them for off-campus food and laundry. By using these Beak 'em Bucks at restaurants students can go to other places other then on campus dining halls. The restaurants are easy to get too and students can take the campus bus nearly everywhere around Lawrence. Lawrence Kansas is a great town for college students to go and eat.

A Great College Town – Lawrence Kansas is a small college town with an active atmosphere. The campus of the University of Kansas holds many activities such as the Relay for life. Around the town there are many things to see and do. There is a variety of great restaurants to try and many places to enjoy musical performances. Also if you wish to be in a larger city Kansas City is about 45 minutes away. Lawrence Kansas is a fun and active college town.
Parking passes are very expensive and the lots are still quite a hike from most classes. The bus system is excellent though, and free for all students.

There is no lack of things to do on the weekends and even during the week at KU. Walking through the "student ghetto" you will find many house parties, and there are several bars that are known for having a big crowd and good drink specials for each night of the week. It is not hard for underagers to get into many of the bars in town, and even easier for them to find a fake ID. Even if they don't do that, there's always a plethora of house parties to attend. Lastly, KU's Saferide and Safebus services provide every student a sober ride home.

Campus Safety – I have felt afraid for my safety on occasion on campus but mostly because I have a habit of studying at the library very late into the night. When walking to my car afterwards I sometimes get spooked, but nothing has ever happened to make me fear for my safety.

Thank God for Buses – The hills at KU are crazy. When it rains, a lot of kid just don't go to class. The dorms are a good eight minute walk from the main part of campus so when the weather is bad, most kids take the bus. In Kansas, it will rain at a moments notice, so make sure to keep an umbrella handy.

Most Fun of Your Life! Greek life is one of the best things about KU. There are tons of fun frat parties nearly every weekend and they put on a ton of events during the weeks to raise money for the community as well. However, if you don't participate in the greek scene it's not a huge deal.

Where Did All My Money Go? The food at KU is amazing. There are several places to eat on campus and at the residence halls. Everything from Chinese, salads, wraps, and quesadillas are available for students to purchase for a fairly low price.

Born and Raised a Jayhawk – Growing up in Kansas, I had no desire to attend anywhere else and after being here, I know why. KU has a great student atmosphere, incredible academic resources and support and a basketball team that wins championships!

Strict With Dorm Regulations – The campus is somewhat strict regarding the dorm rules and regulations. In the all girls dorms, boys must sign in and out if spending the night over on weekends. Also, they are somewhat tough on the greek organizations regarding suspensions and probational periods.

Resourceful Library, Great Rec Center – The library at KU Medical Center is a great resource for students. They provide numerous study rooms for students to study in private, helpful staff and an extensive list of journal databases that help with research projects and papers. The rec center provides free classes along with new equipment, a pool and basketball court. It's a nice way to ease the stresses of school.

The Town Is Quaint but Full of Character – Coming from a big city like Miami, it was initially a shock to get over how quiet the town of Lawrence is, but after adjusting I love the quaint town feel and the sense of history.

2009 NCAA Champions – KU is widely known for it's sports program. Especially with the basketball team winning the NCAA championship last year. For those interested in athletics the choices are many and varied.

Copious Living Opportunities – With the high amount of houses for rent, fair amount of apartments, and suburban sprawl Lawrence, KS has a variety of options for those looking for off-campus living. Although the most plentiful of those options are the houses for rent, so look into roommates.
The entire staff at the University of Kansas are very helpful with trying to help you find money for school. They also provide many opportunities to get involved around the campus.

Hills Cause Problems – With Kansas weather in the winter, the hills on KU's campus can become very icy and not easy to provide transportation on. When the weather is nice though, transportation and mobility around the campus are easy.
There is much diversity on the University of Kansas' campus. Mostly because of the study abroad programs that allow the university's students to accept new challengs and accept other culturess.

Campus Living – Living on the University of Kansas is relaxing none the less. It's atmosphere provides for fun times but also allows for the times when students need to begin studying in a relaxing setting. Life on KU's campus is refreshing and is set out to make the college experience worthwhile.
Ugly to Sexy – You will find all kinds of people at KU, some you don't even want to look at other you don't wanna stop looking at.

Excellent Overall – All considered, the facilities are pretty great. The recreational facility is brand new, there are several cafeterias with at least some variety and classrooms are generally well-equipped technology-wise. There are a good number of computer labs but seeing as the student population is so significant, it's not uncommon to have to wait during peak hours.

Healthy Except for the River – The campus is well-patrolled and I've never felt threatened anywhere in Lawrence. The university health clinic is great, very accessible. The river is unfortunately one of the most polluted in the US, however, and none of our lakes are natural so they all have murky water.

Lawrence, KS – Lawrence boasts a phenomenal community due in large part to the university. We seem to have an ever increasing population but still manage to maintain a small town feel. There truly is something for everyone.

If You're Outside the System, You Probably Hate It – The members of the Greek community give it rave reviews. It certainly is a great way to make friends, meet lots of people of the opposite sex, connect with alumni, and get involved in community service. However, you can do all of those things as an independent, although there might be a little more effort required. By and large, people outside the Greek community find it annoying. If you're not a fan of North Face jackets, Ugg boots, and polo shirts, it's probably not for you. While there are some exceptions, Greeks tend to be preppy and conservative and look down on unaffiliated people. There are many, many Greek houses around campus, and groups of frat guys and sorority girls tend to fill up entire bars, use their numbers to set up camping groups for the best seats at basketball games, and Greeks tend to dominate student Senate elections. The attitude toward Greeks are based mostly on stereotypes. There are many great people in the community who do not fit those descriptions, but there are enough that do to perpetuate the stereotypes.

Whatever You Want, Lawrence Probably Has It – Finding something to do on Friday and Saturday nights is never an issue at KU. The off-campus student population is concentrated in a neighborhood affectionately referred to as the "student ghetto." If you're underage, you can wander Ohio, Tennessee and Kentucky streets until you find a big house party, where strangers are usually welcome to come in and buy a cup. There are also lots of parties in the dorms, especially McCollom and Oliver. Fake IDs are also extremely popular, but some bars are likely to catch you (Louise's), while others are very lenient (the Hawk). There are also a few clubs such as the Chateau that are 18+. For people over 21, Mass St has a wealth of great bars catering to every social scene. There are several places with good dance floors (Taproom, Replay), cozy, literate hangouts (Henry's), Greek dominated bars (Brother's) and several places where you're liable to see just about anyone (Louise's, Harbour Lights, Barrel House). Lawrence also has a unbelievable music scene, with national tours frequently stopping at the Granada, Bottleneck and Liberty Hall, and there are a number of quality local bands as well. Most of the nightlife in Lawrence revolves around alcohol, and probably about 95% of students drink on a regular basis, but for those uninterested in drinking, Student Union Activities (SUA) puts on cheap movies, free bowling and other activities. If you really want to avoid the alcohol scene, or if you just want to meet people, joining SUA is a great idea. Liberty Hall gets lots of great indie and international films, and there are many great coffee shops downtown where you can find a good conversation any night of the week. The scholarship halls sort of live in their own universe, but they seem to have a mix of drinkers and non-drinkers, so that might be a good place to find alcohol free activities.

Great Quality and Variety, but Pricey – The two main cafeterias on campus are in the Union and the Underground in Wescoe Hall. There is great variety - both places have Pizza Hut Express, a sandwich shop that makes great wraps, sushi, and a really good salad/soup bar. The Union also has has a grill with fast food quality burgers, chicken sandwiches, french fries and mozzarella sticks, as well as a Chipotle-esque mexican place and a gourmet counter that has a few high quality entrees, with different themes daily, ranging from pastas to asian to breakfast. The underground has a Chick-fil-a and an asian place. The quality of the food at all those places is generally quite good, and obviously there's great variety, but it can be hard to spend less than $5-$6. Wescoe has a fairly small seating area, so during the lunch rush it's hard to find a table, although when the weather is nice, the best outdoor hangouts on campus are right outside. The Union has plenty of seating and TVs, but it's on the edge of campus, so it's a little bit of a walk from most of the classrooms. There are also retail cafeterias in some of the dorms that are open late, which is very convenient and makes for a nice study break.
